movie_review_blurb: The producer's hand is heavy in No Place on Earth, but it ultimately can't sink the inspiring tale of endurance.

Organic interactions are interrupted by Gondry's words, or abandoned in favor of fantasy sequences. The film's verisimilitude too often takes a backseat to conventional storytelling and Gondry's whimsical aesthetic.
Nicks nets moments that are at turns horrific and touching, redemptive of those seeking treatment and the workers who provide it where no one else will.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love (1995)

movie_review_blurb: There are few moments in Warrior's Gate that seasoned viewers will not recognize for what they are the minute they happen.
The tired zombie apocalypse genre gets a refreshing shot in the arm in Shinsuke Sato's I Am a Hero.
The mother of all allegorical monsters takes on new meaning in a talky, vaguely nationalistic reboot that slips on like a comfortable sweater, even if it's a sweater with some holes in it.
Kim Dae-hwan's debut is an assured, if occasionally labored exercise in uncomfortable family dynamics rooted in the simmering resentment and repressed rage that only families can engender.
Ultimately the story is secondary to the action, which rarely lets up and never lets viewers down.
The trouble with Chongqing Hot Pot is that despite its brief running time, it takes too long to bring its various threads together.
Chow and To don't tinker with the lore's DNA too much, but fortunately they have Peng to freshen it up, and even the specter of Li does little to detract from his emerging star power.
movie_title: Rise of the Legend (Huang feihong zhi yingxiong you meng ) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chow and his army of writers (seriously, it took nine people to write this) get terrific support from a strong cast of regulars and newcomers who really sell the story, cheesy special effects aside.
Strips the silly fun and relatively straight-ahead narrative from the original for a humorless, if photogenic spin on extreme crime.
Coming Home sinks into a conventional tragic romance rut that not even engaging performances by Gong and Chen can save.
Bottom line, The Beauty Inside works for the fantastical, soft focus romance it is.
A surreal and haunting procedural.
Pandora ticks off all the current societal scares and packs them into one slightly bloated, often shrieking action drama that nevertheless gets the job done despite its worst narrative instincts.
It's the fourth collaboration between Grant and writer-director Marc Lawrence, and it could be their strongest outing to date.
Love the One You Love's strengths lie in its normalcy, in the recognizably banal beats of working at a relationship and the mundane factors that can sabotage them.
After about an hour of Wei's amusing escapades, however, things take a turn for the decidedly vicious.
On any number of levels, Devil is troublesome at best, offensive at worst.
Imperfect but timely drama that puts a human face on a frequently demonized people.
Dresnok comes across as honest and credible, and his story is absolutely fascinating.
Bong's typical satirical, almost absurdist humor is in evidence here -- most vividly in a funeral scene that disintegrates into hysterical fisticuffs -- along with a touch of socio-political comment.
This is a strong, assured debut and just the jolt the Hong Kong industry needs right now.
Director Cho shows a steady hand and a good eye.
For anyone who saw Election, Johnnie To's masterful, modern reworking of the Hong Kong Triad drama and its mythology, Election 2 isn't so much a sequel as a logical extension of the story.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Dora's extremely gentle satire about bigotry, redemption, faith and acceptance has the kind of sweet nature that helps it pull off its ridiculous premise.
Scoop! may not be terribly original, but it is an engaging and resonant low-key drama about an aging paparazzo trying to reinvent himself and stay relevant as his skill set becomes obsolete.

Predictable though it may be ... Wei has been careful to replicate the whimsical ebbs, flows and beats required of the form, and 52Hz, I Love You captures the cotton candy essence of the musical romance rather effectively.
A reflective and refreshing character-driven drama.
Cheang does his able best to balance a love story with the heightened fantasy action expected of the previous two films, and after a rocky start he largely succeeds.
Namiya is a case of "If you've seen the first one, don't bother."
As intellectually and morally unassailable as it is, I Can Speak, as a film, is emotionally manipulative and narratively schizophrenic.
The film tells an outrageously labyrinthine tale of power, corruption and lies pivoting on a ruthless matriarch and the daughters she is ostensibly gaining all her wealth for.
movie_title: The Bold, the Corrupt, and the Beautiful (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A pedestrian sci-fi jaunt that brings nothing new to the table.
A three-hanky weepy that's not nearly as grating as it should be.
movie_title: Along With the Gods: The Two Worlds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A willfully oddball martial arts drama that rises above its modest station thanks to star Stephy Tang's lead performance.
Familiar but nicely realized.
A quietly powerful portrait of childhood grief.
Despite Headshot's flaws, it does have a mesmerizing quality in its illustration of humanity's dark side, social and spiritual. It's a film that coaxes into its world rather than drags.
[Li has] put more artistic weight on the film than it can bear and needs to accept pulpy entertainments like The Brink for what they are.
There's a fair amount to unpack in Glass Garden, which, for its often forced lyricism and muddy storytelling, makes for a compelling view.
Simply retrograde, fan-fiction level hokum that allows some icky messaging to slip past the radar.
Sky Hunter barely even cuts it as an action film.
A typically nonsense piece of science-fiction entertainment that will please fanpersons of the form ...
Exactly as heartbreaking and infuriating as it needs to be.
A conventional and predictable but disarmingly entertaining actioner.
Love Off the Cuff's little parts add up to a much greater whole.
At times visually arresting and intellectually engaging, Wong too often hijacks himself by shoehorning in some stunted backstory and making random, questionable creative choices.

Vampire Cleanup Department's special effects (by Fong Wai-kit) are suitably cheesy, and supporting turns by favorites Siu Yam-yam, comedian Jim Chim and Eric Tsang lend the whole affair some old-school credibility.
movie_title: Vampire Cleanup Department (Gao geung jing dou fu) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lau has done a fine job of recreating the period, but he's let down by an overstuffed script by Chan Man-keung that can't decide on what it wants to be.
Wilson whips up an efficiently sleek actioner that knows where its comfort zone is and doesn't stray from it.
The Adventurers is every bit as generic as its title ...
Berlin Drifters will ... be hampered by its raw production values and hit-and-miss performances, but even those can't really disguise the film's fundamentally sweet-and traditional-heart.
A welcome departure from the martial actioners, retro gangster epics and crass comedies Hong Kong has largely been pumping out lately.
The script is deeply nuanced and moving, and all the performances beautifully understated. The gorgeous cinematography is second only to the glorious scenery.
Battle of the Sexes gets it right where it counts by conveying the complexity of Billie Jean King's story - and reminding us all that the fight for basic fairness isn't over.
The Fits follows 11-year-old Toni, portrayed with nuance and grit by newcomer Royalty Hightower, on her journey from standoffish tomboy to member of an elite dance squad.
Director Keith Maitland does a beautiful job traversing both darkness and light.
If it's free and you're hungover on a Sunday morning someday when this is streaming, go for it. But otherwise, save your Fandango dollars for a movie that makes more sense.
The teenager who lives inside your head will giggle, while the more highly evolved parts of your brain might wonder if it is a Trojan horse for parodying xenophobia, extremism, and sexual repression.
The movie is subtle, full of quiet power, and showcases finely crafted performances from all but one of its key players (Nick Kroll).
This is an enjoyable movie for fans of country music, for whom the rich soundtrack should be a delight. And if they happen to have a crush on George Strait, so much the better.
Roberts asks her students rhetorical questions: What makes art good or bad? Who decides? But the movie answers them as canonically as the syllabus Roberts abandons.
An average, uneven, coming-of-age flick with decent performances.
A personal, yet impartial picture about the messy complications and contradictions of brothers, family and personal relationships.

It has its moments, but it also has long, slow stretches where you feel like standing up and wandering around and maybe going out to hunt up a beer. That's fine for baseball, but it's not the way movies are supposed to work.

The movie offers some potty humor and jokes aimed at adults, but nothing the tot crowd can't handle. It isn't as predictable as its predecessor, keeping even moms and dads on the edge of their seats with its nonstop action.
You will find yourself shuddering at the slam of every door and screaming at every sight of a corpse-pale face and gnarled hand.
Carries with it the whiff of Harlequin, the mouldy and tired air of a cottage paperback left on the dock.
To put it mildly, the doc is way more than just T&A , Bunnies and centerfolds. Although there's some of that too.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a pretty picture, but it sure is a compelling one.
Leaves too much time for Demme as he turns an interesting character study into a full-blown tribute.
Extremely timely and intensely affecting, Milena Kaneva's passionate documentary takes us on an eye-opening trip into the Burmese jungle.
Sweet it is. Remotely connected to real life, however, it is not.
A little resistance might have done the project some good.
Though Harden has the showier role, a subdued Pantoliano is the movie's real star. Sometimes, the quietest performances are the most powerful.
An anemic adaptation of Steve Niles and Ben Templesmith's creepy comic series, 30 Days of Night is lighter on horror than it is on inadvertent humor.
So what's it all about? Got me.

Fans like Bruce Springsteen and Bob Dylan express unvarnished awe, but it's the well-told arc of Seeger's life that makes the strongest impression, as director Jim Brown takes us from the highs to the lows and back up again.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We chart the growth of a woman and a country at the same time, a tough assignment that Harper tackles with humor and passion (even if her Kissinger impersonation could use a little work).
Structurally, it's a bit murky, but in every other way Gone Baby Gone marks a triumph for the Affleck brothers.
This death trap may be rusty, but as long as it keeps generating fresh blood, it's unlikely to slam shut anytime soon.
A marvel to watch.

A modestly impressive debut -- especially considering that writer/director Ash Christian was 21 when he made it -- this poignant comedy will appeal to anyone who vividly remembers what it's like to be a high school outcast.
Unfortunately, a single, compelling plot would have been far more effective than earnest lectures in triplicate.
From its extravagant costumes to its pompous score, The Golden Age is packed with distractions. But the biggest of all is the story itself, which works so mightily to tarnish the queen at its core.
Not even Hollywood could invent a romance more extraordinary than this one.
The movie suffocates under the weight of too many wrong choices.

Half drama, half social tract, Guy Moshe's feature debut is meant to illustrate the horrors of child prostitution in Southeast Asia. The intentions, unfortunately, are more notable than the execution.
Never promise wonder when all you've got is manufactured whimsy.

You know that deflated feeling you get after you've spent a lot of time and money shopping -- and have little to show for your efforts? This disappointing biography, about performance artist Reverend Billy, does an awfully good job recreating it.
If you enjoy time spent in the kitchen, you may find some surprising enlightenment in Brown's observations.

One could say there are two kinds of people: those who appreciate Charles Nelson Reilly, and those who don't know enough about him. This engaging documentary will charm the former and educate the latter.
More significant in its sense of purpose than its uneven execution.
A disquieting, and somewhat disjointed, call to arms.
You've just found one of this week's hidden treasures.
Even when their picture wanders from any reasonable path, it's never less than stunning to look at.
The most searing film I've seen this year.

There are thousands of untold stories still left to emerge from the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. It's worth hearing the ones Alex LeMay shares in this compassionate, if somewhat underdeveloped, documentary.
The awkwardly told story of salsa legend Hector Lavoe, El Cantante doesn't even get the title right: It should have been called La Esposa, since it's really less about the singer than his wife.
Daddy Day Camp, the unexpected sequel to 2003's barely watchable comedy Daddy Day Care, is superior to its inspiration in one very significant way. It's three minutes shorter.
You'll be untangling Dresnok's knotty reality long after you leave the theater.
Heartbreaking and hilarious...
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If you've never been particularly fond of Atkinson's brand of slapstick, you certainly won't be converted by this trifle.
While Illegal Tender has misguided pretensions towards Serious Filmmaking, it's surprisingly likeable if you see it instead as a cheesy thriller good for a lazy Friday night.

Lennon, Garant and Fogler are masters of the prolonged punch line, extending a joke so far that it hits funny, whizzes into the stands, then bounces back. The same, come to think of it, could be said for their movie.
Note to fledgling directors: when making a movie, you don't have to do everything yourself. In fact, you probably shouldn't.
Although the movie is hardly more ambitious than its young protagonists, there's a lot of value in a lazy day. Quiet City knows where to find it.
Israeli director Eytan Fox specializes in blending the mundane with the extraordinary -- an everyday dichotomy for the characters in his sensitive drama about life in Tel Aviv.
Paul Auster's suffocating romance makes you feel as if you're helplessly stuck inside the head of the most pretentious person you know.
movie_title: The Inner Life of Martin Frost (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Oh, what stories these heroes have to tell.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is mighty tricky territory, and Cahill deserves major credit for keeping the story from becoming mawkish or twee.
[Director Jacobson] skillfully turns one man's story into a spirited portrait of a good-time town.

On television, Amanda Bynes' tendency toward slapstick can come across as sitcom-cute. Blown up on the big screen, it's the equivalent of a hammer hitting you over the head. For 90 minutes. In surround sound.
...the unpolished actors and raw São Paolo setting offer an unusually authentic feel.
Overwritten dialogue is matched by melodramatic performances.
movie_title: The Beauty Remains (Mei ren yi jiu) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is a comfort film, the on-screen equivalent of mac and cheese -- though with a splash of truffle oil to class things up.
All the couples have palpable chemistry, and Kinnear and Freeman seem so convinced they're in a respectable movie that they actually make it one.
Director Andy Fickman seem to have thrown everything into this artificial comedy, in the hopes that something might stick. Almost nothing does.
Illuminating and deeply distressing.
A reasonable choice for bored tweens -- as long as they don't demand too much magic from their movies.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Amir Bar-Lev began this documentary as a fairly straightforward portrait of a prodigy. What he ended up with was a complex examination of art, the media and the nature of fame.
The entire cast is fully committed to this squishily sentimental tale, which is especially impressive given that it's the kind of generic dramedy you'll swear you've seen a thousand times before.
Here's hoping Karslake's film won't simply preach to the converted.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The plot is contrived, the performances are all over the board, and Chomski's camera ogles his actresses just a little too much.
Cute and clever enough to enchant little girls -- not to mention their mothers.
It seems sacrilegious to dismiss a zombie movie by Romero, who's been blending horror and satire since 1968's Night of the Living Dead. But his latest approach feels uncomfortably behind the curve.
It would be nice to say this predictable fantasy has such a big heart, we can forgive its excesses. But director Kirsten Sheridan overplays nearly every already-corny scene.
Very good but very grim, Paul Andrew Williams' punishing debut doesn't pull many punches -- although the characters certainly field their share of body blows.
Completely predictable.
[Reynolds] is -- once again -- better than his material, which relies too heavily on obvious sentimentality and lazy '90s nostalgia.
Most of the jokes either drag on endlessly or are cut short without a real punch line.
As the girls' mother, Kristin Scott Thomas is basically reduced to shaking her head, sighing and wondering how things turned out so badly. Indeed.
This could have been a perfect choice for the Enchanted set, if only its charms were more than skin-deep.
A provocative reflection of its rule-breaking subjects, Brett Morgen's political documentary re-examines the past while drawing unmissable parallels to the present.
There's no avoiding the fact that Christopher Rowley's feature debut is as uninspired and predictable as your average Lifetime movie.
The movie's power comes less from its contrived story than everything else: the stark setting, chaotic energy and authentic cast.
Make sure to bring extra tissues when you go see Beth Murphy's intimate and inspiring documentary.
The directors take a compassionate approach that encourages their young subjects to open up in remarkable ways, making this a must-see both for girls and the grownups who love them.
There is no question that [direcotr Terry] Sanders has discovered a worthy subject. He just hasn't found the right way to approach it.
It's the low-tech side of Stephen Chow's fantasy that proves the most interesting.
The story's fractured structure -- and Christopher Doyle's dreamlike cinematography -- make for a striking mood piece.
In adapting Winifred Watson's 1938 novel, director Bharat Nalluri strains frantically to evoke the champagne fizz of classic screwball comedies.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you're interested in intellectual abstraction, you might find Haneke's games intriguing. Just be warned: When the movie ends, you'll definitely feel like you've been played.

It's no easy task staying awake through Sleepwalking, a downbeat debut from Bill Maher (no, not that one). Only a typically intense performance from co-star Nick Stahl offers the jolt needed to keep us alert.
With its carefully-chosen soundtrack, funky animation, and enthusiastic interviews, Dean Budnick's affectionate documentary pays apt tribute to Wetlands, a local landmark that closed in 2001.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Negret is clearly less interested in imagining a fictional romance than in conveying his vision of a land that has lost its way.
Even if this movie doesn't quite hit the highs of its predecessor, it's nice to know that there are still filmmakers ready to respect the eternal struggles of freaks and geeks.
Even if you know nothing at all about the game, you'd be hard-pressed to find better entertainment for such a modest entry fee.
So French you may have to buy your ticket in euros, Christophe Honoré's musical trifle feels ready-made for emotionally woozy undergraduates.
Though he doesn't break any new documentary ground, Lee knows how to shoot his subjects. Their stories are moving, and their moves are thrilling.
Eventually something's got to give, and the slapdash feel of Meet the Browns hints that [Perry] might need to give himself a break.
Viewers of any age are bound to be moved by [director Peirce's] primary theme: that there is no easy cure for these damaged young veterans, whether they return to war or fight their demons at home.
An excellent actor too often stuck in unworthy roles, Nick Stahl deserves much better than Andrew Jenkins' derivative, self-conscious heist flick.
[The film] regularly grinds to a halt just so Putnam can capture Hilton running, sunning or simply posing -- usually in slow motion.
Nothing about the movie is memorable, unless you happen to be McConaughey's undoubtedly proud personal trainer.
Spiking sentimental family values with crude hilarity isn't the recipe for an award winner.
In The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, director Julian Schnabel and his gifted lead, Mathieu Amalric, take us on an indelible tour through the highest and lowest points of the human experience.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Originally made to supplement a new DVD release, this is one extra worth watching on the big screen, thanks to additional, and extraordinary, concert footage that never made it into the original film.
While [director] Yu's experimental approach brings valuable insight to the human condition, the interviews themselves too rarely measure up to her ambitious structure.
o matter how silly the situation, each member of the uniformly strong cast creates a nice balance between sentimental and sweet -- which is just how every holiday gathering should feel.

[Director] Schroeder peppers scenes with snippets of classic films, and there's no doubting his deep love of cinema. But the honest truth is that no matter how generous your audience, it's never a good idea to remind us of other, better movies.
Looking for plot holes? You can't miss them. But if you go in hoping for a good time, you'll find that, too.
Between the manic editing, atrocious acting, and laughably pretentious narration, Ritchie's tired tricks feel like empty distractions in a game of three-card Monte.
This is a movie that lobs even appropriate criticisms from a safe distance, a flaw its strengths can't overcome.
Shot in a silvery black and white that lends a photojournalistic effect, this is not an easy film to sit through. But it will be a tough one to forget if you do.
It's a shame that Gabrielle Union can't get better scripts than this one.
Oh, come on. Do you really care? And even if you do, you shouldn't.
For a movie meant to shake viewers out of their ignorance, this clunky drama sure does indulge in a lot of stereotypes.
Touching, if uneven.
A somberly effective look at one of the most shameful events in human history.

Unless you happen to be one yourself, chances are pretty good that you'll take an immediate dislike to the self-satisfied hipsters who populate this disappointing comedy from Heathers director Michael Lehmann.

It's a little corny and somewhat overlong, but a sweet sensibility and stirring adventure scenes make The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep a welcome gift for anyone looking to keep kids entertained over the holidays.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though Ice Cube and Morgan should make an ideal team, neither seems particularly comfortable grappling with Talbert's amateurish script.
Aside from the fun musical scenes, the script is pretty lackluster, and the animation could generously be described as old-fashioned.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone watching this appealing actress march toward the inevitable will wonder why she's settling for so much less than she deserves.
When someone takes our money without offering much in return, don't we have every right to get mad?
By the time it's over, [director Gibney has] broadened his focus into a documentary so damning of the U.S. government, it's hard to believe he even got it made.
How She Move gets it right in every dance sequence, but stumbles badly whenever the characters step offstage (or a car hood, or the sidewalk, or wherever they happen to be practicing).
Some stories, Teixeira is wise enough to realize, are best left unadorned.

Salita doesn't see many other conflicts in his twin passions -- which, ultimately, makes for a less-than-gripping story. He's a likable guy and we're happy to watch his successes, but the movie lacks the emotional punch needed to knock us out.
Obviously, there's no replicating the real thing. But it's as close as you'll come to achieving the best of both worlds.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ilana Trachtman's gentle profile does make for touching viewing, but she leaves too many questions unanswered.

Directors James and Maureen Tusty acknowledge that few outsiders care much about this tiny Baltic nation. And then, through a mix of moving interviews and affecting footage, they show us why we should.
Bursts with so much amped-up energy, you may need to rest once it's finally done.

The beautiful black-and-white photography -- and disappointingly sappy ending -- are the only remotely sober elements here, thanks to Besson's loopy script and Debbouze's very funny turn as a loser who simply can't believe his luck.
The Ten is so proud of its own wit and irreverence that when you fail to be equally impressed, you are likely to wonder if your own sense of humor is, in some way, deficient. Rest assured it is not.
James Scurlock's often riveting documentary is likely to leave you outraged over the manipulative greed of America's banks and credit card firms.
The Namesake is suffused with radiant grace, and manages to be old-fashioned yet immediate, epic and intimate.
At least all this uncertainty is leading up to a spectacular twist ending -- oh, wait. No, it's not.
Designed to elicit as many gasps as laughs, Anders Thomas Jensen's pitch-black comedy offers an audaciously skewed take on good vs. evil.
Though it has a familiar inevitability, the journey is generally compelling, thanks to fierce battles, a gorgeous landscape and heartfelt performances.

If Scott Glosserman's witty slasher spoof had celebrities, it would probably be a success like Scream or Scary Movie. As an indie, it's more apt to be a cult fave. Either way, it's a must for those who like thrills laced with humor.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You'd be far better off tracking down the original tale than trying to untangle Bob Shaye's choppy adaptation.
These characters don't feel like the turtles of old; there's not enough excitement to reinvent the franchise, and just barely enough to revive it.
There is not a single moment in Sunu Gonera's Pride that you haven't already seen, or that you can't predict.
Director Jafar Panahi has long been an eloquent and passionate representative for Iranian women. But judging by this deeply poignant comedy, they may not need a mouthpiece much longer.
The characters may suffer once the bride walks down the aisle, but [director] Bier, [writer] Jensen and their first-rate cast work together like a match made in heaven.
Goldberger's stubbornly insular script might have fared better on stage, where the story would feel more contained than suffocating.
The movie tends to wander between story lines and characters without any real sense of purpose.

[Director] Dornford-May deftly balances the details of his setting with the universality of his themes, exploring every dusty corner of a village thrumming with tension between patriarchal leaders and strong-willed women.
Carr tries to put one over on us by tacking on a sentimental ending. But as any homeowner could have told him, you can't disguise a weak foundation with a cheap finish.
This is an oddly second-rate production for a major-studio release; the underwhelming mystery belongs in a Scooby-Doo episode, and the slapdash direction is just as shaggy.

Written, disappointingly, by Wes Craven and his son Jonathan, this limp sequel to last year's remake of Wes' 1977 original feels like the work of a guy who's spent a few too many days lost in the desert.
What Disturbia lacks in complexity, it makes up for in witty jokes, sneaky jolts and a timeless lesson: If you've got windows, someone's always watching.

People peek through windows, hack into computers and sneak into apartments without the slightest hesitation. We're guilty of voyeurism, too, since the primary pleasure to be found is in seeing three confident leads play off each other.
So insane it approaches a sort of mad brilliance, this full-length Cartoon Network spinoff must have been made with chemical enhancement in mind. Enter with a clear head at your own risk.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Oddly sterile.
If you think about it too closely, Andrea Arnold's jarring feature debut doesn't quite hold up. But chances are you'll be so focused on her lead, Kate Dickie, that you won't even notice.
While some may be put off by Peggy's wild-eyed mania, and the film's broadly comic tone, Shannon makes this lost spirit strikingly sympathetic.

Although the movie's artistic merits are virtually nonexistent, Sadek does understand his audience, most of whom are unlikely to be acquainted yet with two key aspects of the film: driver's licenses and women.

Short, sharp and to the point, Vacancy has a single goal, and that is to scare the hell out of you. It's not as gleefully sadistic as, say, Hostel, but it will give you one very rough night's sleep. Naturally, I mean that as a compliment.
Bong Joon-ho's cheerfully outrageous monster movie is set to attain instant cult status.
In his uneven drama Two Weeks, first-time feature director Steve Stockman bravely delves into the ugly realities of dying. Unfortunately, he has no idea where to go from there.
The movie strolls right past absurdity into offensiveness, by trying to pass this pulp nonsense off as noble art.
What financial strings had to be pulled to get John Travolta, Tim Allen, Martin Lawrence and William H. Macy to sign on for this second-class City Slickers?

Given the physical limitations of their characters, Polley and Robbins give remarkably compelling performances, and though the resolution of their slowly evolving relationship is a bit too pat, it is one you won't soon forget.
Touchingly nostalgic, the sixth chapter in the saga of Sylvester Stallone's eternal underdog packs a far more powerful punch than anyone would have expected.
If the lives of CIA spies are really this dreary, they may as well keep their secrets to themselves.
The Painted Veil may begin too slowly, but it also ends too soon.
Where the first film was a seminal forerunner of early stalker classics like Halloween, this version feels as stale as old gingerbread.

How do films this stale and generic continue to get made, let alone with topflight talent? Cedric has been stealing scenes from bigger names for nearly a decade; he deserves better than a few amusingly-improvised minutes at the end of his own movie.
While new times deserve new tales, this ground has already been trodden -- twice -- by a more memorable ogre than any you'll find in Ella's enchanted forest.
What we get is scene after scene of exhilarating routines, all leading up to the big finale. And with two furiously intense teams ready to dance each other off the stage, it's an absolute winner.
Who would have thought that a real-life tale of sex, drugs and murder could be so instantly forgettable?

Director Wisit Sasanatieng uses every trick imaginable to create surreal postmodern nostalgia. Has he wound up with pure camp, or a cult classic? As he clearly understands, the best B-movies are both.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Narrated by Nicole Kidman, this poignant documentary tells only half the story of three Sudanese 'lost boys' who emigrate to America. Though it doesn't delve as deep as it should, this movie will still break your heart.
Even if circumstances edge toward the unlikely, [director] Kravchuk and [child actor] Spiridonov make an effective team, exploring the realities that lead to so much heartbreak for so many children.
Pegg and Wright are armed with an endlessly impressive arsenal of attention grabbers, from witty editing tricks to a wry soundtrack and a joke-packed script that demands multiple viewings.
There are a few funny jokes scattered throughout, but the halfhearted direction and clunky script are underscored by performances that feel like they belong in community theater.

Go see Anthony Minghella's jagged new drama, Breaking and Entering, and you'll feel as if you're getting two movies for the price of a single ticket. The bad news? Only one of these stories is actually worth your money.

How can you make fun of such self-aware subjects as Borat or Johnny Depp's winkingly fey Jack Sparrow? Who hasn't already noticed Tom Hanks' bad Da Vinci Code hair? And really, is there anything left to say about Samuel L. Jackson and those snakes?
With Factory Girl, Hickenlooper has taken an icon and made her ordinary.
