We know actors are trained to let it all hang out, but Jason Segel takes naked vulnerability to new levels in Nicholas Stoller's likable debut, Forgetting Sarah Marshall.
Armed with little more than a great title and limitless confidence, documentarian Morgan Spurlock sets off in search of the world's biggest bad guy. He comes up empty in more ways than one.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Every actor has a few titles on his résumé that he'd love to forget. So should you ever have the opportunity to meet Deception stars Hugh Jackman and Ewan McGregor, we highly recommend you pretend this movie was never made.
Jon Reiss' high-energy doc hops all across the globe in order to paint the fullest portrait of the most modern art.
Without strong guidance, the self-conscious lines make the characters sound like, well, characters rather than actual human beings.

The cinematic equivalent of a cookie-cutter wedding, Made of Honor ultimately feels a little depressing. Shouldn't any major event, from getting married to making a movie, inspire some hint of passion and creativity?
Young, who directed the movie, compares today's climate with the Vietnam era, and doesn't bother hiding his disappointment in the present.
This does seem to be a world Mamet knows well, and every so often we see flashes of the great movie he might have made.
While Diaz and Kutcher make their clichéd characters as likable as possible, you can bet on this: Any movie named after an already-stale ad campaign isn't likely to gamble on the unexpected.
It's not sharp or ironic, but drab and downbeat. Unfortunately, it's also going to feel utterly familiar to those who've seen their share of independent dramas in the last 15 years.
What kid wouldn't want to spend every day at the beach instead of in school? Well, Doug Pray's absorbing new documentary suggests that no dream is as ideal as it may seem.
Sure, it's a big-budget spectacle. But it's also the kind of grandly old-fashioned entertainment we don't get enough of anymore.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The kind of discovery that comes along only a few times a year (if we're lucky), Joachim Trier's energetic, inventive debut takes such a novel approach to well-worn themes that it makes most movies look downright lazy.
Christian Petzold's disquieting German thriller feels modest while you're watching it, but makes a stronger-than-expected impact.
It's hard to imagine a worse movie will come out this year, and yet Boll's growing notoriety has already earned the trailer millions of hits on YouTube. Ed Wood never had it so good.
The dangers these musicians experience every single day are bound to impact any audience. This is what it really looks like to bang your head against the wall.
Parvez Sharma shares the fundamentalist Muslim perspective, which will look depressingly familiar to anyone who has seen the other films.
Every silence, pause and sudden noise startles -- and the results, frankly, are more frightening than the graphic torture scenes in movies like Hostel and Saw.
They're all over 40 now, and writer/director Michael Patrick King deftly balances their hard-won wisdom with the wistful dreams they still share. At the same time, there's plenty of fun to be had.
There are enough droll moments to spark cult status, and McBride's commitment is impressive.
In this fairy-tale of arrested development, Korine has created his most mature movie yet.
Setting out a grandly romantic dish, Wong encourages us to indulge. And then he leaves us hungry for something more.
'Here we go again,' sighs adventurer Rick O'Connell in The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor, and he's not the only one to notice that things are starting to look awfully familiar.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: By the end, Holdridge has captured the bittersweet complexities of romance with a wisdom that proves surprisingly seductive.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Is it possible to enjoy the company of the world's most irritating woman? Mike Leigh's surprisingly sunny dramedy makes a pretty good case that, in fact, it is.
It's refreshingly snarky and quick.
As for Fanning, she continues to prove herself a natural who can handle anything thrown her way. It's worth wondering, though, if she should have to.
Just slightly funnier than you'd expect, this dashed-off teen comedy cribs from a thousand other movies, without coming up with anything original of its own.
No amount of generosity could excuse the levels of ineptitude on display here.
These eager young amateurs have the kind of passion nobody could fake.
These candidates work hard and play fair, and when they screw up or slack off, they accept the consequences without complaint. Simply because, they believe, that's the way things should be done.
It's hard to complain about a pop culture phenomenon built on unabashed innocence.

The torture devices, once so fiendishly adapted to each offender, have become generic excuses to spatter gore. The script is insultingly lazy, and inept direction from newcomer David Hackl hardly helps.
The script is compelling, the direction confident, the production values professional. But it does not, in the end, feel real.
Next month's Twilight may get more attention, but Tomas Alfredson's understated vampire tale is one you won't want to overlook.

Without the wit, raunchiness tends to feel uncomfortably forced. And the moments when Z&M works are, almost without exception, the ones that are more sweet than shocking. All the rest, frankly, feel like Apatow Lite.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Wilkins understands that what we don't see is often more unsettling than what we do. But he also throws in plenty of well-earned gore, making this an ideal option if you're looking for a few new Halloween scares.

Made primarily for those who already know why Fred Lebow deserves his own documentary, this biography of the New York City Marathon founder isn't quite compelling enough to draw couch potatoes from their living rooms.
Though this is far from Mac's most memorable work, his appealing performance will undoubtedly remind the audience how much he'll be missed.
Self-referential projects are tricky territory, but Van Damme handles himself with such likable humor, this could be a career-changer.
Check out the trailer before you commit to this one; if it's for you, you'll know instantly. And if it's not, you'll know that, too.
When Boyle pulls back to show us his grand vision, it's a stunner. And everything suddenly falls into place, as if this uncommonly daring film was fated to work from the very start.
A fun project that doesn't quite reach its potential, Josh Koury's doc is still worthwhile for anyone who can't wait until 2009 to see Harry Potter back on the big screen.
Wry, observant and frequently heartbreaking.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Anthony Byrne's lazy drama is insulting to just about everyone, including Maeve Binchy, who wrote the short story on which it was based.
Screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg does a decent job adapting the first book in Meyer's series, and despite a tendency toward cheesy effects, Hardwicke keeps things moving swiftly.
It may not be perfect, but this under-the-radar indie from Hal Haberman and Jeremy Passmore is smart enough to leave you glad you found it.
Rafferty keeps the structure so blandly standard, the title is nearly the most intriguing element of the whole film.
Though Luhrmann starts with plenty of potential, he squanders it almost immediately.

The actual plot is so uselessly convoluted you'd get a headache just reading it -- but you might want to pull out the Advil anyway, given Ritchie's reliance on flashy editing, a blasting soundtrack and fetishized gunplay.
And though the film ultimately falls short of its considerable promise, there's more than enough here to keep thoughtful moviegoers - of any age - intrigued.
A film that is both deceptively modest and deeply resonant.
A premise this promising should have developed into something more.
No matter how serious the subject matter, this is an unabashed fantasy for tweens and teens.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Where the biker films of the late '60s and early '70s offered edgy, amusingly cheesy thrills, this sputtering effort is as rusty as an unrestored Triumph Bonneville.
How ironic that a biopic about charismatic punk legend Darby Crash -- lead singer of the Germs in the late '70s -- would be so unmemorably bland.
More enthusiastic than genuinely entertaining.
Be warned: The opening ceremonies for the 2008 Olympics might look a little different if you see Makoto Sasa's disturbing documentary beforehand.
The steady spray of jokes ricochets with machine-gun force, hitting dozens of worthy targets.
While nobody's expecting This Is Spinal Tap, both the audience and the cast -- which is strong all around -- deserve better than the generic script and bland direction here.
Well, you've got to say this for Death Race: It knows what it is and doesn't apologize for it. What it is, incidentally, is junk.
Fortunately, Coogan remains impressively unafraid of humiliation, pushing every joke just far enough to keep us watching. But he deserves more.
A little miracle, Azazel Jacobs' lovely story of a life lost and found tackles big issues -- love, maturity, fulfillment -- in deceptively modest fashion.
David Kaplan's sweet, if superficial, fairy tale won't change the world, but it makes nice use of its setting (Chinatown) and visual style (rotoscope animation).
A lightweight goof that feels a little dashed-off, the latest from cult director Takashi Miike won't earn him any new fans, but might entertain the many he's already got.
Though not the most sophisticated movie, Darryl Roberts' earnest documentary gets its points across with enough power to make it a valuable experience for both adolescent girls and their parents.
Who needs subtitles when you can speak the universal language of stereotypes?
movie_title: Morirse esta en Hebreo (My Mexican Shivah) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Why would you watch a bad movie about better movies, when you could just rent the originals instead?
An abysmal French thriller in which everyone -- Diesel included -- speaks as if they've learned their lines phonetically.
With a title like this, shouldn't Jason Todd Ipson's comedy celebrate Italian culture? Instead, it aggressively insults the heritage it pretends to admire.
A decidedly lightweight amusement, the first comedy from documentary filmmaker Jessica Yu is the sort of movie that works best if you keep your expectations low.
Is it an exaggeration to call The Women the worst movie of the year? Well, yeah, probably. But it may be the most disappointing, given all the effort that went into it.
When film critic Godfrey Cheshire decided to make a movie of his own, he found the ideal subject right in his backyard.
Leave it to the unfailingly brilliant Gervais to breathe new life into an expiring genre.
Rarely has there been a movie as misguided as Hounddog, which self-righteously indulges in exploitation while loudly decrying it.
There's a gentle beauty in these long, anguished silences, and Wang and his actors make the most of it.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though the leads do fine work, their efforts often feel slightly futile.
Lee takes nearly three hours to tell this sad tale, but he never makes the most of the opportunity.

It's an increasingly rare pleasure to see two naturally aging adults onscreen, and it's not exactly hard work to watch this still-gorgeous pair fall in love. Especially if you're overdue for a little vacation from reality yourself.
A film as unique as this is a gift that shouldn't be ignored. And if Menzel once again finds the audience he deserves, we won't have to wait years for another.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While Mark Friedman's script is as unsubtle as Winkler's direction, their sincerity and the subject's sharp immediacy lend the film a certain power.
Still witty and eloquent, these cerebral boys became the haunted men who do their best to share their experiences with us, even as they know we'll never truly understand.

Like its porcine protagonist, E.B. White's classic 1952 story Charlotte's Web manages to be both radiant and humble. If only the same could be said for Gary Winick's live-action adaptation, which is neither.
Should have been either darker or funnier. Or both.
Less likely to haunt an audience than simply bore them to death.
By the time you leave, Jackson will have you believing that his Coach Carter is a true original.
Though Appleseed has its selling points, it's not an especially strong entry in the genre, despite the presence of so many pneumatic heroines.
The special effects here are surprisingly smooth, and everyone seems to be having fun.
Are we laughing yet?
Sloppy, melodramatic yet, ultimately, immensely affecting.
An intimate, affectionate portrait of one tiny pocket of the world.
Fortunately, Turturro's subtle turn keeps our emotional connection solid even when the story skates on thin ice.
In this earnest but ill-conceived message movie, Irish director Damien O'Donnell appears determined to teach us a lesson without quite understanding it himself.
Not a single scene connects smoothly with the next, characters make head-scratching choices that come out of nowhere and logic consistently proves itself an enemy to be avoided at all costs.
Though Daybreak boasts a couple of minor insights and a compelling performance from Pernilla August, only the masochistically inclined will consider them sufficient reward.
Like most cult bios, this barely skims its subject's private life. Fortunately, there are copious clips of Nomi's mesmerizing performances.
Sticking closely to formula, Disney delivers a sweet script and charming storybook backgrounds, with serviceable, if sappy, songs from Carly Simon.
It's not often that you witness the creation of a star, so grab the chance now.
Too superficial to shock or surprise.
A masterful collection of cinematic essays, Agnes Varda's triptych of short films takes its audience from elation to despair and back again.

Reminiscent of the films of Aki Kaurismaki and Jim Jarmusch, this wry, very slow German import by Michael Schorr has amusing moments but doesn't possess the droll absurdity needed to make it genuinely compelling.
Though a bit long and occasionally awkward, this drama ultimately does justice to its inspiration.
The movie works as well as it does because the cast knows the material so intimately.
Fox intends to draw historical parallels between Jewish and Palestinian victims, but the film nearly drowns in earnest morality.
As stripped down as its title, this gentle Argentinian road movie makes much out of very little.
Confusing the profound with the pretentious, director Bessai packs the story with elliptical, ominous flashbacks that undercut all the advances he makes with the contemporary tale.
Harvard President Lawrence Summers recently touched off a firestorm by speculating on why more girls don't display an interest in science. He might consider Tim Fywell's Ice Princess Exhibit A.
This off-putting satire is a jumble of misguided ideas that gather like lint in the navel of self-obsessed director Philippe Caland.
Both Rossi and Charlotte Rampling, as the mother of another young patient, do fine work. But the only surprises come at the end, too late to move us the way they should.
There are few real revelations to be found among these curiously dispassionate radicals, making the overall experience sort of like seeing the movie, instead of reading the book.
A shallow film.
A few genuinely tense scenes are not enough to overcome a thin script, weak direction and an unceasingly high-strung score.
A moving film but not, to be frank, an entirely memorable one.
Hess' deadpan debut could have been so much better if only he'd had the courage to actually appreciate his loser characters.
Gram Parsons' last rites were among the most extraordinary in rock history. Too bad this retelling of the singer's final adventure is so tame.
If you want to laugh at cartoonishly shallow rich girls, you'd be much better off staying in to watch the new season of The Simple Life -- for free.
Feeling for all the world like an extended video game made by teenage boys with no girlfriends and a lot of free time, this sci-fi fantasy doesn't exactly make sense, but it sure looks cool.
Few performances are hardy enough both to blossom in the dark intimacy of live theater and bloom under the glaring eye of a movie camera. Ghostlight is not the exception.
Though the film deals with some heavy issues, director Shemi Zarhin uses a generally light touch, rightly believing that a family drama does not have to be loud to make an impact.
A lazy attempt to snare some preadolescent allowance money, Sleepover earns little more than a few bored yawns.
Kelly's story of a brilliant, disturbed teen (Jake Gyllenhaal) drowning in the cultural morass of the 1980s now feels bloated.
Deftly intercutting between several tenuously-connected lives, Barbara Albert's astringent drama is transformed by bright flashes of compassion.
It's the subject himself, still brimming with passion in his 80s, who provides the most inspiring moments.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: So laughably preposterous that it's thoroughly entertaining.
It's quite a paradox that someone so acutely attuned to racism would so enthusiastically embrace the worst clichés of homophobia and misogyny.

Although their on-board antics are mighty entertaining, it's the extraordinary performances -- including Joplin's historic, heart-rending 'Cry Baby' -- that lift this movie into the cannon of classic festival films.

Having challenged his audience with ultraviolent movies, Japanese shockmeister Takashi Miike throws us for a real loop with a screwball comedy. Granted, we're talking about a guy who considers squashed puppies hilarious.
A challenging, flawed look at a little-known slice of history.
The mildly surreal drama doesn't always make sense, but it sure does look great.
Ought to charm its loyal subjects, or at least their less demanding little sisters.
A feature-length promotion for the trading cards your kids will beg you to buy all the way home.
Even if [Schwartzberg's] choices feel somewhat clichéd, there's no doubting the spirit of his subjects, who seem genuinely proud to share their thoughts and feelings for a few, too brief moments.
There are a few gross-out laughs, but Without a Paddle's gang-written script doesn't know what it wants to be.
All the Benji productions have had a high corn content, but in this one, even the corn is cheap.

While co-writer/director Tanit Jitnukul's vision is unapologetically graphic and slightly marred by an artistic awkwardness, this is a rare and worthwhile glimpse into another nation's historical legend.
Slickly packaged and nicely shot, the movie is as easy on the eyes as its good-looking cast. It's also as confused as its hero.
Dardo Barros gains points for sincerity and good intentions, even if his intimate drama never quite reaches its potential.
Do they have Cinemax in Italy? Because surely that's where this filmy, flimsy fantasy belongs.

It's not surprising that director Joe Maggio got Hal Hartley to score his off-kilter drama. Both upend clichés through a deadpan visual style and mordant performances. As a result, both have had uneven success.
A disappointing retread of a bunch of better movies.
Cute, campy and as proudly insubstantial as its heroines' micro-miniskirts.
Provides some solid entertainment along with its moral and historical lessons.
Pawel Pawlikowski is helped by his young leads, who make a memorable impact in this unsettling romance.
Herbie feels modern in all the right places, with a young heroine whose presence on the track is never questioned or undermined.
Tells this story simply and effectively, with an uncharacteristic restraint that prioritizes genuine sentiment over high-gloss style.
You won't be as easily impressed.
Generally witless ode to illegal substances.
movie_title: The War on the War on Drugs (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Though it lacks a focus or greater artistic vision, Thomas Balmès' no-frills documentary offers Westerners a valuable glimpse into the sweatshops of the new China.
Enthusiastic performances help, but without a logical script or confident direction, the fizz very quickly goes flat.
Brief, underdeveloped documentary.
Felix Van Groeningen's low-budget romance is also sly -- if utterly superficial -- fun.
What makes the film feel genuine, however, are the performances.
Gradually, though, White pushes the film toward significance by encouraging a deeper examination of two primary preoccupations of the region: sin and penance.
You'll be wondering why you're sitting passively in a darkened theater, rather than scaling a cliff or rafting down a river.
If you've ever harbored a secret wish to jump on one of those Big Apple buses or join a local walking tour, you'll find what you're looking for here.
Consistently moving but never quite coalesces into a strongly coherent whole.
A quietly simple fable that hits you hardest after it's over.

Morrison and his cast approach this familiar story with such understated intelligence, we don't even realize they've pulled the rug out from under the audience until we've tumbled to the floor, clichés scattered in pieces around us.
Though undeniably slight, Brian Herzlinger's endearingly enthusiastic documentary My Date With Drew makes a pretty good case for the underdog.
Part exploitation thriller and part sociopolitical statement, Secuestro Express is a little too enamored of its own gangsta cool to be taken seriously.
Writer-director Michael McGowan must be exhausted after all the tugging he does on our heartstrings in this sentimental drama.
Sauper captures a world in which life and death are treated with equal practicality -- and disregard.

Jokes that were barely funny the first time around -- like Griffin's endlessly resourceful terminology for male prostitutes and their anatomy -- now feel as tired as Deuce after a heavily booked weekend.
Though the story is as creaky as a plantation porch, Iain Softley's lushly atmospheric The Skeleton Key does offer a few nifty twists on the classic 'woman in peril' picture.
Not even the widest political chasms, Gordon finds, can eradicate the universal pleasure of a young girl's giggle.
Pretty Persuasion sets out to be a social critique but settles for smug disdain.
Why do filmmakers persist in believing that we want to watch actors pretend to be mentally challenged?
According to Paolo Virzi's vibrant coming-of-age drama, Italian teens are just like their American counterparts, except that who they vote for matters more than what they wear.
Preachy and single-minded, populated by a world of sympathetic heroes and hissable villains.
Éléonore Faucher's quietly assured debut is a lovely, almost painfully intimate story of female bonding that never panders to its characters or its audience.
Nimrod Antal's defiantly mordant comedy is smart, imaginative -- and nearly impossible to watch.
With little plot and a stifling set, the movie needs stronger performances than its leads can offer.
A gracefully understated drama about a widower trying to help his sons - and himself - heal after a tragedy.
The story doesn't make any real sense, and the production values are home movie-cheap.
This topic could have been tackled with greater finesse; Fischer's conclusions feel a bit facile. But his actors do an excellent job portraying young people struggling with an almost manic paranoia.
At least Dash corralled every artist he knew into playing cameo roles, so bored or confused fans can bide their time star-spotting the likes of Mariah Carey, Kanye West and Angie Martinez.
Mostly, Benazzo and Day leave us alone to take in the extraordinary sights and sounds.
movie_title: Short Cut to Nirvana: Kumbh Mela (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A highly amusing folly, rendered with a surprisingly gentle affection.
Zingaretti does a fine job shading a character that is written as an unalloyed saint. But the most touching moments come at the end, when we see documentary footage of his true-life inspiration.
movie_title: Perlasca: The Courage of a Just Man (Perlasca. Un eroe italiano) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A big hit back home, this good-humored gem from Brazilian director Jorge Furtado manages to tackle some serious issues without sacrificing its inherently sweet nature.
Somehow, Jang manages to meld shocking sadism, slapstick laughs and a poignant political plea into a head-spinning trip that, it seems safe to say, is like none you've taken before.
After a while, all these odious, yammering people start to sound a lot like Charlie Brown's teacher. And they somehow all end up together at a time and a place you do not want to be.
A meta-cool history lesson and homage.
Ultimately, Dance is unable to connect the many threads of his rather flimsy script, leading to an abrupt and somewhat unsatisfying conclusion.
This narcissistic mockumentary is less a film than a full-length promotional video for Roc-a-Fella Records mogul/director Damon Dash.
There's plenty of passion beneath this movie's unadorned surface.
Richter's brisk direction keeps us riveted through the suspenseful finish of his vivid history lesson.
An appropriately uneasy blend of graphic military drama and tender romance, Brothers pulls no punches even as its worst violence occurs offscreen.
A genuine pleasure.
The sort of slick-looking indie that plays well at film festivals, this heavy-handed boxing drama is really just a flyweight bulked up on cliches and false sentimentality.
Pointlessly stilted and frustratingly obvious.
This amiable, off-kilter Australian comedy pits parental manipulation against adolescent pride, with generally amusing results.
Arnaud Desplechin's sprawling drama exudes a go-for-broke determination that is frustrating and exhilarating.
This tale of disaffected sexual depravity is practically a parody of the worst of French filmmaking.
Modest but memorable, the first film from 24-year-old director Tommy Davis follows four Mexican friends as they attempt to sneak into the U.S. by trekking through the Texan desert.
If you've ever struggled to watch bowling on TV, you'll appreciate Browne's gifts when the film ends and you realize -- no kidding -- you can't wait to see these guys compete again.
Each stammer, hesitation and nervous laugh reminds us of who we once were, still are or even hope to be.
A vanity project so preposterous it deserves to become an instant camp hit.
movie_title: Adored: Diary of a Porn Star (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some strong performances, the movie never really makes a case for its own existence.
Noujaim ably reveals the splits between truth and perception, raw anger and calculated hypocrisy.
Shockingly wholesome and lots of fun, Lizzie's just the kind of girl parents want their children to hang out with.
Rent Mr. Mom instead, and have a family night in.
Musician Syd Straw unintentionally strikes truth when she sardonically asks about the film, 'Is this more like a fluff piece?'
Abranches intends for a religious parable by way of Greek tragedy, but the film drowns in a morass of portentous signs and poetic symbols.
It's unabashedly derivative and spooky enough to keep you up at night.
Maher's feature debut has amusing moments, but falls apart as quickly as a cheap knockoff.
Novice director Lucky McKee wrote the first draft of this labored horror flick while he was in school, and for a student film, it's not bad. But it's not ready for the big time.
Are we expected to sympathize with this motley bunch? Admire them? Laugh at them? Or, perhaps, relate to them? Against all odds, we do a little of each.
We've seen it all before, and too many times.
The unceasing sadism is so graphically excessive, the director just ends up exposing his own obsession.
Though the energy occasionally flags, the movie does a nice job of exploiting the crossover potential.
A remarkably assured feature debut, Eric Eason's raw, intimate movie deftly captures the kinetic energy of its Washington Heights setting.
Though structured as the biography of the late German pastor Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Martin Doblmeier's engrossing documentary also offers a well researched history of his times.
It has serious themes, long, wordless scenes and poetic symbolism, but all that complexity leads to a surprisingly simplistic conclusion.
Masterly coming-of-age drama.
Amiable but oddly amateurish.
At moments, the story skirts uncomfortably close to the grotesque. But this atmospheric oddity delivers a surprisingly sensitive take on the overwhelming ache of loneliness.
How could something so expensive, so loud and so frenetic simultaneously be so mindnumbingly boring?
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Though buoyed by excellent, unflinching performances, this melancholy drama reflects the dismally monotonous lives of its subjects just a little too well.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A genial dramatic comedy that eventually crumbles under the weight of its ambitions.
Combine two mannered performances with a script intent on achieving maximum cuteness, and you've got one wince-inducing sugar rush.
Surprisingly sweet and smart.
Feels like an amusing Saturday Night Live sketch that overstays its welcome by a good 90 minutes.

Other than a few witty jokes and a game cast, there's nothing particularly special here. Still, the nods to masters like Wes Craven and George Romero -- along with buckets of blood -- ought to thrill horror fans.
[An] unabashedly heart-tugging documentary.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Reality Land is a village built on lowest common denominators -- the cheapest, the dumbest, the wildest -- that Bunim and Murray well know often leads to the most fun.
An ongoing problem ... is the complete lack of chemistry between the leads.
One of the rare Imax movies in which the 3-D effects are completely melded into the picture, rather than simply used as a gimmick.
Despite the inexperience of the director and his cast, there's rarely a false moment.
Their ghoulishness is so repugnant it's fascinating.
That's not a movie, it's a timeline.
The movie is so confused about where it wants to go, it suffers from the same identity crisis as its protagonist.
The only problem with this special film is its stark reminder of all the mediocrity other movies count on us to accept.
An ultimately overwrought project!
Although it's an intensely intimate film, there's something special about taking your seat in the theater as though you're pulling up right next to L.B. Jefferies (James Stewart).
Diamonds can be proud of its achievement as the ultimate primer on elderly embarrassments and the best ways to exploit them.
Although Iris has no idea who she is, Morton is utterly certain, and inhabits her temporarily defeated soul with an ease that knocks you out.
Exalted work from cinematographer Freddie Francis.
A lovely, luminous dream.
Different from anything that came before it.
One big, ugly chase scene!
So sure, the characters and jokes may feel awfully familiar, but for those who see a little of themselves in Angelo's family, well, that's just part of this little movie's charm.
As always with Kevin Smith's films, the strongest element is the writing, and he's reached a new level here.
[Bouchez and Regnier have] fleshed out portraits of a depth rarely seen on screen.
Without exception, every one of Dr. T's -- and thus Altman's -- women is either neurotic, needy, naked, or a lesbian. In other words, either a male fantasy or a male fear.
Nothing about the movie even makes sense!
It's not that this is lousy entertainment, it's just that it's a Serious Topic given unnecessary Celebrity Sheen.
The script is ridiculous and the direction inept.
Has some honest laughs, a few touching moments, and a welcome balance between the girls and the boys.
Granted, a heavy period drama about an impending execution doesn't sound like your typical date movie. But it doesn't get much more romantic than this.
movie_title: The Widow of Saint-Pierre (The Widow of St. Pierre) (La veuve de Saint-Pierre) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Well-intentioned but utterly misguided.
Beautiful, heavy, and fatally flawed.
It couldn't possibly work without a transcendent central performance. Harper gives us that, and more.
Descriptions of great art are, of course, ultimately irrelevant, and Trueba knew we'd have to experience his passion for ourselves. He's offering a dazzling invitation -- take him up on it.
Our Song is the most faithful cinematic depiction of adolescence in recent memory.
The British hero of Nick Hornby's novel, on which this movie is based, certainly does not scream out 'John Cusack.' And yet once you see him, you can't think of anyone who'd do it better.
Devoted family man, aspiring poet and petty whiner, the Nazi propagandist Joseph Goebbels depicted in Lutz Hachmeister's unusual documentary presents a compelling study of the banality of evil.
Having written, co- directed and played the lead in this awkward, ego-driven memoir, Hayata has turned a genuinely compelling life story into an embarrassing vanity production.
Exhibiting the same sort of patience as his sensible hero, Philibert has created an extraordinarily humane portrait of a partnership between one adult and his very fortunate charges.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A droll script and generally deft direction make the Icelandic chill surprisingly inviting.
The patina of witty satire eventually gives way to a gratuitous sadism that makes this sordid story feel like a fraud.
With lots of cool gadgets, plenty of silliness and a clever concept guaranteed to appeal to preteens, this should be an unflagging, high-octane romp.
A warm and engaging home movie.
There's no denying the poignancy and power of Young's commitment to old-fashioned -- and, he seems keenly aware, out of fashion -- political activism.
The laconic Lemarquis does a solid job carrying off Kári's dryly mordant wit, making this eccentric story well worth watching.
The rapidly aging cast is clearly in it for the cash, with not a single one fully committed to the task.
Never Die Alone is the first of Goines' ultragritty novels has made it to the big screen. If this is the best his words can inspire, it should also be the last.

There's little to enjoy in this unsettling tale, but Doillan's unblinking depiction of manipulation and desperation stays with you long after the characters make the deals that seal their unjust fates.
Despite a few magic moments, the rest of the film feels stale.
Where Kim's best-known movie, The Isle, was a stomach-churner, this beautifully composed canvas is the sort of film one falls into, resurfacing at the end with great reluctance.
Insightful and often painful to watch, Patrice Chereau's sensitive drama captures the reality of chronic illness.
One of the silliest, sweetest and most fun family films in recent memory.
Hickenlooper does a nice job blending Bingenheimer's flashy past with his somewhat pathetic present, creating a genuinely compelling study in diminishing returns.
With so little action or even insight, Marathon is far too long at only 74 minutes.
O'Haver ... has a great time juggling silly jokes, contemporary tunes and anachronisms like hand-cranked escalators at the medieval mall.
Affairs and murder mysteries: sounds intriguing, no? Well, no.
Self-indulgent in the extreme, Julian Hernandez's laconic ode to heartbreak feels like the work of a lovelorn teenager.
Yale Strom offers an important addition to his collection of Jewish history movies.

It's easy to pick apart Stephens' thin script and clumsy direction. But whether you were a high school outcast or the prom queen, you're bound to root for his misfits as they find their place in the world.
[Fey's] snappy script and the deft direction of Mark Waters, who did Freaky Friday, keep the laughs coming.
Packed with enough muddles and mixups to stock a French farce (or a middling UPN sitcom), Rules coasts amiably on without striking any real sparks.
Despite strong performances, this drawn-out Day feels like a cross between the claustrophobic play it once was, and the R-rated After-School Special it wants to be.
Though the film is based on fact, most of its characters exist only in movies.
Speed doesn't boast much in the way of innovative storytelling. What it does offer is a story that still badly needs to be told.
movie_title: With All Deliberate Speed: The Legacy of Brown vs. Board (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Both painfully self-indulgent and awkwardly self-conscious.
Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! starts out as fresh as your popcorn, but turns stale before you finish it.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious and impressively inventive undertaking.
If your idea of a great time is drinking a case of Red Bull while playing video games at top volume, Torque ought to provide just the right level of hyperstimulation.
Fox's slender but striking story gains strength from his matter-of-fact approach to potentially controversial material.
It is spirited and heartfelt, but as [Green] meanders from college romances to corporate jobs to showbiz breaks, it's clear none of these incidents is actually worthy of big-screen attention.

Definitely better than DeVito's last movie, the disastrous Death to Smoochy. Alas, it's not nearly as good as his two films from which it takes its obvious inspiration: The War of the Roses and Throw Momma From the Train.
Southlander does have enough energy and wit to make a solid music video. But that leaves us with about 80 minutes too many.
movie_title: Southlander: Diary of a Desperate Musician (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This Sundance winner deserves every accolade it's earned so far for the way the director and his cast sidestep the script's inherent obstacles of eccentricity and whimsy.
This somewhat surreal animé import is unlikely to earn the same mainstream recognition as last year's Spirited Away, but it's certainly worth a look.
Uncovers a complex, multilayered tragedy with a surprisingly wide range of victims and perpetrators.
A yawn.
What starts out amusing eventually becomes something of a drag.
It's impossible to ignore the strain of misogyny that taints the movie.
Gershon's self-aware shtick is either titillating or irritating, depending on your taste, but the rest of the actors are uniformly excellent.
Garbus spent three years patiently mining for beauty in the ugliest of environments. The remarkable result stands as a challenge to anyone who would have seen only the worst and walked right by.
There is a hardly a false note, which makes this both a difficult and exceedingly memorable film to watch.
Since the movie's sensibility ranges from the preposterous to the absurd, there are few genuine frights.

While it's clear that Workman is fascinated by the subject matter, that turns out to be the primary problem: He gets so wrapped up in creating the structure that he forgets to put much of anything inside.
Director Gonzalo Justiniano beautifully captures the fishing village but never quite captures the story.
A lovely little coming-of-age story.
For better and worse, Rosemary Rodriguez's directing debut feels just like what it is -- a drama about addiction made by a recovering addict.
Where the original was slight but sweet, the remake is depressingly superficial and cynical.
Ggripping documentary.
Both enchantingly old-fashioned and daringly modern.
A powerful drama that turns a common event -- the rending of a family -- into an intimate, personal affair.
Has gorgeous cinematography with spectacular landscapes -- plus a lazy script, forgettable performances and regrettably uninspired direction.
Depending on your perspective, this French family drama will either feel sweetly sentimental or shamelessly manipulative.
The movie hits as much as it misses, with enough witty observations to ensure that somewhere, Kesselman's mother is kvelling.
Despite the excess of information, the films are so unfocused we never get to know the man behind the gowns.
movie_title: Yves St. Laurent: His Life and Times (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unless you find kicks in the groin hilarious, the lunacy here is considerably more tired than inspired.
Herzog allows us to make up our own minds as we watch this lost soul on his fervent, increasingly desperate search for love, spirituality and fame.
A film whose level of imagination can be discerned right from its title.
This is an insider's tour -- the uninitiated are, frankly, not likely to be converted.
movie_title: We Jam Econo: The Story of the Minutemen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone who laments the loss of an older, grittier New York ought to adore this affectionate portrait of Greenwich Village restaurant owner Kenny Shopsin.
Within the formulaic structure is a deeply heartfelt desire to say something new about the Mexican-American experience.
While Seidelman deserves considerable credit for making the rare romantic comedy about seniors, it's a shame the movie itself is as bland as a low-sodium diet.
Hard to watch but important to see, this compassionate documentary tracks the considerable travails of Iraqis living under U.S. occupation.
Too mature for little kids and much too corny for older siblings and chaperones, Barnyard probably should have been put out to pasture long before it made it to the multiplex.
Step Up barely bothers to build a memorable story. Instead, the movie rests entirely on the well-sculpted shoulders of charismatic leads Channing Tatum and Jenna Dewan.

Frankly, this would have been a perfect candidate for the straight-to-DVD shelf. But the young stars are appealing, and at this point in his career, Allen could carry a family film with one hand tied behind his back.
Given the dismal reception that greeted their last comedy, Mail Order Bride, you'd think filmmakers Doug Bollinger and Robert Capelli Jr. would have considered alternate career choices.
Director Fabrice Du Welz doesn't reinvent the backwoods-freakshow formula, but there is something undeniably entertaining about violent psychos who are also committed art lovers.
After languishing unseen for years, Laurent Firode's long-delayed comedy is finally getting its day in the sun. Too bad there's such a heavy shadow hanging over it.
Like its underachieving protagonist, Steve Pink's teen comedy Accepted flashes just enough charm to get by but is too lazy to really make anything of itself.
At this late date, filmmakers who draw inspiration from the Mafia had better have a whole new angle to offer. Otherwise, they'll end up with a movie like 10th & Wolf.
There are a few laughs -- and a corking hangover.
A wild dream that spins into a nightmare, Moonlight isn't quite as provocative as it aims to be.
Tucker's heart is in the right place. His work, however, isn't: Lectures belong in school, not in the movie theater.
A superficial tween comedy that mocks celebutantes like the Olsen twins while simultaneously pushing stars Hilary and Haylie Duff as their replacements.
At the start of Yilmaz Arslan's somber drama, it's hard to understand why the young narrator sounds so embittered. By the end, his sadness is devastatingly clear.

The first film from OutKast iconoclasts André Benjamin (André 3000) and Antwan A. Patton (Big Boi) has all the wit and creativity of their music videos. And here's the bad news: That makes it at least an hour too long.
Wahlberg and his co-stars, including love interest Elizabeth Banks, really seem to believe in the story, with a grave intensity that enhances its underdog appeal.
Writer/director Greg Pritikin has created a reality-TV satire as clueless as the self-impressed 'stars' it scorns.

Among the cast, Chandrasekhar is easily the funniest of the Lizards, though in fairness, each has his moments. The movie does, too; just expect them to shrink exponentially depending on your level of sobriety.
Pierre Rehov's chilling documentary gets up close and personal with those who consider martyrdom the highest calling.
Here's hoping its old-fashioned sensibility appeals to contemporary kids, because we could certainly use more movies as smart and sweet as this one.
We need all four hours, and even more, to understand the man who so prophetically divided the world into 15-minute increments.
Here's hoping that somehow, this intelligent, uncommonly perceptive film finds the fairy-tale success it deserves.
The resulting jolts add up to one unforgettably surreal nightmare.
Jeff Lowell's slapdash script is as phony as Beth's trendy animal activism, but it does offer plenty of easy laughs.
The perfect antidote for anyone sick of overlong blockbusters, this diverse selection packs six films into just 95 minutes.
Plot and character development are quickly sacrificed to over-the-top action, but with a miniskirted menace in the lead, it's safe to say that fans, at least, will love it.
An exhausting combination of generic thriller, political tract and sentimental weepie.
Narrator Robert Baer tries to understand why humans would give up their lives to take those of others, and he's gained remarkable access to those at the center of this ideology.
movie_title: The Cult of the Suicide Bomber (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nunez's fans will appreciate his ability to evoke a palpable atmosphere. But there's just not enough spark in his scorched setting.
Genuinely touching and unquestionably sincere, the movie certainly has heart -- but it could have used a little more game.
Whenever he takes the time to line up his toxic arrows, usually with the help of a compellingly squirmy Bleibtreu, he hits the bull's-eye.
It achieves the near impossible, turning cars, trucks, tractors and farm harvesters into cute Disney characters whose fates you'll care about.
It is our good fortune that Akin and his on-screen narrator, bass player Alexander Hacke, are our passionate guides through the country's musical history.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Connolly, bless him, throws himself heartily into the task of acting opposite a computer-generated cat given to bad puns and flatulence. Everyone else, however, looks mortified, and can you blame them?
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The kind of movie in which plot and performances (and members of the fairer sex) are treated as accessories, Tokyo Drift is all about the action. And on that count, it won't let you down.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: While disaster ensues, the directors have the sense to avoid the obvious, finding trouble in the least predictable of places.
As is often the case with Toback's films, even as you're shaking your head at his shameless self-indulgence, you can't help but keep on watching.
There's also something patronizing about the zeal with which Machado wallows in the muck, especially since his characters' lives revolve entirely around sex.

Charles Sturridge's charming adaptation of Eric Knight's classic book Lassie Come-Home will thrill any adult who can't face another insipid children's movie about talking animals. Oh, and the kids will love it, too.
Even those unimpressed with [Cheech and Chong's] genially lowbrow work will be intrigued by the political tenor of this portrait.
Both epic and intimate, this impassioned samurai drama is for anyone who's ever watched a movie and muttered, 'They just don't make 'em like they used to.'
Offering both too little material and too much, the movie leaves us in the bizarre position of understanding its subject no better by the end than we did at the beginning.

Ask yourself: If you saw an unknown, single man repeatedly approach kids in the park, would you be concerned? If so, you may not find Paul, and his unbalanced Peter Pan complex, quite as charming as Paige does.
Unlike so many indie films, Michael Kang's gently empathetic debut embraces eccentricity without drowning in its own hip irony.
Sturla Gunnarsson... took a look at the eighth-century epic poem Beowulf and decided he could cut it down to size. And he has, for better and worse.
...an atonal love letter to a single corner of the culture - one built, in the words of singer Lydia Lunch, on 'beauty and truth and filth.'
Well, it was bound to happen: The Wayans brothers have made a movie that's even more two-dimensional than a cartoon.
Chereau keeps us locked inside their suffocatingly unhappy home, making for an intensely theatrical chamber piece.

The Groomsmen captures a single, specific moment, when responsibilities await but adulthood is still unwelcome. If their predicament strikes a chord, you may want to join Burns' boys for their final hurrah.
Anyone with the slightest interest in mob entertainment -- from The Godfather to The Sopranos -- should check out Marco Turco's grimly compelling documentary
If he earns no other accolades for his directorial debut -- a distinct likelihood -- Lee Daniels deserves some kind of award just for assembling the most bizarrely random cast of this young century.

Though the stripped-down style of Heather Lyn MacDonald's documentary doesn't quite do justice to her fabulous heroines, the extraordinary energy of the five former chorus girls she profiles provides plenty of fuel.
Some moments of off-the-cuff beauty aren't enough to mask the creepy heart of Larry Clark's latest look at outcast kids.

A scrappy action flick that shifts into high gear immediately and never slows down, this rousing French import aspires to no higher goal than flashy entertainment. In that regard, it succeeds entirely.
Looking for Kitty offers moments of striking insight amid the inevitable self-indulgence.
Overly reverent but still immensely touching ...

One of Walsch's precepts is that you should never make a living doing something you hate. If I'd known that, I might not have felt obliged to sit through every excruciating minute of this sanctimonious infomercial.
Documentarians Barbara Kopple and Cecilia Peck are skillful enough to tell this story from multiple angles, making Shut Up & Sing as insightful as it is entertaining.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A meandering, amusing trifle, Werner Herzog's latest film is as cheekily flaky as his recent Grizzly Man was sharply down-to-earth.
Just like its increasingly wan antihero, this blood-soaked series is on its last legs.
Quote not available.
Allen and Short seem to be having so much fun that their enthusiasm is entirely contagious. Let the season begin.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It will be a long time before you forget the deep pain etched into the weary face of Carmelo Muñiz, the mariachi singer at the center of Mark Becker's immensely moving documentary.
Good intentions and some nicely playful moments go a long way toward balancing out Paul Morrison's uneven story of British immigrants in the early 1960s.

Both in art and in death, Arbus escaped the demeaning constraints of society. By envisioning her as a flawlessly gorgeous mouse with no will of her own, [director] Shainberg and [screenwriter] Wilson have dragged her back.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This intensely personal film may not bring either [Joey Lauren Adams and Ashley Judd] widespread acclaim, but it's a small triumph nonetheless.
It's the perfect antidote to overprocessed entertainment, for moviegoers of any age.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Visually arresting and deeply disheartening, James Longley's impressionistic documentary explores the pain of a shattered country by homing in on a few tiny shards.

Since Adam Sussman's script is as lazy as Asif Kapadia's direction is disjointed, nothing ever makes sense, even after the anticlimatic explanation is revealed. Not even Gellar can work up any interest in Joanna's fate.
For all its flaws, Bobby is a heartfelt and undeniably relevant project.
By the time it's over, you'll be inspired to scour your own attic for undiscovered treasures.
... although there are some very striking moments in Neil Armfield's debut, there are simply not enough to keep us absorbed the way a movie should.
Ever been on a blind date that you knew would be dismal from the start? Well, this is the movie version of that date, stretched out over the slowest two hours imaginable.
It's probably best to approach the Quay Brothers' dreamlike fantasy (which they call 'poetic science-fiction') with the understanding that you'll never quite know what's going on.

Arnett has seven movies coming out within the next year. It seems safe, or at least optimistic, to assume that this is not going to be his high point. But he does make a consistently amusing Felix to Shepard's frustrated Oscar.

As reliable as your Aunt Harriet's sweet potato casserole, every holiday season brings a movie just like John Whitesell's Deck the Halls, in which otherwise sensible actors commit themselves to a cheerless exercise in jingle bell hell.
Tossing off one-liners about drugs and porn to a New York audience, even Waters sounds a little bored.
Even if you're not a stoned adolescent, there's plenty to appreciate in Liam Lynch's loopy, cheerfully lowbrow comedy.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Director Daniel] Burman tends to focus very tightly on the details of individual identity - religion, nationality, gender. It is all the more striking, then, that his restrained and unassuming films are wise enough to speak to every adult.
Bouchareb nobly honors men whose sacrifices have largely gone unnoticed.
As good as Nolte is, the relatively unknown Morgan matches him scene for scene.
Burton's skewed vision is seamlessly realized by director Henry Selick and cleverly enhanced by Danny Elfman's songs.
Selim's script doesn't hit new territory, but beautiful cinematography takes it just far enough.
[Director] Goldthwait explores his themes more thoughtfully than you'd expect, but ultimately, we know just how things will end. And what's subversive about that?
The intimate history of Doug Block's parents becomes fodder for a broader look at family secrets in this complex documentary.
Red Doors feels like a first-time film; quirks are overplayed while themes remain underdeveloped.
More vanity project than full-fledged film, Manu Boyer's modest chronicle is best left to diehard Kiefer Sutherland fans.
movie_title: I Trust You to Kill Me (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... profoundly mediocre ...
The Rock commits himself admirably to this trite tale, but by the end, even his enormous shoulders buckle under the weight of so many cliches.
Like a mango rotting in the sun, Frank Flowers' squishy Caribbean thriller has been sitting on the shelf long enough to attract suspicion. Bite into it at your own risk.
Like the average best-man toast, Debbie Isitt's amiable mockumentary has many funny moments, a few touching ones and some that fall just slightly flat.
The latest Dawson's Creek alumnus to break out of his WB bonds, Joshua Jackson proves himself all grown up in this sweetly scrappy indie.
In Ronny Yu's sweeping film based on the life of wu shu master Huo Yuanjia, the retiring action star manages to tug a few heartstrings while breaking plenty of bones.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Only adolescent boys -- the movie's target audience, despite a well-earned R rating -- will appreciate the most extreme gross-out gags, none of which can be described in a family newspaper.
Though it would have benefited from a more detached approach, this is a vital look at a subculture that remains foreign to many New Yorkers -- despite its growing influence over all our lives.
With its halfhearted script, stiff performances and overlong running time, this is the kind of movie that's simultaneously dazzling to look at, and increasingly tough to sit through.
It's a promising concept, but instead of expending effort on, say, a coherent script, the filmmakers lazily rely on cheap editing tricks and gleefully relentless sadism.
An earnest -- if bone-crunching -- ode to Thai culture.
A story that balances gentle messages with enough goofy anarchy to please any kid.
Just like a real job, Greg Coolidge's workplace comedy Employee of the Month offers long, slow stretches lightened by a few laughs and some oddball characters.
Jonathan Liebesman's prequel to Tobe Hooper's 1974 horror classic is just another trip down a very dusty road.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Meskela's is a story worth tackling again -- but without the over-caffeinated approach.
Writer-director Claudia Myers' clunky debut feature makes the case that first-timers should probably focus on either writing or directing.
Freida Lee Mock's adulatory portrait makes for pleasant viewing -- but should it? Her subject is a professional rabble-rouser, an intellect determined to provoke a sleeping world into action.

In itself, it's a riveting story. Unfortunately, director Michael Sajbel has envisioned an overwrought Lifetime movie of the week, complete with an Esther who could be a cast member of Laguna Beach and a king notable only for his washboard abs.

Linney hits a single note for her uptight character, while Walters travels the scale indiscriminately. Her outsized eccentric darts from amusing to grating. Only Grint is just right, as the boy they, and the film, can't do without.
So what could be better than an endless supply of jellybeans and ice cream? Only a multiplex permanently stocked with smart, sweetly silly family films like this one.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A murky swamp of a movie.
Very little about the plot actually makes sense, but who needs logic when you've got a creepy ghost child and his banshee mom lurking around?
A happy surprise.
Horse-mad tweens may not notice its flaws, but with a defter touch, even this familiar story might have made for a more exciting ride.
A popcorn flick like this does best when it sticks to shallow waters.
Paolini was 15 when he began writing Eragon, and the book's epic imagination reflects its creator's precocious youth. What a shame a bunch of grownups had to step in and muck it all up.
The movie jumps from scene to scene, too scattered to make a strong connection with anything, or anyone, in particular.
Taking over from the more cerebral Bryan Singer, Ratner is unable to maintain the emotional intensity that has made this series so deeply epic. But he sure knows how to put on a show.
Not only do we rarely get to participate in the fun -- fun being the chance to watch demon guts splattered across the walls -- but there's barely any to be found.
Fanning and Russell are a perfect, sweet-and-sour pair. And, of course, the horse is absolutely beautiful -- which, in the end, is what this all comes down to, anyway.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: You get the exhausting feeling that Stolberg is desperately trying to prove how cool he is.
Yeboah is so levelheaded about his own accomplishments that the swelling score and emotional narration from Oprah Winfrey feel embarrassingly sentimental.
A visually lush and eerily enigmatic parable of female sexuality, Lucile Hadzihalilovic's ominous fairy tale raises questions you'll be wondering about for days.
Gentle and affecting, it offers an introduction to a mostly unfamiliar world while touching on issues recognizable to all.
A journey into the original heart of darkness, Peter Bate's uneven but immensely important documentary examines the shameful history of Belgium's King Leopold II.
movie_title: Congo: White King, Red Rubber, Black Death (2003)

movie_review_blurb: At the very least, with Saw II, you get what you pay for.

The women are shrewishly materialistic, the men are manipulative or violent and the Polo wardrobes look fabulous on everyone. It's an ugly affair overall, but at least you can say you've never seen such beautiful shirts.

Blessed with a surfeit of archival footage and dozens of marvelous, first-person stories, filmmakers Dan Geller and Dayna Goldfine have created a rich, complex portrait of the legendary Russian Ballet.
Jeppe Ronde's unusual documentary is unabashedly superficial. But it's an approach that works better than you might imagine.
Even though Kiyoshi Kurosawa's influential Japanese horror film captured a particular mood when he made it in 2000, its late arrival here is likely to elicit jaded yawns.

Zathura, Jon Favreau's adaptation of Chris Van Allsburg's kid-lit adventure of the same name, more than fills the bill -- though it's unlikely to draw anyone over the age of 11 (not counting baby-sitters).
The subject matter is much too dark for children, and the tone is not sophisticated enough for adults, so it's hard to know who Mark Bamford had in mind for this awkwardly sentimental drama.
The race between her deep-set ideology and burgeoning conscience is a compelling one, but there are too many shortcuts -- from fevered dreams to convenient coincidences -- along the way.
There are moments of amusing melodrama, but for the most part, the action is too preposterous to take seriously, and too serious to be very much fun.
The parts are more valuable than the whole in Angelina Maccarone's Unveiled.
Eran Riklis and his co-writer, Suha Arraf, take impressive care to create a sensitive and thoughtful examination of each character (and country's) deeply held bias.
Every holiday season welcomes a big-screen turkey, and this one's got extra stuffing.
Not even likable leading man Usher can save this muddled mob comedy from a quick route to video shelves.

As its sappy title indicates, Dani Menkin's uneven documentary about an Israeli man with severe muscular dystrophy suffers from that all-too-common affliction: the need to sentimentalize courage in the face of extreme illness.

Fashion is something you either get or you don't, and whether you'll want to lay down $10 for Douglas Keeve's insider documentary depends entirely on whether you'd spend your last few bucks on the new issue of Vogue.
Working with a self-consciously urgent, neo-noir style, Goldberg seems intent on expressing a meaningful message of some kind. It's too bad, then, that he has chosen such a shallow subject.
Tom Arnold does have talent, but some self-defeating streak keeps him from using it.

It's Van Zandt's family that provides the film's most memorable moments, from the second wife who declared life with him 'a bummer' to the children still trying to reconcile the great artist with the very mortal man.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Wenders handles America's physical landscape with characteristic clarity. But he never gets a handle on the trickier political terrain and so, like Uncle Paul, ends up chasing too many roads to nowhere.
[An] underachieving indie.
The many riveting moments will stay with you for days, and Padilla is well up to the task of carrying this intense story on his tiny shoulders.
Though it bears absolutely no relation to real life, this sweetly silly modern fairy tale possesses just enough charm to endear itself to secret sentimentalists.
There's no denying the power of seeing two cultures standing so helplessly on opposite sides of a single fence.
The only real surprise about this cheerful gay romance is that such a silly movie was such a smash hit in its native Taiwan.
On the evolutionary scale, this B-movie misfire hovers pretty close to amoeba status.
Much of this feels like pandering to her liberal audience, as she approaches subjects like reproductive and gay rights without offering many new -- or funny -- observations.
A good movie that could have been better, Joseph Cedar's sensitive Israeli drama falters when he trades sociological observations for political ones.
A suddenly vital biography, Make It Funky, pays apt homage to the unique gifts New Orleans has given its country over the last century. Watching it ought to inspire anyone to return the favor.
This droll Japanese import puts the predictable banality of most Hollywood teen flicks to shame.

With a soundtrack that ranges from classical to jazz to bluegrass, this is not only an obvious choice for music lovers, but required viewing for anyone interested in the mysteries of creative inspiration.
It's still thought-provoking, but not quite as profound as it pretends to be.
Angelopoulos has created a memorably sweeping survey, but even an epic needs some moments of genuine intimacy.
movie_title: Trilogia: To livadi pou dakryzei (The Weeping Meadow) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Either it's a truly lousy retread of horror-movie clichés, or it's a mildly amusing sendup of them.
Panayotopoulou does handle the material with sensitivity, but she relies too much on her young hero's unlikely precocity, which unwittingly diminishes the intensity of a child's very real grief.
movie_title: Dyskoloi apohairetismoi: O babas mou (Hard Goodbyes: My Father) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As an actor, Lepage is a captivating presence, easily transforming from one sibling to the other. And as a director, he braids the personal and the universal with dexterity, turning theatrical intimacy into cinematic ecstasy.

Parallels to the current day are plain to see, so Vittoria's insistence on juxtaposing images of contemporary politicians and an angry narration only undercut the power of his otherwise absorbing presentation.
movie_title: One Bright Shining Moment: The Forgotten Summer of George McGovern (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating capsule of an era long past.
movie_title: I am Cuba, the Siberian Mammoth (Soy Cuba, O Mamute Siberiano) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: With the exception of likable lead Robert Knott, the performances are cringingly broad, and the surreally animated backgrounds offer a promise that's never realized.
Malcolm Lee's sweet-natured dramatic comedy Roll Bounce captures the decade's texture with a well-earned nostalgia that never seems cheap.
Phelan makes nice use of the New York locations, but all the trees in Central Park can't make up for a clichéd script and characters who speak entirely in platitudes.
Straightforward and immensely powerful, the movie offers a blunt assessment of the war from soldiers currently fighting it, and their perspective is not pretty.
As always, Whedon's sci-fi fantasies smartly parallel the serious issues we're grappling with here on Earth, while his protagonists remain mordantly funny in the face of utter disaster.
Despite an admirable effort to explore topical concerns, both director and actor are obviously overwhelmed by the immensity of the subject matter.
[Has] enough moments of insight to blunt charges of sexist stereotyping.
Rob McKittrick's sour debut is such an obvious candidate for the direct-to-video shelf, someone will surely be demoted for sending it into actual theaters.
A sermon writ as large as a multiplex movie screen.

In a movie that deals with controversial sexual, racial and class issues, the boldest observation is the most basic: that we each have the right to define our own realities, and live comfortably within them.
Like its troubled protagonists, Mark Milgard's ultrasensitive ode to adolescent angst is equal parts earnest and awkward.
Because his self-conscious musings are given so much space, it helps to arrive at the movie already awed by Shicoff's talents so you can overlook his (and this dramatically unfocused film's) flaws.
movie_title: Finding Eléazar: Portrait of a Tenor and a Role (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A muddle of good intentions and bad direction, this amateurish road movie follows a young Brit across Europe as he reconnects with his Jewish roots.
A generation-spanning journey that feels both comfortingly familiar and excitingly original.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Though self-centered by its very nature, Grace Lee's chronicle of other women who share her name turns out to be a funny and insightful exploration into identity issues we all can recognize.

When [Redmon] runs out of things to say, his film lands in an anticlimactic puddle, just like the shiny trinkets forgotten after the party ends.
There's a fascinating and terrifying story to be told about Elizabeth Bathory, the dramatically depraved 17th century sadist known as the Blood Countess. This ain't it.

Everything a good documentary should be.
A sour vanity project: trash posing as a socially relevant 'cautionary tale.'

Perhaps we need a sequel, which would likely be as riveting as this inspirational introduction to two courageous pioneers.
It's a mildly amusing feature that takes a few too many potshots at some very broad targets.

Grim, bloody and relentless, without even a spark of fun or intelligence, Evil is barely good enough for late-night cable.

movie_title: Power of Nightmares: The Rise of the Politics of Fear (2004)

movie_title: How to Eat Your Watermelon in White Company (And Enjoy It) (2005)

His struggles remain compelling, thanks to Knoller's sad-eyed authenticity.
Enthusiasm carries the day in this paint-by-numbers period tale, which is just charming enough to coast on its own clichés.
Brad Leong's "quirky" romantic comedy retreads ground that is already so well worn, everyone just slides right through.
We're treated to the bizarre spectacle of Ronan arguing with herself repeatedly over which guy to kiss. But since both are similarly bland, it barely matters.
There's no overcoming the poorly conceived premise of Benjamin Epps' debut comedy. But a strong start and solid cast take it further than one might expect.
Though consistently engaging, Redford's latest directorial endeavor does feel like a plea. You can almost hear him coaxing us to learn from the past, even as we rush into the future.
What unholy spirit could have possessed Julianne Moore when she signed on for the sort of throwaway horror flick that would normally star unknowns and go straight to DVD?
Costa brings a nice, lived-in sexiness to the evocatively shot setting, and Gandolfini settles into his character with extraordinary skill and sensitivity.
There's not much depth to Mosley's debut, which is based on a short story by Tim Macy. But Michael Angarano and Juno Temple are an appealing pair as John and Alice, struggling suburbanites.

Alvarez is primarily interested in upping his corpse count, in the most gruesome ways imaginable. In this, he is undeniably successful. He also establishes an effectively breathless pace, and weaves in a steady stream of fan-friendly references.
[An] unsubtle but unsettling assessment of contemporary technology.
While there's no ignoring the social ills that haunt Robbie's hopes, the movie's optimism serves as a cheeky, and surprisingly inspiring, retort.
Berger's got some clever ideas, but he does not push far in exploring them. And aside from Cross, there is virtually no one to like among these self-involved suburbanites.
Neither Claude nor Ozon comes up with a satisfying finish to this intriguing setup. But because they're both so committed to seducing their audience, it's a lot of fun watching them try.
To be able to find, nurture and share one's passion with such unceasing enthusiasm is surely the essence of magic itself.
movie_title: Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ahmed keeps bringing the focus back to an intriguingly ambiguous center. His scenes with Schreiber have a crackling tension, and he pushes back against the script's obvious manipulations.

Akerman does work hard to keep up the energy level. Cusack, though, seems bored by the superficial proceedings, which don't even offer the distraction of a real romantic connection or a suspenseful confrontation.
Easy resolutions compete with preposterous melodrama.
The cinematography is memorably vibrant, and the performances are solid, even if they pass by too swiftly. Most of all, of course, the subject matter remains fascinating.
This glossy doc is indisputably attractive, with lots of famous faces, amusing stories and stunning clothes to admire.
Director Deborah Anderson ... turns a welcome opportunity into a shameless example of exploitation and self-promotion.
Bier and Jensen have relied so heavily on clichés that their effort can't compare even to the formulaic movies they're trying to emulate.
Assayas looks back on youth with both the generous affection and wry clarity of adulthood.
Regadas overdoes everything in a self-indulgent presentation of trite fantasies masked as memories.
In paying homage to two iconic performers, he's given a former small-screen star the chance to announce his own cinematic arrival.
"Peeples" may not break any new ground, but it's about time Perry threw a family reunion hosted by someone other than Madea.
Hardly anyone will see it, but those who do ought to be impressed.
Fuqua knows exactly how to pump up a straightforward script from first-time scribes Creighton Rothenberger and Katrin Benedikt.
Let's call The Call what it is: high quality trash that both diminishes and is redeemed by all the talents who have deigned to bring it to life.

Like a creaky Vegas act desperate to please, "The Incredible Burt Wonderstone" is so eager you can't help wanting to like it. But you also can't help wondering if something better is playing in the theater next-door.
Even if he's slumming, Renner gets it best: his dry delivery fully acknowledges the movie's ridiculousness. If you're planning on entering this fractured fairy tale, you'll want to follow his lead.

At his best, Gibney focuses on his subject and then explodes it outward. But with "The Last Gladiators," he's taken a rare misstep. There is undoubtedly a great story within the bruised history of NHL enforcers. Why, though, did he choose Chris Nilan's?
Grohl's aim is to explore the aura of a place, but what he winds up proving is that people make the magic.
A movie so brazenly off-kilter that I'm not entirely sure its title is even accurate.
As a film critic, I've seen nearly 4,000 movies over the last fifteen years. Right now, I can't think of one worse than Movie 43.

What success the movie finds is due to the leads' efforts, which are impressively strenuous. They start out with a great premise, and they're clearly ready to run with it. But most of the laughs are stolen right out from under them.

There are elements that hold up - especially Cruise's blinding charisma. The aerial scenes are still thrilling, and perfectly suited to a giant screen. Everything else? Well, that depends on how nostalgic you're feeling.
The Tavianis blur the boundaries between fact and fiction, but they couldn't do it without the full complicity of their actors, or the audience.
Unusually suffused with the contrast between experience and memory, reality and surreality.
What's missing -- from the entire movie -- is that magical spark that can turn a film into a franchise.
The greatest pleasure comes from watching Okuno, a stage actor who wholly embraces the biggest film role of his 81 years.
The story feels fairly perfunctory - not to mention unnecessarily knotty - but the well-connected leads do their best to ground it.
There is indeed much beauty on display, from the icy Taiga landscape to the age-old trapping techniques passed on through generations.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A clear affection for its subject and setting help deepen Daniel Hsia's otherwise shallow romantic comedy.
It's not that Dark Skies is so awful you need to be warned away from it. It's just that it's so bland you might as well find something better to do.
Big and loud and so bland it kinda feels like we've been sold a bill of goods.
Anyone who grew up dancing to "Hava Nagila" at weddings and bar mitzvahs may be interested to learn the song's origins.
Ever wonder what you're missing by not attending the Sundance Film Festival? Many of the entries look a lot like this little indie, a nicely observed but overly familiar coming-of-age tale.

There is plenty of evidence that Webber has something significant to say, and the gifts with which to express himself. Once he's ready to commit fully to his own vision, there's no end to what he might accomplish.
Lucas and Moore don't bother to come up with a single funny joke. Instead they apparently hope that combining racist and sexist insults with unfocused mayhem will be diversion enough.
If it only had a brain. Or a heart. Or nerve.
Thomas makes an assured debut as both writer and director, the gifted Culkin is excellent as always, and Garner finds lovely shades of nuance in Rachel's innocent faith.
Though Perry probably wanted nothing to do with her project, his participation might have pushed this glimpse at the band's evolution into a genuine revelation.
This dully conventional biography doesn't do justice to its subject.

Though "Upside Down" starts with a strong idea, its compelling conceit is immediately weighed down by leaden execution.

Perry is a likable presence, but the movie around him is such a mess that he never gets to prove his potential.
Each one of the current contenders is genuinely worth watching.

Cryer makes a likable sad-sack and Will Sasso provides balance as his narcissistic best friend. But both guys deserve better. As do we.
