Gauzily romantic flashbacks, ultradark comedy and religious iconography are all jumbled together, without sharpening into focus.
No matter how extreme or unlikely the scenario, we want to know how Lou will handle it. Gyllenhaal makes this antihero funny, scary and fearlessly strange.
John Leguizamo can do so much better than this weak rom-com, in which men are morons and women are either neurotic or nasty.
Why do so many filmmakers think "Old People Fall in Love" is the only concept they need?
Hall and Williams have given us one of the rare family films that can fairly boast of having it all: humor, heart and huggability.
This unusually intelligent crowd-pleaser is welcome proof that quality filmmaking needn't be limited by subject, audience or budget.
Hopkins fails to fulfill the potential of her own script.
The actors all commit, but it's frustrating to see how little material they're given.
There's a thrilling undercurrent of rebellion in the way this straightforward, seemingly old-fashioned Western takes up the feminist cause.
Does Hollywood have so little to offer women that well-regarded actresses feel obliged to accept demeaning indies like this flatly unfunny, morally vacant comedy?
The excessive plotlines are sloppily written and choppily edited, while the acting is almost uniformly subpar. Worse, the concept itself is bafflingly empty.
Rawal takes a compassionate but dry approach that suggests he's focused on making a call to arms, not art.
Granted, it's no classic, but a sassy script and good-natured voice work from Benedict Cumberbatch and John Malkovich should keep kids and grownups entertained over the holidays.
This seemingly ordinary biographical documentary about the retiring animation master unfolds, at a deceptively gentle pace, into a work of immense beauty.
movie_title: The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's an algorithm for making an Oscar-ready prestige picture - and "The Imitation Game" follows it obsessively.
A biopic that is both visually engaging and emotionally compelling. But it's hard to shake the feeling of careful ambition that keeps everything moving forward so neatly.
"Still Alice" is hampered by both an unimaginative script and ordinary direction, but it's a serious Oscar contender. Why? Because Julianne Moore is in the lead.
The actors give their all, and Esmail's got an interesting directorial approach. But his own misguided script continually pulls this starry-eyed project down.

The movie is so tone deaf, and travels so far from its original feminist ideals, that it's painful to watch.
A fascinating film that's also a crucial social document.

This uneven directorial debut from Jen McGowan is notable mostly for a nicely understated turn from Juliette Lewis.

Watching these lost characters stumbling through life's challenges, it becomes clear that the true subject of Benson's film(s) isn't rare or extraordinary heartbreak. It's the universal confusion of ordinary adulthood.

This is a promising premise and the cast is certainly game. But it's as if the actors are emoting into a canyon - or, more accurately, a narrow hallway.

Wasikowska makes for excellent company. We watch her mature from idealistic dreamer to a weary, hard-worn adventurer.
Director Wes Ball and his outstanding young cast work unusually hard to counter the derivative feel.

In a movie, nothing good ever seems to happen at a country house. And when it comes to this film, nothing very interesting happens, either.
Teller is, by far, the best thing about this easygoing, stubbornly generic independent romance from Max Nichols.

What has gone so horribly wrong in Cage's career that he is forced to accept any paycheck that comes his way?

[The] streamlined approach seems appropriate for the subject, which boils down to the banality of evil.
The songs, like the script and the animation, are unmemorable.
The mystery is pretty low-key and the resolution somewhat disappointing. But Amalric is mesmerizing and the film's taut, chilly tone leaves us unnerved.

Reflecting its wishy-washy title, "You're Not You" is the sort of movie that's not good enough to embrace, but not quite bad enough to dismiss.

You may not even notice the flaws, since we get so many compelling layers to sift through.
If this movie is any guide, Webb's later years deserve a film of their own. We ought to know more about this fascinating character. And we ought to see more of the fully engaged actor playing him.

So much cynicism might be unbearable were it not for the sure hand of director Perry. He, along with narrator Eric Bogosian, approaches the intellectually brilliant, emotionally empty antihero with bemusement.
Stewart seems out to prove her potential with this solemn drama. For the most part, she succeeds.
Sinks like a rock thrown into a sun-dappled lake shaded by magnolia trees sparkling under a sky of shooting stars.
Seidelman lacquers this predictable plot with a sitcommish sheen, but that's where we see the value of great casting.
movie_title: Six Dance Lessons In Six Weeks (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Leigh and lead Timothy Spall make full use of their canvas, creating a sprawling portrayal of a wonderfully messy personality.
For all the talent involved, the overall effect is surprisingly flat. Foxx appears disconnected, Byrne is wasted and a painfully hammy Diaz seems to be in another movie altogether.

Im Sang-soo can't improve on Kim Ki-young's 1960 original, a jaIm Sang-soo can't improve on Kim Ki-young's 1960 original, a jarring and operatic cult favorite. Still, he does tweak the themes in intriguing fashion.

Mexican-American culture isn't merely draped over the story as an added element but woven throughout with a casual practicality that respects both the primary characters and their shot-on-location East L.A. setting.

The Amy Schumer and Goldie Hawn dream team deserved a better Mother's Day outing than Snatched.

movie_review_blurb: Yes, it'll remind you of countless other movies, from Weekend at Bernie's and Very Bad Things to Bachelorette and Bridesmaids. But if you take it on its own merits, you may wind up glad you saw it.
We're in it for the ride, the company, and the pure pleasure of watching these women, and the actresses playing them, embrace an independence Hollywood doles out too grudgingly.
It's all fascinating and terrifying and inspiring and essential. And at each stop, we're left wanting to know more.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The best way to watch is to think of it as a parody of a particularly pretentious brand of indie romance. Unfortunately, director Xavier Manrique and writer Nicholas Schutt play it so solemnly straight that it seems unlikely they're aiming for satire.

The description makes Patti Cake$ sound like a pretty typical Sundance crowd pleaser. Which, technically, it is. But what sets it apart from other overpraised festival indies is its tremendously gifted lead.
Under the current circumstances, Barker has given us a film with much broader appeal, one that's not only absorbing but also essential in its depiction of humane, responsible leadership.

Abbasi has elicited outstanding performances from his entirely-amateur cast, who infuse both authenticity and professionalism into their roles. And it's impossible to remain unmoved by the many contrasts he carefully arranges.
While parents may miss the second-level smarts of its predecessors, kids should fall right into the fun.
Every theme is overtly defined, every subject dissected until it dissolves. Conversations turn into speeches; references are hit hard.

Like its television predecessor, is all dressed up in bubbles and cupcakes and rainbows. But it's so jam-packed with rousing girl power, it passes the Bechdel Test with (literally) flying colors.
Ai is intent on contrasting the intimate with the intimidating. The sheer mass, the never-ending flow, threatens to overwhelm us. And that, one suspects, is the decisive point.
When Novitiate retains its focus, it ventures towards some interesting answers.

The combination of straightforward realism, deadpan surrealism, historical horror and domestic tragedy is harrowingly impactful. It's as if Maoz realized that a single, sustained tone couldn't possibly do justice to the vastness of the subject.
Hamoud deftly mixes both the intimate and the enormous throughout, endowing vibrantly-shot, slice-of-life storytelling with an often wrenching depth.
But to what end? Bergman, Cassavetes, and Allen excavated this material decades ago, and there are no new insights uncovered amid the interior lives of these husbands and wives.
Mantzoukas and Revolori are ideally cast, bouncing off each other with a salty-sweet chemistry that's as natural as it is entertaining.
What you can't see with your mind's eye, however, are the performances, which save the movie from a treacly inevitability.
Nearly every element of Rao's debut is uneven. But her passionate vision of so much useless prejudice leaves a lingering impact.

First-time writer/director Michael Johnson falls back on coming-of-age clichés. But overall, his sensitive, moody camerawork and the cast's strong performances go a long way toward making the familiar feel fresh.
It works, but not entirely.
Most of the credit goes to Whitman, who stands in, and stands up, for the DUFF in all of us.
Despite its flaws, the first feature from "Junebug" writer Angus MacLachlan is a heartfelt, bittersweet and often amusing portrait of early middle-age.
"Big Eyes" is still a compelling film, well presented and solidly performed by leads Amy Adams and Christoph Waltz. But more weirdness would have done wonders.
The life lessons are delivered with insight and heart, the rightfully beloved music is well handled and the cast is so enthusiastic that we can excuse some rough patches.

Whether Wahlberg's been miscast or misdirected, we never buy him as a desperate addict. Still, the movie is so quick and cool that for much of the time, we barely notice how little is actually at stake.

The best movies are ever-shifting, intelligent and open-hearted enough to expand alongside an audience. "American Sniper," Clint Eastwood's harrowing meditation on war, is built on this foundation of uncommon compassion.
Basinger, Rourke, Anne Heche, Vivica A. Fox, Akon and Wyclef Jean all appear lost or disengaged in bit parts that give a B-movie feel to a political passion project.
The movie is gorgeous, awash in lavish costumes and stunningly detailed sets. But it's merely a wash thematically, leaving us with 170 minutes (!) of unabashedly grandiose fan fiction.
A palpable sense of environment and strong performances from Noah Wyle and musician Steve Earle can't balance the extensive flaws in this unconvincing Appalachian melodrama.

Here's hoping Bruce Willis bought something special with whatever cash he earned from this pointless, brutally ugly rehash of 1973's "Westworld."

It all seems like low-key riffing, rather than a movie that makes any cohesive statement.
Johnny Depp has done so much for us. Let us now return the favor and pretend "Mortdecai," a disastrously misjudged career low, never existed.
Every time the film inches into compelling territory, the band backs away to avoid offending anyone.

movie_review_blurb: Does the curdled thriller "Wild Card" represent a brief misstep? Or is this the moment when Jason Statham, like so many action heroes before him, settles into self-caricature?

For dance fans, any glimpse of the New York City Ballet's inner workings is welcome. Ultimately, though, this observational documentary from Jody Lee Lipes feels too much like an exercise in form over function.

Given the state of Nicolas Cage's résumé, it's faint praise to say this samurai tale is slightly better than most of his recent movies.

The spirit of the series remains true: cheerfully random jokes, blink-and-you'll-miss-them references and, above all, a silly, stubbornly sentimental streak that only the crabbiest cynic could dismiss.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Johnson is a true find: She's so committed, she makes Ana's every discovery - in or out of the bedroom - convincing.

The violence flies repellently over the top, and the finale features an extended joke so insanely sexist it sends us out on a seriously sour note.

With all the talent on tap - including screenwriter Buck Henry, who worked with Michal Zebede to adapt Philip Roth's 2009 novel - you'd think we'd get something better than this outdated indulgence.

The cast is so good, they elevate and expand the movie.

How anyone could make such an uninvolving movie out of such a fascinating subject remains its own inexplicable mystery.

movie_review_blurb: Clear your calendar. There's no better time to get to know a character so obnoxiously stubborn that not even his own creator can shake him.
Stockwell understands most of all that we don't need Carano to talk; we need her to kick ass.

It's too intelligent to dismiss, but not emotional enough to inspire lasting passion.

This is a movie about the transcendent bond between partners who can communicate without speaking a word, so it's only fitting that the gorgeous cinematography perfectly captures the movie's emotional depths.

It's cheesy fun for sure, but fun nonetheless.
Surely a big-time Emmy winner like Surnow can do better.
The actors are smoothly professional and the production feels polished. But it's hard to recommend a romance without passion, no matter how pretty it looks.
Not even this movie's foolish characters could fail to notice the irony: there isn't a single moment of creativity in their own story.

Indie stalwart Henry Jaglom's new film stumbles too often, and is too awkwardly earnest, to be considered a success.
There's not much else we can praise about it, but at least "Walk of Shame" is perfectly titled.
Despite the film's worthy goals, there are some empty calories.
This stilted crime drama from Atom Egoyan feels misguided from the start. He's attempting to fictionalize a true story that has already been told better, several times over.
"Moms' Night Out" is really all about moms staying home, where, according to this movie, they apparently belong.

None of the pieces here quite fit together, but it's still often amusing to watch everyone's attempts.
Apocalyptic visions are no longer enough to shock us. By this point, if you want to imagine the end of the world, you really need to say something new about it.

It does have a weird, boldly ugly edge that makes for unexpectedly compelling viewing.
While there's little dialogue and no music, the naturalist filmmaking is anything but boring. The tension lends weight to the everyday business of being a young person with time on your hands.
This movie's biggest audience will come from Jean-Claude Van Damme's fan base, and boy will they be disappointed.
Fairbrass moves stiffly through both the drama and fight scenes - as if he were underwater. Supporting parts in Jason Statham movies may be his calling, instead.

In its sloppy humor and unabashedly earnest expressions of friendship and romance, the movie feels like any likable, and generally forgettable, teen comedy. And yet with its casually handled twist, the genre ambles forward just a little bit.
Shana Feste's flatly generic update manages to make Franco Zeffirelli's gauzy 1981 romance look like a masterpiece of psychosexual intrigue.
Every would-be director of a celebrity biography should be required to watch Chiemi Karasawa's delightful example.
This ill-advised romance from director Andrew Fleming is the sort of indie lark that nearly drowns in its own whimsy. Wade in at your own risk.
[It] has some offbeat charms. They are not, however, strong enough to carry such a heavy load of cliches.
Either Riggs needed to dig deeper or she should have included a wider range of personalities.
He walks on water, heals the sick and raises the dead. But not even Jesus can transform "Son of God" into a compelling epic.

What does John Cusack get, professionally or personally, from making so many mediocre movies like this empty, ugly thriller?

Predictable as the adventure may be, the company - and the countryside - make it worthwhile.
Unimaginative and bland.
A committed cast elevates what is, ultimately, a gimmicky thriller. It dissolves into a puddle of blood-tinged hypocrisy.

The intentions feel authentic, but not enough else does.

Not a second of this feels real, but at least we see Duvall croon "Mexicali Rose."
Phil Alden Robinson's overheated dramedy feels disconnected from reality in every emotional way, but at least he captures the impotent fury that hits everyone stuck in the wrong lane on Flatbush Ave.
But because Besson is so limited in his vision, she resembles a gorgeous robot more than a fascinatingly evolved human being.
To some, Corbijn's movie will feel moody and complex. But anyone looking for fizz or flash will spend most of the movie engaged in a hearty game of Watch Check.

Disappointingly, Foner's young heroines are defined primarily by their reactions to other people. It's a great credit to Olsen and, especially, Fanning that they manage to make these characters vibrant and sympathetic anyway.
Fast-paced, funny, and packed with - to indulge in a bit of ad-speak -eye-popping action.

To see an expensive, big-studio movie freed from creative constraints and directorial cynicism is always a rare and wondrous experience. In a season of bloated indulgence, it's also fair to call it a marvel.
It's McCarthy's complex use of language, rather than the plot's grueling imagery, that elevate the book. There's simply not enough insight here to make the punishment worthwhile.
Catherine Keener rarely gets the chance to grab the spotlight all for herself. That makes this turgid drama especially disappointing.
"Happy Christmas" is a lovely example of an undeniably valuable genre.
Zwick clearly wanted to update "The Big Chill," but he never pushes past the concept itself.
It's admirable that writer/director Michael Walker wanted to make a socially conscious thriller. But surely he didn't have to replace all the thrills with broadly moralizing messages.
If you're willing to treat the stiff dialogue and uneven performances as so much light drizzle, it's easy enough to get caught up in the action.
Dowse blankets his love story with heavy layers of cutesy quirkiness, but there's no denying its conventional and derivative soul.
It's not the sort of festival favorite that will change an industry, make hundreds of millions or earn Oscars. What it will do is charm viewers who appreciate rough gems.
It may be time to put the zombie trend to rest. At least that's what writer-director Jeff Baena's initially promising, and ultimately disappointing, directorial debut suggests.
Breillat's self-conscious refusal to establish a realistic basis for this deeply mismatched relationship winds up weakening the film irreparably.
Coogan and Brydon make terrific companions for us partially because, at least as they appear onscreen, they're so amusingly incompatible themselves.
I went through half a pack of Kleenex watching "If I Stay." But know this: those tears are no more honestly earned than if director R.J. Cutler had merely been chopping onions in front of me.
How could Weiner make, as his debut comedy, a movie as amateurish and off-putting as this one?
The characters don't click, and the action feels dull.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jennifer Kroot's good-natured biography is so appealing that even non-Trekkies may be convinced we needed a full-length documentary about the man who was Sulu.
The movie often feels like a full-length ad for a great workplace, which just happens to stash whips and chains in the stationery closet.
Imagine James Bond without the charm, heart, and sense of humor.
Schechter based "Life of Crime" on Elmore Leonard's novel "The Switch." And though the movie is not a disaster, his unfocused effort does sit pretty low on the list of Leonard adaptations.
There's not a three-dimensional character or nuanced observation to be seen here.
Writer-director Carter Smith got his start as a successful fashion photographer. But you wouldn't know it from the murky look of this generic thriller.
You won't find much heft in Maria Sole Tognazzi's Italian dramedy, but it'll make for a decent mini-vacation if you could use a brief escape.
Thank goodness for director Michel Gondry ("Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind"), whose vision is so brazenly, enduringly unique.
How could a movie that offers Jason Segel riffing on sex and Cameron Diaz regularly disrobing be so dull?
Awkward and atonal.
Alas, there are no sparks. There is no excitement. Hopkins' clumsy script simply bumbles its way past plot holes into predictabilities.
MacFarlane has corralled a great cast, which makes it especially disappointing that the movie's merely OK.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Be forewarned: What admirers will consider measured may read, to the unimpressed, as merely slow-moving.
Swedish auteur Lukas Moodysson returns to his roots here with a charming coming-of-age drama.

Liman and his screenwriters - Christopher McQuarrie ("The Usual Suspects") and Jez and John-Henry Butterworth ("Fair Game") - make their concept feel fresh with smart setups and ambitious (if underdeveloped) themes.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The parts are greater than the whole, but there's a lot to like here, including the easy interplay between the leads.
You don't ever really know what's going on, but at least the heavy-handed music tells you what to feel.
[Gregg] makes a tonally disastrous swerve ...
[Features] a charming performance from Tom Schilling as Niko, a confused college dropout wandering around Berlin as his world casually crumbles.
Leduc is an author worth knowing about, but this is a character only an already-established fan could love.
It's the unflinching edge that gives the film its unexpected depth.
The desolate country is alluringly evocative, but Michôd relies too heavily on atmosphere when we need meaningful action.

If you've ever been inside a multiplex before, you can guess what happens during their vacation. Sure, it would be nice if the filmmakers gave us a few surprises before the happy ending. What's worse, though, is how low their comic bar is set.
Young's bland Valli never really grabs us the way he should. But when Piazza smolders and glowers as Tommy, the group's fiery wild card, we can't take our eyes off of him.
Daniel Cohen's genial French comedy is as airy as a soufflé. Alas, it's not nearly as satisfying.
Ultimately, this biopic seems far more interested in Saint Laurent's emotional passions, and the love story between him and Bergé serves as the movie's core.
Rudd and Poehler are a delight together; she hits the broader gags with endearing enthusiasm, and he tweaks his own experience as a romantic leading man with deadpan irony.
Knightley does fine work, but she's been miscast. Her innate sophistication undermines the movie's intentions right off the bat.
Zemeckis, who also made the 2010 burlesque chronicle "Behind the Burly Q," expands the Hiltons' biography into a fascinating history of the American sideshow.
The 6-year-old I watched it with summed it up perfectly: "It starts out fun but then it's kinda sad and scary. And sorta boring, too."
The movie feels less like a weak "E.T." than a substandard "Mac and Me."
It's not the possession but the predictability that'll make your head spin.
Rejected the status quo with an irreverent, quick-cutting documentary style that could fairly be described as mod, rocking and mocking.
Heavy doses of humor and empathy, along with gorgeous hand-drawn animation, keep things from getting too morbid.
A retread of every lousy '80s high school comedy you never bothered watching.
Pahani's films have become increasingly indistinguishable from his complex life, making them a challenging but often thrilling experience.
Gets points for both effort and entertainment value - even if viewers will be hard-pressed to find much coherence in his convoluted plot.
An uneven effort ...
Jim Mickle's gripping adaptation of Joe R. Lansdale's pulp novel.
It's hard to know whether Sebastian Gutierrez is imitating or satirizing the hard-boiled noirs of Hollywood's past, but either way it feels like a botched attempt.
This earnest adaptation of Michael Muhammad Knight's novel is too busy processing events to fully understand them. But director Eyad Zahra is so enthusiastic that he wins us over anyway.
Ever catch yourself thinking, "Man, I wish beer commercials lasted just 104 minutes longer"?
Drive Angry is pure grindhouse, so committed to its own junkiness that it is, in its way, a pleasure to behold.
Sharp-edged, surreal, and often astonishing in its giddy creativity.
A film whose extreme self-consciousness begins with the title and carries through.
It tries hard, but it always falls short.
Though there's enough to admire intellectually here, every "Jane Eyre" should also deliver some emotional swoons.
If you're willing to ignore the many leaps in logic, his fast-paced thriller goes down easy enough with a side of popcorn.
While Frost is particularly well-cast, most of the actors seem to be having fun. You will, too, as long as you arrive with lowered expectations.
Those who pore over his fashion columns in the New York Times Style section will particularly appreciate this respectful look at a true local character.
[The film] doesn't offer a single flying sequin to justify its considerably higher ticket price. It's simply a blandly shot recording of Michael Flatley's musical revue, as performed overseas.
We're left wondering how Desmond Tutu wound up in this vanity project in the first place.
Zombie soldiers, dragons, cyborgs, doesn't matter: Snyder is just a big boy with lots of toys. These, unfortunately, include his actresses.
Despite the cliches that push every scene forward, there's an unexpected appeal to John Gray's modest drama, emanating from its center.
Neither Francophiles nor film fans could ask for anything more than François Ozon's latest, a charming comedy that showcases its iconic stars, Catherine Deneuve and Gérard Depardieu.

Judging by the actors involved in Barry Blaustein's amusing but unpolished comedy, it's fair to assume he has a friends in high places. That's good, since they refine Peter Himmelstein's rough script.
"Super" starts off feeling like a cult comedy you might catch during a midnight film festival. But since Gunn never nails his tone, the concept makes more sense than the execution.
As fake and forgettable as a marshmallow Peep, "Hop" goes down easy enough. It's the thought of a talented actor stuck on an industry conveyor belt that leaves an unfortunate aftertaste.
It's a tribute to Adrien Brody that Wrecked works as a modestly compelling thriller, since there's almost nothing to see but Brody himself.
Though John Stockwell's action comedy is shamelessly derivative, his enthusiastic cast propels it much further than it should go.
Franco truly saves the day. His hilarious deadpan in the midst of utter insanity turns a bawdy goof into a most welcome lark indeed.
Fans of Kelly Reichardt's minimalist portraits will adore her stark Western, but others may be taken aback by the bold lack of traditional filmmaking.
A decent weekend diversion, this IMAX documentary is cute enough to engage your kids, while teaching them the most basic lessons in ecological responsibility.
Does Uma Thurman perpetually underestimate herself, or is Quentin Tarantino the only filmmaker who appreciates her?
Anyone who bemoans the gentrification of New York will revel in Celine Danhier's love letter to a long-ago city, back in the late '70s.
If Tyler Perry finds liberation in lipstick, Lawrence has become suffocated by Spanx.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Redford's fictionalized chronicle of Mary Surratt's 1865 trial is high-minded and slow-moving. Some may chafe at his unsubtle sermonizing, but strong central performances will reward the patient.
The complete lack of explanation suggests Jaswinski forgot to finish his script. But Anderson tries hard to compensate, distracting us with suitably ghostly atmospherics.
[Bieber is] the perfect first crush, and this is the perfect movie for someone currently experiencing that crush.
You know things are bad when you've started feeling sorry for your villain.

Fans of the original may be dismayed by his often-awkward adaptation, which turns too many of Shange's survivors into victims. But it's equally likely that his blunt, emotional approach -- using her words to create his own melodrama -- will connect ...
Those hoping for another "Hangover" may be disappointed by Todd Phillips' punch-drunk followup, which is basically "Planes, Trains and Automobiles" for the road-rage generation.
Though based on a true story with a well-known outcome, Doug Liman's "Fair Game" is as suspenseful as any fictional thriller -- and considerably more tragic.
Every aspiring performer will appreciate Gregori Viens' unassuming comedy, which cheerfully skewers industry pretensions and media-fueled trends.
Stahl should have had a career similar to Sam Rockwell's, blending thoughtful indies with fun popcorn flicks. Instead, he's spinning his wheels in junk like this.
It takes a little while to pick up speed, but once Tony Scott's "Unstoppable" starts moving, it becomes a lean, efficient action flick.
Equal parts action thriller, political parable, and multidimensional love story, Hallows feels sad and strong and true.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Two hours of recycled plots and plastic acting.
A psychosexual thriller that lures its viewers into a woozy nightmare.
A decent family adventure, perfectly suited to a cold Saturday morning -- and likely to be forgotten by Sunday.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: How do you know when to cut your losses and go see something else?
Anyone who's seen Gibney's superior version will immediately be struck by how false this fictionalized account feels.
The relative lack of coarseness and snark may come as a surprising relief, even to 21st-century audiences.
All together now: "FockersFockers-Fockers." Are you rolling on the floor in hilarity?
"Somewhere" is an undeniably minor film. But if you"re willing to be indulgent, you"ll find surprising pleasures hidden within.
It all feels so lazy and familiar that adults may find themselves hoping Black will start to challenge himself again -- and the more swiftly the better.
The perfect haven from the cheap ironies and cruel indifference we all have to field both in life and, far too often, at the movies.
What saves "Country Strong" from drowning in its own tears are the leads, all four of whom imbue Feste's unabashedly clichéd script with some genuine humanity.

Michel Gondry has crafted an irreverently funny, ultramodern take on the 1930s radio serial, with a vibe so casual you half expect star Seth Rogen to amble off screen and put his feet up on the seat next to you.
Real life isn't choreographed for maximum impact, it's messy and unpredictable. At its best, so is "Every Day."
Portman will get past this speed bump with well-earned swiftness. The affable Kutcher, however, seems stuck in a cycle of depressingly empty comedies.
Lawrence Levine should earn some attention with this agreeable indie comedy.
movie_title: Gabi on the Roof in July (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If ever a thriller were to inspire a collective "eh," it's got to be "The Roommate." It's not a good movie, by any means, but it's also not bad enough to have fun hating on.
Frankly, it's depressing to watch two likable talents pushing such a blatantly empty experience.

The movie belongs to Helms and Reilly, ringleaders who barely seem to notice that the script from Phil Johnston favors easy jokes and obvious setups. They, and the others, give this minor movie major heart.
Relying on obvious clichés doesn't seem ironic anymore, just easy. And though there are several genuine jolts, poor pacing leaves too much time between the silliness and scares.
The cast and crew render every detail so exquisitely that there's almost too much take in at once. Repeat viewings will be required.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A well-meant drama that never transcends its earnest aims, Janet Grillo's feature debut is notable mostly for an heroic turn from lead Beth Broderick.
With its careful compositions and message-minded dialogue, Chris Weitz's modest drama feels more earnest than real. Still, its sincerity is admirable, and often touching.
Despite their efforts to address most sides of this complex story, each new interview leaves us wanting to know even more.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A haunting portrait of loneliness in its starkest state.

Bay misses every opportunity to make something interesting out of his characters; instead, he's content to spend his enormous budget on grinding destruction so generic and visually convoluted, it's often hard to tell who we're supposed to be rooting for.
Director and co-writer Thomas Bezucha shows no particular flair for either of his jobs. But kids are unlikely to focus on the terrible editing, flat visuals, or lack of character development.
Crawford radiates charisma, and Pierce sells even the nuttiest moments.
This story doesn't go well with popcorn, and you won't be able to shake it off like so many blockbusters. That said, it's likely to be the most unforgettable film you see all summer.
Throw a party and ask all your friends to share their stories; you'll probably find more surprises, and have a lot more fun.
Gordon, who made the terrific documentary "The King of Kong," is still a little wobbly when it comes to fiction. Fortunately, his outstanding cast steadies all but the most uneven moments.
Young Besnaïnou is so lovely that her solemn independence is a wonder to behold, and her early adventures retain an eerie and compelling charm.
Oy, such terrible jokes and choppy direction.

Gavin recalls his experiences while standing atop a building ready to jump; we're meant to be on edge ourselves, but the only real mystery is why Tyler took such an unrewarding role in the first place.
It's wonderful. Epic and heartbreaking and just as grand as it needs to be.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Starts out on the right path, but loses its way early on.
It's all compelling, in the way reading trashy gossip usually is. But without any new perspectives, what's the point?
Can't get yourself off the couch? You'll find all the inspiration you need from this spirited look at Oregon's titular marathon.
Thank your lucky stars I had to see Gil Cates Jr.'s darkly comic misfire early enough to warn you against wasting your own time and money.
While there is some sense of the complex dynamics that propel all teen parties, the pacing drags in a way a summer night never should.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the cool visuals, its bold self-assurance remains unearned.
"Friends With Benefits" isn't nearly as original as it pretends to be. But it's cute and funny and sweet, which -- as any woman can attest -- puts it way ahead of most Friday night options.
McDonagh indulges in too many '90s affectations, from blaring chapter titles to philosophizing gangsters. But he captures his misty setting's insular atmosphere beautifully.
Miranda July's rejection of traditional storytelling is valuable, but the common complaints that her work is mannered or twee are accurate.
The cast is splendid, the script quick-witted and the action satisfying.
I laughed all the way through, thanks to both consistently clever dialogue and deft delivery from Carell and Gosling, who clearly relished a chance to flex his comic muscles.
The thing is, this could have been funny.
Barely makes the grade in either humor or provocation.
Thanks to plucky performances and some perfectly precious pets, "Mr. Poppers Penguins" provides a pleasant, if obviously packaged, pursuit.
Even if we can't live his cowboy life, Buck Brannaman's world is well worth visiting.
As smart as it is side-splittingly silly.
The story has heat, even if the movie is more entranced with its subjects than in what they're trying to achieve.

Director Francis Lawrence and writer Richard LaGravenese replicate just enough of the novel's fantasy to keep audiences involved, even if the results hardly add up to the most spectacular show at the cineplex.
[Perry has] recycled the same material so many times, it's starting to turn rancid.
Now this is how you make a summer movie.
"Broom" doesn't take any risks or offer many surprises. But then, do most weddings?
Even if you've got a soft spot for silly rom-coms, know that this one is as empty-headed as it gets.
Massy Tadjedin's intimate directorial debut takes a spare, thoughtful approach to relationships.
Just as Apatow redefined leading men in a more realistic manner, Wiig may well change the way Hollywood looks at ladies.
In truth, this would be rather familiar indie fare without its perfectly-cast star, who fearlessly alternates between bitter humor, aggressive desperation, and gentle helplessness.
Fans who've been waiting 15 years for the director of "Drunken Master" to helm a new movie definitely won't be disappointed.
Is Antonio Banderas's career really such a big bust? On the one hand, it's a shame to see a talented guy slumming in this budget-bin thriller. On the other, it'd be entirely unwatchable without him.
Though noticeably lacking in originality, Anthony Burns' low-key directorial debut skates by on the charms of its hazy wistfulness and a likable cast.
An action comedy as entertaining to watch as it evidently was to make.
The new captain is Rob Marshall, who scrapes off a few of the barnacles that clung to the last effort. But he can't avoid the feeling that this adventure has run aground.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though underdeveloped, Charlie Minn's passionate look at Mexico's saddest city is indisputably moving.
When Julianne Moore enthuses about the fact that kids got crayons with their meals, you have to wonder if a short film might have suited this story better.
movie_title: Florent: Queen Of The Meat Market (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It would be nice if Phillips could find something original to say when we all get together to tear the next town apart.
The parts are ultimately greater than the whole, but Adam Reid's offbeat debut suggests a talent worth watching.
It's big, bright, savvy, and so expansive you'll undoubtedly leave feeling you got your money's worth.
A misfire from frenetic start to frantic finish, Dermot Mulroney's filmmaking debut suggests his gifts are best seen in front of the camera.
Though written too broadly to serve as the powerful allegorical tale writer/director Christina Yao intends, this historical epic is just compelling enough to be taken on its own terms.
The kind of rare cinematic challenge that was made for film students- and likely to try the patience of anyone else.

Ultimately, the movie's dry structure is irrelevant: after two hours in the company of singers like the Soul Stirrers, Rosetta Tharpe, and Mahalia Jackson, you'll leave feeling exalted no matter what.
What we're left with is a sort of contact high, drifting gently over to our seats in the back row.

Sombogaart approaches his soapy subject with just enough restraint. As a result, you can convince yourself it's a highbrow arthouse film even as you're swooning and sniffling over so many tangled love stories.
There are rewards to be teased out of Monte Hellman's enigmatic new picture, but you'll have to accept the title as a promise, rather than a threat.
Having a bad day? Then get yourself to Greg Jacobs and Jon Siskel's life-affirming documentary, immediately.

Ten years into the Jackass franchise, it's obvious the well is starting to run dry. Then again, if you show Johnny Knoxville an empty well, he'll jump in headfirst. After packing it with writhing snakes.
Reeves so deeply understands the nature of childhood terror that Let Me In burns with a white-hot clarity.
The script is merely serviceable and too reminiscent of similar fantasy tales. But kids will instantly relate to the gentle Soren, while watching wide-eyed as he faces each challenge.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director John Lee Hancock has turned Oher's remarkable life into a Hollywood fable that trades difficult truths for easy clichés.

Pedro Almodóvar's latest is perfectly titled: it's a big, swoony kiss that doesn't quite connect with the passion he intends. But fans of the Spanish auteur--or his muse, Penélope Cruz--will find plenty to love.
DeMonaco deserves credit for wanting to do something different. But what starts out as a witty tweak on tired mobster movies eventually collapses into those very same clichés.
Surprisingly conventional by director Richard Linklater's standards, this pleasant, low-key dramedy is most memorable for the discovery of co-star Christian McKay.
One has to wonder if oil industry executives are concerned about the release of Joe Berlinger's damning documentary.
A lovely Hollywood romance that floats buoyantly along on a sea of sadness.
If one of your non-filmmaker friends watched Office Space a few too many times, this is probably the movie he'd make.
Both visually and emotionally ugly from start to finish, this empty crime thriller doesn't have a moment that's genuinely worth watching.
Though all the actors try to expand their underwritten roles, Mirren is most successful.
A Single Man -- the striking directorial debut from fashion designer Tom Ford -- is so unusually beautiful it would be easy to dismiss it as superficial.
Thirteen-year-old boys big enough to sneak into R-rated movies are presumably the prime audience for this witless comedy from the Broken Lizard troupe.
Herzog fans will love it.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The numbers are flashy enough to entertain, and the cast appealing enough to appreciate. Just don't expect to fall in love.
A biography that is quite enjoyable to watch, and a bit too easy to forget.

Actually, Hollywood, it's very simple: If you're lucky enough to rope pros like Meryl Streep, Alec Baldwin and Steve Martin into a formulaic comedy that's clearly beneath them, you rise to the occasion.
While this recently rediscovered screenplay won't rank with the best of Williams, the script does possess a poignancy that remains frustratingly out of reach onscreen.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Stay home and rent Junebug or Enchanted instead.

Francois ultimately resembles every other character Cera has played, only with a mustache and a dirtier mouth. If he wants to show us what else he can do, he'll need to stage a much bigger rebellion than this.
The filmmakers' motivation couldn't be clearer: They needed to capture a way of life that may soon exist only on film and in memory.

The script -- which took three people to write -- is barely coherent, and it's unclear whether Brian Levant was even on set when he directed. All that's left for us to enjoy are the action scenes, and frankly most of those are a little depressing.

As you may have guessed, this is purely synthetic, assembly-line stuff, with messages like "Dreams are good for everyone." As a result Johnson overcompensates, amping up his typical enthusiasm until it feels uncharacteristically false.
Even if you overlook the lousy lighting, awkward editing, and uneven acting, there's so much talking -- and so little story -- that your mind is likely to wander.
Gibson hasn't had a starring role in seven years, but he has no trouble returning to work. That he looks a little wearier, and a lot older, simply adds to his character's pathos.
The leads do have a strong chemistry, and Seyfried brings a spunky confidence to her role.

There's little difference between the first and second movies so the perfunctory story line will feel familiar to fans. But the action, and the head-spinning stunts of those agile lead actors, will never get old.
Weitz takes a looser approach than the series' last director, Catherine Hardwicke, did. He has a better sense of humor, too.
A somber drama about intimate wartime tragedies, Oren Moverman's debut feels more respectful than real.
I could fairly describe the 2012 plot as follows: The highest-paid members of an indifferent cast survive the massive floods and giant fireballs that cause our planet's destruction.
A visual treasure that successfully blends deadpan quirkiness with a wry realism rarely seen in any film, let alone one for children.
You could get angry that a guy like this even got a chance. Or you could just forget about him, and move on to something worthwhile.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: [It] embraces broad jokes and obvious setups. Fortunately, these are balanced out by assertive pacing and entertaining observations.
Actor John Krasinski deserves credit for having the ambition to adapt material as difficult as David Foster Wallace's short stories.

Since everyone is turned into such a caricature, the answers feel optional. It's hard to forget that Larry's fate is being controlled not by God or luck or even his own worst instincts, but by the Coens.
It's that happiest of surprises: a multiplex movie that genuinely respects its young audience.
The footage is terrific, and all the guys make for charismatic heroes. But Belman barely addresses the stories happening off the court.
Though Maya Angelou is enlisted as the solemn narrator of Hilary Helstein's Holocaust documentary, the survivors here need no help expressing their own tragedies.
Ever go on a vacation where most of the people around seem to be having more fun than you? Then you already know what it'll feel like to visit Couples Retreat.
Just as a great player can take an average team to surprising heights, Michael Sheen turns an ordinary sports movie into an unexpected winner.
Whether you have good hair or not, there's plenty to appreciate in Chris Rock's rollicking documentary about what goes on when African-American women hit the salon.
It's not the rough edges that bother here; it's the desperate attempt to capture Napoleon Dynamite's success by relying on oddball characters and off-the-wall scenarios.
Bleu remains one to watch, but only real fans will want to watch this.
Don't worry if you miss some details; this is the kind of movie that rewards a second viewing.
Anyone with a fondness for the midcentury cartoons and films that inspired this scrappy comedy will appreciate the latest trip to the titular British boarding school.
Just when her Chilean employwers wonder if she's sociopathic, Saavedra suggests that Raquel's behavior is, in fact, perfectly rational.

The details are perfect, from the particle-board sets to the porn-ready score. (And dig those polyester suits.) But just like the movies it parodies, this one feels over long before it's actually done.
Does John Leguizamo need a better manager, or does he just have terrible taste in scripts? Because aside from voicing the Ice Age movies, he wastes too much time on misfires like this one.
While Twilight will make more money and get more attention, the darkly comic Cirque du Freak boasts the shaggy charm of the natural underdog.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: David Bowers' retro-cool update on the titular icon looks so great, it may take a while to notice it's a clunky political parable wrapped in a tonally confused fairy tale.

Jaa, who co-directs, has only one thing in mind: a series of increasingly complex fight scenes in his characteristically wide-ranging style. If movie theaters allowed you to fast-forward past the filler, your life just might be complete.

Because Parker is so determined to expose the art scene's pretensions, he neglects other areas, like dialogue, plot and character. And what's the point in making a shallow satire about shallow subjects?
The only truly ugly side to this self-consciously grimy movie is the streak of Neanderthal humor. Operatic overacting is funny. Racist and homophobic jokes? Not so much.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hess wrote and directed "Dynamite," and here's proof we shouldn't have rewarded him. The hollow Broncos is even more cruelly disdainful, designed primarily to scorn the pathetic lives within.

Daniels is not a subtle director, and he encourages Mo'Nique's powerful expansiveness. But it's much harder to act quietly than loudly, as Sidibe must do, and her still grace should not be mistaken for blankness.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some directors, it must be said, only have one really good movie in them. We're starting to worry that Richard Kelly may be among this select group.

It would have been helpful had Smith put his words into some sort of context, allowing others to assess his theories. Instead there's simply Ruppert, talking, raging and warning, as if his very life depended on it.
Where's the ethnic diversity? The cultural overflow? The dirt, the chaos, the cramped quarters, the people who look like us, rather than movie stars?
Ken Kesey decided the camera was mightier than the pen. This enjoyable but surprisingly unenlightening documentary suggests otherwise.
Such dark doings won't be for everyone, but fans of similarly dry Nordic fare - like the works of Aki Kaurismaki - will be happy to have found it.

movie_title: Etoiles: Dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Though it's not much more than an haute-bourgeois morality play about the inadequacy of bourgeois morals, that's plenty in view of the small but terrific ensemble at Fellowes' disposal.

movie_review_blurb: This fluidly paced film, with its keen observation of the confused longing for love, family and stability in an inherently unstable world, nonetheless keeps faith with the Czech genius for holding the tonal line between tragedy and the absurd.

movie_review_blurb: Strangely moving.

The visceral passion of these tales of poverty-stricken but tight communities, dreaming and striving for better futures for their children, gripped me.
Straddling nihilism and a moral fastidiousness so "pure" it flirts with the very fascism it means to critique, The Notebook cedes not one solitary inch to humanism.
In the end, Weir's movie is more a capitulation than a challenge to television, and a vulgar one at that. Truman turns out to be more Burbank than he is True-man.
If nothing else, Memento is a savvy comment on the queasy uncertainties of the postmodern condition, in which history goes no further back than yesterday's news.
Self-taught and roaming free in the city, Vivian Maier captured the remarkable in the ordinary.
An old-school drama so sincere, yet so ham-fisted, it borders on parody.
A magnificently lush, broody period piece that harks back to the great maternal melodramas of the mid-20th century.
Shoots for vintage screwball and misses for lack of wit.
There's no dismissing the film, if only because it offers another long, loud example of how Hollywood remains the hagiographic spinmeister of American war history.

If Steven Spielberg's emotional intelligence matched his visual genius, his harrowing, passionately felt and honorably flawed new film might qualify for one of the greatest American movies ever made about World War II.
It hardly matters that Jolie's accent rambles a bit between pungent Cockney and plummy Buckingham Palace.
If only the movie didn't insist on constantly telling us what it has quite clearly shown.
Elegantly scripted with an edge of biting gallows humor by Stepan Hulik, Burning Bush blends an intimate domestic drama with a thrilling Cold War procedural ...
A richly detailed portrait of a great man riddled with flaws and undone by adulation.
Bulger remains frustratingly opaque.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Recalled in the somewhat breathless History Channel-style voice-overs of the participants and their families, the journey was a triumph of guts, perseverance, endurance, ingenuity and teamwork.
Land Ho! walks and talks like a hand-held indie, except that it keeps making these funny skips into horror comedy and the musical.
The kind of careful, listless adaptation that makes a critic want to rave at length about the wonderful novel on which it's based.
The Babadook makes the most of its special effects as needed, but this smart little frightener keeps its head close to the rising anxiety of a young widow whose husband died a violent death.
The plotting is wooden, the flashbacks lazy, the adoption device a bad joke, and as always, everyone stammers like Woody.

Computer Chess is about the dawn - one of many, but that's another story - of the tech revolution. It's also a reminder that you don't need state-of-the-art toys to make a formally playful comedy about man versus machine.
While it's lavish and lush in all the expected costume-drama ways, A Royal Affair never bogs down in period detail.
Minor but satisfying ...
It's hard not to feel carried along by the generously conciliatory spirit that warms The Other Son ...
For once in an American movie, the uplift feels earned.

At a time when most family movies come processed through extreme software and 3-D glasses, this film's gentle vision of the simple life has its old-fashioned charms - though they press too hard on the emo buttons for my taste.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It is what it is, which is emphatically not enough to bear the weight of genocide.
What I liked was the movie's feel for the emotional mess and ambivalence of family ties, and its openness without hysteria to the fact that some of those ties might fray beyond repair.
A propaganda piece with blame on its mind.

The film's rhythms mimic the volatile emotional life of adolescence: the violent rushes between euphoria and despair, the overconfident contempt for adults mixed with regressive dependence when things fall apart.
How to Survive a Plague is thorough almost to a fault.
The Master will burrow its way into your mind, heart and soul, and simmer there long after you leave the theater.
The Words founders on a spurious dichotomy between love and art.
An alarming documentary about the trafficking of Russian child models to the Japanese fashion market ...

Have we really come a long way from chick flicks about women expressing friendship by nursing each other though divorce, cancer and other common losses, to movies in which women can only express love through a windy haze of carnal chatter?
A warm-hearted if somewhat over-orchestrated documentary that gives voice to four teenaged adoptees from loving but very different homes.
A sweetly muted domestic drama struggling to contain a fierce and ancient folk tale.
Why Stop Now refuses to keep faith with its characters, to carry them as far as they can go without tying them up in a neat bow of redemption.
Let's just say that the dog gets the best lines.
Inventing Our Life hosts a conversation about a utopian dream as it encounters the realities of social change and human limitation.
movie_title: Inventing Our Life: The Kibbutz Experiment (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's a sweet-tempered folly in which all's well that ends well.
Bobcat Goldthwait's bracing new black comedy...
Deeper down, the movie seethes quietly with the moody influence of other East European masters of the timeless ineffable.

The best that can be said of Knightley is that she's puppy-eyed eye candy, in vibrant reds and blacks with fur trims to die for.

A sensitive, decent, well-crafted little drama about frailty and forgiveness.

This heartfelt tale of disintegration and acceptance, seasoned with family devotion, will both raise and soothe the anxieties of those of us who regularly ask ourselves why we came into the kitchen two minutes ago.

The movie makes for joyless viewing, big stars and all.

It treats its themes of guilt and responsibility with delicate tact and a precise eye for the neglected commitments that stubbornly dog a man trying his damnedest to efface himself from the world.
A big-hearted and veddy English chamber piece, never mind that it was directed - respectfully and with love - by famous Yank Dustin Hoffman.

A love poem to the ultra-Orthodox world as seen from within.

Horrific and uplifting ...

This enormously satisfying story honors the smiling, courageous couple we see in a photo behind the closing credits.

This emotionally intelligent first feature offers a sympathetic but clear-eyed look at the tangled skein of inequalities that entrap women (and the men they love and resent) in a Bedouin village.

movie_review_blurb: "You have a nutty energy," one bemused prospect tells Michal, and that is generally true of this brightly colored, often zany crowdpleaser with sharply written dialogue and a pop soundtrack.

movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bening's expert runs up and down the emotional register leave no room for doubt about Grahame's charisma even when she's playing her own worst enemy.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Human Flow leaves us wondering what will become of this lost generation, stranded without home or schooling or work, if or when they run out of hope and turn to anger or despair.

A love story that restores agency to a woman who has lost all, and asks us to take a hard look at our own.

Clocking in at a trim 76 minutes, The B-side is as warmly affectionate as its subject, a close friend and neighbor of the director.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Swim Team is long enough to break and warm your heart in equal measure - which is about what you'd expect from a documentary about teenagers with autism who are training to compete in the Special Olympics.

Mesmerizing ...
If you liked Webb's enormously popular but, to this critic's mind, horribly pandering (500 Days) of Summer, you'll probably enjoy this too.

Polina springs to vivid life as a winsome hip-hop ballet.

Willfully or not, the director misses one opportunity after another to pull back and assess.

A winning humanity seeps through the high jinks. Lawson comes not to judge, but to assess the unintended consequences of sexual free play.

An engaging if heavily sugared portrait of a courageous woman triumphing over a disfiguring genetic mutation that prevents her from gaining weight.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even without its moving parable of emotional repair, When Marnie Was There has all of Ghibli's exquisitely hand-drawn sense of place ...
Never less than a sensual delight. The editing craftily mimics Laurent's style, impeccably cut and full of stealth moves and weird angles that take you by surprise.

It looks lovely, yet Wenders' worshipful account of Salgado the man feels like a tale half told.

Gayle Kirschenbaum explores her fraught relationship with her mother in this richly ambivalent documentary.

Let me say off the bat that without the transcendent performance of its star... Martin Pieter Zandvliet's drama about an allegedly recovering alcoholic trying to regain custody of her kids would add very little to the conversation.
Satisfyingly overwrought ...

A powerful maternal melodrama spanning three generations of implacable women bound by blood, spilled milk and the tumult of a world in transition.
Lolo is fun and fresh to look at: Violette's habitat is fashion-world, Centre-Pompidou new Paris, blessedly free of the Louvre-and-Seine shorthand that sells French movies to American audiences.

Though Miller is a bit lighter on her feet here than in some of her other movies, Maggie's Plan doesn't clip along smartly enough for screwball. In the end, there just isn't enough chemistry to go round ...
The stakes remain infantile, the black humor never flags, but the competition takes on a sinister savagery as bro-bonding alliances shift and hero-worship curdles into betrayal and resentment.
At its sharpest, The Witness is a careful inquiry into the tricks memory plays, and into how ambiguous events get reshaped into narratives that fit individual and collective needs.

Minor but highly watchable ...
Solondz gives no quarter, nor does he mince words about where we're all headed. His vision of our predicament is bleakly funny and weirdly heartfelt.

River of Grass is very funny, but in a more somber key it also test-drives what will become Reichardt's specialty: the transformation of cheerless wastelands into backdrops for journeys of the parched soul.
It's hard to put into words the wildly imagined beauty of director Ale Abreu's drawing, with crayons and other tools kids might use.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Gere's deft showboating, with Fanning under-compensating beautifully at the other end of the seesaw, is quite enough to carry a movie whose potency surely depends on not spelling things out.
On the plus side, the Mojave desert looks mighty handsome, and I really liked the twangy guitar.
If the movie touches on universal issues of sibling rivalry, the psychological insight is almost incidental in what is an intensely particular and roughly tender tone piece.
The film is an intensely descriptive, head-to-the-ground mood piece, and when it's not talking too much, Glassland is the satisfyingly tangled love story of a boy and his mama.
A handsomely mounted drama about a pivotal moment in the life of track star Jesse Owens ...
At once compassionate and rueful, "Colliding Dreams" is recommended viewing for open minds, and essential viewing for those that remain snapped shut.
Pairing Rampling with Courtenay was an ingenious move, and not only because the two perform a beautifully calibrated pas de deux.

A peculiar and occasionally charming poke in the ribs of the superman myth.

movie_title: Bunt. Delo Litvinenko (Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File) (Rebellion: The Litvinenko Case) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Mike Myers likes ice hockey. He also likes Deepak Chopra, a little bit too much. So he pulled together a bit of hockey and a whole lot of Chopra and called it a plot.
Canadian filmmaker Jeremy Podeswa has given it the old college try, but in pursuit of tact and sensitivity, he has hollowed out the novel's urgency.
A pity that, other than the fights, everything else in the movie is equally bloodless.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This goofy tale of self-emancipation, a love story made by a mature man wise to the possibilities of the improbable, is also a thriller with an unexpectedly dark edge.

A savage, funny, tender, tragic and strangely beautiful riff on being young and growing up in a broken world.
A tale as ploddingly familiar as it is good-looking and worth telling.
Claude Miller's World War II domestic drama is unusually attentive to the way that the Holocaust disrupted lives that were messy enough to begin with.
A mesmerizingly ambivalent documentary about an itinerant family of Jewish surfer-dude health nuts.

By all means, gather up the little ones and take them to this perfectly pleasant, very good-looking, modestly funny, dispiritingly unoriginal variant on the nerd-with-a-dream recipe.

movie_review_blurb: Like most British realist dramas, When Did You Last See Your Father? is stuffed with team-player acting.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Schütte deftly juggles antic comedy, pathos, and melancholy.

movie_review_blurb: What's depressing about this movie and others like it is the low bar it sets for both modern women and the movies that seek to represent them.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Gray's lack of interpretive distance from his subject, coupled with extreme overacting from his lead actor, results in melodrama that sits up and begs to be farce.

movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Nodding, winking and sighing, The Lodger lumbers its way to a final twist so anticlimactic and silly as to warrant an incredulous titter.

This being Disney, wholesome character-building messages abound, but for once they're freshly spun as cautions against stereotyping both ethnic and canine.

movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For all the familiar terrain it plows -- dysfunctional clan comes unglued, regroups -- the movie is not without its sly rewards, one of which is Anne Hathaway.

Jaw-droppingly arcane and dripping with self-regard.
Doubt is being squired around town as prime Oscar bait. But in Shanley's hands, it only looks deep.
The world's tweens and teens deserve better than this bottomlessly bland pap.

This loving throwback to the paranoid thrillers of the '70s is a beauty.

movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict (2007)

movie_review_blurb: First-time director Corneliu Porumboiu's political satire is uproariously funny and bitingly critical of social hypocrisy before and after Ceausescu, and of the new forms of mythmaking and corruption that have replaced Soviet-style autocracy.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For realism's sake, Jarrold checks in with the usual muddy hems, misty green fields and chickens clucking underfoot. And if youâ(TM)re an Austen reader you can have an okay time just playing I-Spy Pride and Prejudice...
Faster and, if possible, furiouser than its predecessors.

movie_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Molière is as much about the making of a patroness as it is about the gestation of artistic form, for it's she who eggs on the callow playwright to reinvent comedy as serious business with a powerful moral core.

[Director] Trank is so busy fashioning [Wiesenthal] as a superhero that little light is shed on the man's relentlessness and his stubborn determination to keep his data center in Vienna even under siege from a shabby Austrian smear campaign.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

They go at it with such beguiling gusto and heart that I totally bought the movie's dust-covered message about the primacy of friendship over sexual preference.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ...the most ravishingly atmospheric movie I've seen all year. This is not primarily a look-at-my-gizmos dog-and-pony show, though Boyle does amazing things with light to create a self-contained world trapped in space.

This is more suffering than should be asked of anyone to endure, but with admirable perversity, Jonroy decided to make a romantic comedy based on the love between an American Jew and a Kurdish Muslim woman whom the writer-director met in Paris.

Maybe there's nothing more to say and American cinema has finally exhausted its ragging on the most maligned decade of the 20th century.

movie_review_blurb: Warm, playful and inventive.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

The best kiddie picture of the season -- and, along with Ratatouille, of the year.

movie_review_blurb: Don't imagine that you'll find much beyond lip service to serious public debate in this slick thriller.

Fascinating.

movie_review_blurb: Relaxed and goofy in Dave, A Fish Called Wanda and a host of other comedies, Kevin Kline has an endearing way of subverting his own grandee impulses when he's being funny. Give the actor a dramatic role, though, and he comes on all Shakespeare in the Park.

Shifting from the original's focus on the experiences of Greg Heffley (Zachary Gordon) at the ignored-runt end of middle school to domestic tyranny at the hands of his bullying big brother (Devon Bostick, a fledgling Jeff Goldblum) is ill-advised.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though this graceful film is a minor addition to the canon of Middle Eastern cinema in which nothing and everything happens, Bal is still a beauty.

movie_review_blurb: The movie, which won the Golden Bear at the 2009 Berlin Film Festival, is littered with unforgettable images of incongruity, destruction, and, finally, healing.

movie_review_blurb: If there's a takeaway for audiences today, it's a sad one of lessons ignored or flouted after half a century of global mass murder.

One way or another, there will be blood.
Virsi sharpens the sentimentality of the emotional setup to a nicely serrated edge.
movie_title: The First Beautiful Thing (La prima cosa bella) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Witherspoon makes an incongruously squeaky Marlena, and it doesn't help that Pattinson is about as ardently expressive as a log of wood trying to pass itself off as James Dean.
