Holland is properly unsparing about the casual sadism of the German military, but she resolutely sidesteps the sentimental oppressor-victim division that distorts so much pop-Holocaust narrative today.
The sympathetic feature debut of a young Inupiat filmmaker, Andrew Okpeaha MacLean.
The hipster moment may have faded fast through repression and attrition, but in Todorovsky's reading, it was crucially formative on today's Russian youth.

Turn the movie this way, and it's a police procedural that's tragicomically heavy on minutiae while slyly suggesting that official evidence always lies. Turn it that way, and it's an existential fairy tale set in a nocturnal netherworld.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Dwelling as much on setbacks and hurdles as on the glitter of competition, this quietly absorbing film is finally more about character formation -- curiosity, persistence, endurance -- than about achievement as a means to some extrinsic social end.
A confidently spooky indie debut.
An achingly tender chamber piece from first-time director Andrew Haigh.
Prom is a good-hearted, perfectly watchable bonbon about adolescents with little on their minds besides who will ask or be asked to the graduation night shindig.

In The Beaver, a stately family drama with a black comedy struggling to break free from within, Mel Gibson deploys a seemingly magical hand puppet -- plus more charm than he's allowed out in public in years.
The warring impulses within Wiig set a wonderfully skittish tone for the painfully hilarious new movie Bridesmaids, a screwy tale of female friendship and wedding planning from hell.
A sweet and lively story, and a nicely packaged new outing from a past master who has done little more than repeat himself for at least two decades.
Neither fish nor fowl, Larry Crowne skitters between pathos and shtick, wasting abundant acting talent as it goes.
Marsh never speaks on or off camera, but his editing of the testimony makes clear his belief that in trying to make Nim more human, his teachers made themselves less so.
There's very little personal dirt in Sarah Palin: You Betcha! that wouldn't be upstaged by Joe McGinniss' recent Palin tell-all.

The script groans beneath a mass of symbolic winking and declamatory exposition that has the unfortunate effect of turning the villagers into credulous simpletons, ready to blow with any wind that carries them.
While my neighbor had used up her hankie supply by the end of the movie, I left dry-eyed and disappointed.
No popular storyteller ever went broke stoking the undying female fantasy that if a good woman puts her mind to it, a heel can always be brought to heel.
All this paranoid flim-flam drains energy away from the staggering, if far less cinematic, fact that Markopolos was ignored, not targeted.
The movie drowns the deeper questions it raises in a sadistic procedural, an endless circular motion of fight scenes whose only justification is themselves.

More than most documentaries on the subject, Where Soldiers Come From builds a world for these young men and watches it turn upside down, reframing itself slowly and painfully around the unforeseen consequences of snap decisions.
In the chick-flick world, hell is other women, and here specifically it's the stay-at-home wife and mother.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like many an ambitious novice, director Mike Cahill has stuffed every movie he ever wanted to make, every cockamamie parallel he wanted to draw, into his feature debut. I salute his guts and passion, and his imaginatively careless way with genre.

Eric Merola, a former art director of commercials, is either unusually credulous, or doesn't understand the difference between a documentary and an advertisement, or has an undisclosed relationship with the subject of his allegedly nonfiction first film.
Call Lovely, Still life-affirming if you must, but its uplift is designed less to reassure than to honor the difficult process of how we deal when faced with the loss of those we have loved.
Breathless makes alienation look like it was a lot more fun in 1960 than in the ponderous gravitas or ante-upping brutality of indie film today.
One of the best of a new breed of indigenous movies prying open the Pandora's box of German suffering in World War II.
movie_title: Anonyma - Eine Frau in Berlin (A Woman in Berlin) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else, Homecoming should effectively squelch any movie-star ambition on the part of Mischa Barton, though the camera is more than usually attentive to her cleavage.
The laid-back charm of Daniels and Graham's bumpy courtship gives the movie a much-needed edge of idiosyncrasy.

The Cove is properly enchanting, horrifying, and rousing, but it comes dangerously close to making the narcissistic case that dolphins deserve to be saved because they're cute and breathe air like we do.

Sarah Jessica Parker is now 45 years old, and, frankly, I cannot stomach another moment of the simpering, mincing, hair-tossing, eyelash-batting little-girl shtick she's been pulling ever since she emerged...

Other than Rose Byrne's on-screen radiance and a soothingly warm palette lit by cinematographer Seamus Tierney, there's not much to get passionate about in this amiable chamberpiece from theater director Max Mayer.
Celebratory but clear-eyed.
Davidson weaves deeper questions of who a Jew is into this powerful tale of a clan shredded by the rage and hatred passed down through three generations.
The Rashevski Tango begins and ends with a burial, but the movie teems with cranky life.
It hurts to see a terrific cast (including the lovely and intelligent young Irish actress Romola Garai as the couple's quietly seething daughter) squandered on such dreary filmmaking.
There's little in this pointless rehash to distract audiences from the pleasure of watching Tamblyn, a fine young actress whose direct, grownup stare belies her baby features.
Though overwrought in its early scenes, the movie quickly settles into an intelligently faithful rendering of a calling to account, whose visceral power and political implications need no hyping.
[A] scattershot, lazy slice of agitprop, which recycles Moore's usual slice-and-dice job on corporations, while bobbing a curtsey to the current crisis.
The production notes are larded with the Coen Brothers' disclaiming protestations of affection for their hapless characters, but make no mistake: We're being invited to share in their disgust.
The thriving subgenre of immigrant displacement dramedy gets a confident new spin from Cherien Dabis.

With the right attitude this cheerfully calculated effort to update the old girl for a tween market can be enjoyed in all its endearing awfulness, as a loony High School Musical with posher accents and a lot more going on upstairs.
There's no breathing life into a formula that ought to have bowed out gracefully while the going was good.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If you think it's impossible to underestimate the cultural significance of American Idol, go see British filmmaker Havana Marking's documentary about its Afghani imitator.
A highly entertaining evisceration and celebration of the milieu.
[The film's] hauntingly slow rhythms underscore the immanent violence and impotent rage that cripple already attenuated lives.
Empty Nest comes thickly and pleasurably detailed with the minutiae of domesticity.

Hard on the heels of the acclaimed Gomorrah, Italian corruption gets a much quieter but equally vigorous workout in Paolo Sorrentino's highly stylized portrait of the country's most enduring political leader.
Foxx and Downey's disciplined duet come close to redeeming The Soloist from its visual excesses.
Kim is deft and sensitive with her tiny co-stars, but Treeless Mountain lacks the freshness and surprise of In Between Days.
Vardalos calls her film "the ultimate indie experiment," and if that's what is meant by ham-fisted pacing, writing, and acting, this is as ultimate and as indie as it gets.
The movie clips along, tricked out with state-of-the-art hardware and a hotter, brighter partner for Hanks.
Stephan Elliott's deliciously cheeky screen adaptation of one of the satirist's lesser-known jabs at the British upper crust will charm your pants off.
Departures is built for simplicity, and, if nothing else, the appeal to decency and integrity of this sweetly old-fashioned tale make it a must for Bernie Madoff's prison Netflix queue.
Laila's Birthday is beautifully shot and overlaid with a spare, lyrical score that lends rueful emphasis to Masharawi's exasperated fidelity to a chronically malfunctioning city.
Lyrical but bracing.
A pleasantly undistinguished pudding.

Not even the momentary participation extraordinaire of a vertically challenged famous filmmaker self-exiled from the United States can save this phony pseudo-drama from its final collapse into a heap of inconsequence and male vanity.
A roller coaster of alternating hope and despair.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ross is very good at teasing out the politics behind Kasztner's shifting fortunes, not to mention his murky ambitions. But closure is the last thing that's needed here.

Of all European nations, Denmark enjoys the nearest thing to a heroic record of resisting the Nazi occupiers -- which adds both poignancy and punch to Ole Christian Madsen's fact-based drama about two posthumously honored Danes.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Workmanlike, but enormously moving.
Untidy, despairing, oddly exhilarating.

"American radical" may be a misnomer for an intellectual whose life, thought, and rhetoric have been forcefully shaped by a mother whose concentration-camp experience turned her into a fiery booster for every available underdog.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A stale vibe is only one of the problems pervading Erik Gandini's documentary about the pathological symbiosis between unregulated media control and celebrity mania in Italy.
There's a secret busting out of Cindy Kleine's documentary about her parents' long and -- depending on whom she talks to -- unhappy marriage, but it's a pretty banal one.
The Good Guy suffers from the dreary want of imagination about the specificity of twentysomething life that has sunk so many other specimens of this battered genre.
Flowery meadows, wafting dandelion clocks, packs of baying wolves -- all are grist for the film's palette of beauty.
Opper doesn't angle for a climactic group hug, but she sticks around long enough to allow us to exhale while this intelligent young woman begins to set herself, quite literally, back on track.
The young director Tze Chun is not a flashy filmmaker, but he understands the vulnerability of immigrant workers in the sleazy sub-rosa economies of a floundering 21st-century America.
The only whiff of passion comes from the sadistic care that has gone into putting garish clothes and makeup on the mother, which give her the ghoulish air of Jeanne Moreau in a fun-house mirror.
This spirited film sustains its momentum as a tale of powerless women uniting to take back control of their destinies.
movie_title: Le Chant des Mariées (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Daniel Barber's lame handwringing about the root causes of youthful alienation forms a thin veneer over the real purpose of this self-important piece of rubbish -- to hold us hostage to the director's bottomless appetite for spurious depravity.
In its roundabout way, this usefully meandering documentary probes the enduring stain of Guantánamo on its victims and on America.
The Father of My Children loses focus and sags into a how-we-got-through-it family procedural.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hansen-Loveâ(TM)s fevered mix of love and resentment toward this man lends urgency and eros to his professional and personal unraveling.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Diary of a Wimpy Kid is sweet and funny at either end, but in between, it sags with endless repetition of gross bodily functions and Greg's torment at the hands of larger, angrier, or more popular kids -- in that order.
For better or worse, there isn't a human experience that French director Andre Techine can resist lathering into a tone poem.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Honestly, it would take several more dimensions to craft something special out of this adequate but unremarkable animated tale.
The movie turns stiff and pat, leaving us manipulated by Arnold's desire to give her hapless heroine the worst life she can think of, followed by a great escape.
Baichwal is the least judgmental of interviewers, which is a double-edged sword when the solemn testimony ("I had come to meet me") induces a barely resistible urge to laugh.
A Christmas Carol is a whiz-bang 3-D thrill-ride with all the emotional satisfaction squeezed out of it.
The result is some nice atmospherics tethered to a cripplingly half-baked existentialism.

The lyrically complicating hand of Mr. Maysles, who shot the film with several collaborators, is everywhere apparent in the way the camera picks a path around coherence, refusing narrative in favor of the thick detail of life unfolding.
Other than a few tasty tidbits, like the fact that he wrote Joseph McCarthy's will while still a young family attorney, there's not much fresh news about William Kunstler in this documentary.

Alone of all the earnest players in this turgidly euphemistic melodrama, Sheen seems to grasp that the only way you can keep a straight face through this choked-up virginity is to carry it way into camp.
Ecstatically fanciful.
Cevin Soling's lively documentary lays out in hair-raising detail the authoritarian underpinnings of America's child-centered culture.
The real drama lies in the sweetly twisted symbiosis between this likable, infuriating wreck of a man and his devoted son and publicist.
Invictus is stately, handsomely mounted, attentive to detail right down to the Marmite adorning the team's breakfast buffet, and relentlessly conventional.
Man, British heritage cinema can be dull when assembly-lined for the export market.

It's not entirely Thomas's fault: What are you going to do with those fat-cheeked, helium-voiced singing critters but slap together enough "awwww" moments to make the toddlers happy and enough knowing winks to keep parental bums in the seats?
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Gilliam and McKeown's willful refusal of coherent narrative and determination to pack every idea about art they ever had into one scenario, make this fiendishly gorgeous movie more exhausting than exhilarating to watch.
[A] terrific documentary about end-times evangelical Christians.

This workmanlike adaptation of Jay Parini's novel about Tolstoy's last days, adapted and directed by Michael Hoffman, settles into a lushly scenic television drama, though with dialogue strangely located somewhere in the 1950s.
A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night is a delectable, atmospheric creation, a lush dreamscape that we fall into, captivated and elevated.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wachtel initially wrote the script for TV, and it shows -- long-term plot lines are teased at, only to be swiftly resolved without the chance to play out.
Arterton is captivating as Gemma, but Luchini steals the film as the magnifique Joubert, his lust for Gemma often rendered innocent (or impotent) by his wonderful, Buster Keaton-esque deadpan face.
Indie darling Lee Toland Krieger has managed to pull off this high concept film with an innocent charm that harks back to Golden Age Hollywood romance.
Simons is intriguing, but the warmth and charm of the seamstresses carry the film.

Gibson is successful in illuminating the constant struggles of a user and the lasting impact drugs have on one's life, though the film does drag at times and can abruptly shift from subject to subject, disrupting the narrative flow.

Even I, a self-prescribed horror movie skeptic, found myself wrapped up in Morgan - I was invested in the characters, I (mostly) bought into the plot and even found myself embracing some of the gore by the end.
The overall stunning nature of the work cannot be ignored.
The film's real triumph is in how accurately it captures the intricacies of human relationships, especially when tested.
It manages to be heartwarming and heartbreaking all at once.
By the time it reaches its abrupt ending, the only emotion audiences might be left with is boredom.
The Innocents is a powerful, brave film that will stay with you for days.
Classic Christmas TV special is sing-along fun.
Macaulay Culkin v. Mouse King in NYC Ballet treat.
Tween brew: Witchy fun, a pinch of fright.
Concoction of magical fun and fright for tweens.
A big, Harry family adventure full of laughs.
Female superhero can't save this '80s clunker.
Racy college comedy has heart; OK for older teens.
Pacino's intense performance best for older teens.
Fab small-town spoof; subtle humor may bore kids.
Clean, tween hip hop; great dancing, lame script.
movie_title: Hip Hop Kidz - It's A Beautiful Thing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film shows the grueling work it takes for young dancers like Zamora to look effortless on stage, and First Position shows teachers who range from supportive to borderline abusive.
Buirski takes us on an emotional journey, although the start may seem slow to people unfamiliar with the ballet world or Le Clercq's story.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are few titles and no interviews or narration. Entire scenes go by without anyone speaking. Instead, Ballet 422 is a very intimate look at the process.
We barely get to know the children or see much of their dancing. By the time the winner of the competition is announced, it is not much of a surprise, and there is little emotional payout.

Mercifully free of Danny Dyer cameos or Guy Ritchie mockneyisms, this works as both an entertaining gangster thriller and a hard-hitting piece of social realism. Absorbing, moving and authentic, Shifty never once strikes a false note.
Hand-drawn and watercoloured, the animation is as sublime as a stained-glass window.
We can't wait to see what Goldthwait does next.

With a face as impassively beautiful as the landscape she trudges through, Ree Dolly is a heroine you won't forget. Tenacious and stoic, she holds her own in a vernacular that's equal parts hillbilly and hard-boiled.
Without a compelling plot to hold our attention, this only amounts to an impressively bloody bullet-a-thon: 22 seems a very conservative estimate...
Baaria is like a pleasant package holiday: alfresco dinners, strolls through lemon orchards.
Skillfully pitched at its market, this is joyful in a way only the professionally grumpy (dads, film critics) could object to.
Motherhood is neither insight nor escapism. It's a yummy-mummy newspaper column splurged onto celluloid, like baby sick on your best cashmere sweater.

Golden Age Hollywood charm with the obligatory modern Hollywood schmaltz thrown in, this will rile anyone who's been within 100 miles of the real Ireland, but run with it and it's an enjoyable fantasy all the same.
The combined effect is amiable rubbish embodied by Dyer, who continues to walk a tightrope between laughing stock and national treasure.
Vardalos' peppy charm and the postcard scenery make for pleasant diversions, but there's no getting away from the script's mawkishness.
A psychedelic, sepia-toned horror show, touring the dark corners of his mind and those of the white trash world in which he lives.
Away We Go is the cinematic equivalent of Innocent smoothies: it appears to talk like 'us', while all the time reducing us to another consumer demographic.
Whether your nine-year-old niece will care about that is moot - but she'll definitely resent the poor ratio of musical numbers to clunky, contrived emotional scenes.

It's impossible to capture the complex whole of a person in one movie (or novel), but Miller uses this limitation to her advantage, by making the mystery of Pippa Lee's true identity the heart of the film.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's got all the heart and humour of a mainstream comedy-drama, with none of the tedious predictability.

A slasher for the Twitter generation, Tormented catches the spirit of the times without being too try-hard. Quips and snogging take precedence over scares, but its commentary on new technology's power to intimidate is chillingly apt.
Director Ole Christian Madsen has opted rather to make a kind of action thriller-meets-film noir hybrid, and yet visually, at least, it works.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You'll be very glad you were invited because this is a friendly, unpretentious bash, with not a meringue dress in sight. The speeches are funny, the music is ace and the mood falls just the right side of sentimental mushiness.
The Kevin Smith-esque dude banter might place Dick in a US indie tradition, but there's also an honesty to the script and performances that's genuinely original and touching.
Like Ozon's 8 Women, the costumes are magnificent and Angel's mansion is a shrine to the gods of bad taste. All that's missing is a heroine worthy of Bette Davis in her heyday.
It's all just filler between the dance scenes, which are admittedly fun. Think Pussycat Dolls with slightly more clothes on. Unrepentantly formulaic, but enjoyable all the same.
By the end you'll feel like a bored parent trapped in the front row of the school play.
Instead of an exciting big-screen debut, this feels like a Cold Feet episode, written by a fan of Brief Encounter. Duff deserves a bigger challenge.
This kind of thing has been done before and it's been done better, too.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In a choice between traditional and safe and experimental and flawed, opt for the latter every time.
Avoid like you would a naked nutter bouncing down the street.
Unfortunately, as director Michel Spinosa has discovered, making a Fatal Attraction-esque thriller that's also a serious study of mental illness is a lot harder than it sounds.
Every frame shouts, "save the planet!" louder than a roaring pride of Kalahari lions - and when you've seen the film, you'll know just how loud that is.

Harrelson is an entertaining mix of Old South camp and quiet pathos but neither he nor the script's desultory attempts at post-9/11 commentary are enough to elevate it above the level of a pretentious John Grisham adaptation.
It's jolly stuff, yet for all the bawdy banter, there's a Boat That Rocked-like sense of a genuinely interesting moment being regurgitated as a cuddly sitcom.
All buzz, colour and sublime jazz, Chico & Rita is an instant design classic -- and cracking cinema too.
You wouldn't think a film could actually be both very boring and very offensive. Pimp is that paradox made flesh
The pupils' failure to question their fate plays more like lethargy than tragically repressed emotion.
Where Suicide Squad's Big Bad should be there is only a Big Narrative Hole.
In Doctor Who, an end is always a beginning, and so it was with Mark Gatiss's cleverly resonant script.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The trouble with these physics documentaries: the more you learn, the less you understand.
If anyone can make you sympathise with affluent LA yuppies, Rashida Jones can.
It's impossible to be bored by a story this good, especially with that cast.
Cotillard's performance is primed for awards, while Schoenaerts is a rough diamond.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Aided by committed, awards-ready performance, The Sessions transforms 'taboo' subject matter into a humorous, humane and uncomplicated pleasure.
A feelgooder spiced by social conscience, this is one of those underdog productions with potential to punch well above its weight. Go on, give it a chance.
It might not be a massive hit, but it will certainly ease a few paths through the awkwardness of adolescence.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Despite stand-out moments both epic and intimate, Clint's latest is a film about death that's likely to put many audiences to sleep.
Fine turns from Streep and Jones bedrock this compassionate, quietly subversive drama.
If you can ignore the disturbing parallels with recent events, this middle-aged, Middle-American Attack The Block raises a laugh.
Ultimately, we remain unconvinced of Step Up's anti-capitalist credentials. Especially after that hilariously inept Nike plug in the final scene.
The time is ripe for a great Ken Loach film. If only Ken Loach was up for making one.
An awful ensemble comedy to complete that Valentine's Day / New Year's Eve box-set, complete with sexist clichés.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Not only has director Christian Petzold assembled a fascinating hill of beans, but there's a moonlit scene that almost alone justifies his Silver Bear win at Berlin.
Sandler's brash, unpretentious and unsubtle family comedy might be more enjoyable if it wasn't so mean.
Grown-ups will still struggle not to picture a post-puberty sequel featuring DUIs and rehab trips.
This is the terminal illness weepie for people who don't watch terminal illness weepies, and it's much the better for it.
Agent Cody Banks meets post-shark jump 24, with what appears to be an 8-year-old Soviet body builder in the lead role.
A cleverer script could have made its point and remained tactfully agnostic, but it's still amusing to see mumblecore's trademark naturalism leavened by some old-fashioned movie magic.
Enjoyably racy though it is, What's Your Number? racks up zero surprises. Faris fans awaiting a role to do her justice will have to wait a little longer.
Friends with Kids takes an unusual romantic premise and explores it in satisfying and perceptive depth.
Robust, does the job, but unrefined.
A tasty line-up, but a nihilistic tone and lacklustre script make for a fast-food action-comedy that's diverting but throwaway.
If you see only one casual-sex-com featuring a Black Swan alumni this year, make sure it's this one.
The sunniest, happiest film in the world - and if the under-10 in your life can't appreciate that, it might be time to put them up for adoption.
Capturing the energy of club culture on screen is notoriously difficult. This stale production shouldn't even have tried.
More Harold And Maude than Marley & Me; amusing, insightful and a little perverse.
After the millionth lingering shot of a cave wall, you may be less enthused, but this is still a worthwhile trip.
Smart and sly, funny and fourth-wall-breaking... but above all, an excruciatingly accurate coming-of-ager.
The characters are based on stock clichés, and the attempt to complicate the story only defies credibility.
If you are a football fan, if you love the UAE, or if you enjoy films that champion the human spirit, this film is for you.
[A] more-thoughtful -than-average film.
You could watch a heroine barrel into a messy romance all day, provided that she's a lot less dopey than this, but few of Michele's foibles make us sympathize with her.
movie_title: God Is Great and I'm Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: What's the point of watching if everyone feels like a pawn in a script?
A vivacious-looking, tartly-scored bore of a movie.
Despite a couple of memorable scenes, it's boring when it's not kinky.
Horror movies don't have to make sense in the real world, but when you have to help their internal logic along this much, it's pretty much a cue for heckling -- or checking your watch.
Manny is so uninteresting as a pivotal character that he's a black hole who sucks away our investment in the film.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a watery, undeservedly smug update of the low-budget, kids-stranded- in-the-sticks bloodfests of the 1970s and '80s.
This undermarketed noir suffers because many of its characters don't seem to belong in the same universe.
The film short-hands a lot of stuff, but it's gripping for a while.
It's more likable than it is good. Still, it might leave you feeling romantic (and romantic about your particular city) even if it doesn't nail its case for love in a psychopharmacological age.
A devastating work of pro-doggie propaganda.
Feels a lot like two different Hancock jobs stitched together.
The earnest, low-budget indie Anything But Love isn't quite the movie you'd like it to be, but it provides some kicks, nonetheless.
It's all very mesmerizing, for them and us.
You'll chuckle at least once during the proceedings -- but probably not much more than that.

That's the thing about children when it comes to movies: They're not that discriminating. They can be perilously easy to please, which is why it's important that their parents protect them from films like Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2.
Don't expect the inside scoop so much as an unsatisfying slice of life.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Such a measured primer of talking heads and footage -- a broad, slick Tibet 101 -- that it seems better suited to the classroom than the big screen, despite its Himalayan scenery and rustic colors.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Ambitious but clumsy, it's a movie to appreciate rather than to be engaged by.
Unless you're stumped for a way to commemorate the feast of St. Therese of Lisieux Friday, there's little point in going to see the low-budget, one-star-worthy hagiography, Therese.
It's little better or worse than the original. But, to be honest, the original -- minus its nascent stars -- wasn't very good.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even when Walk on Water doesn't quite have you by the heart, its little fingers fumble around in your brain.
Anyone who feels like they're drowning in their own polluted, godless, reality-TV-choked, errand-ridden consumerist life will find a momentary escape from modernity in The Story of the Weeping Camel.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Feels more like a 'making-of' piece or vanity project for actor and first-time director Robin Shou ... than a tight, thorough documentary.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Engrossing because of its amazingly well-documented milieu, which German-trained writer-director Li Yang filmed on location in the northern provinces.
True fans (i.e., the people who are most likely to buy tickets) probably know a lot of this stuff already, and they might be disappointed by the lack of drama and the brevity of 3-D racing action.
It's a juicy premise, but the enactment is so dumbed-down that you couldn't possibly fault your jaded children for yawning and rolling their eyes.

Much of the movie is devoted to the boys dueling card-to-card. And so most the dialogue, forgive me fans, sounds something like this: "I'm going to thwart your Egyptian God cards with my Rare Metal Dragon card!"
Candelabra shines a light on things that might have occurred, but it never quite illuminates them.
People who never saw (or never much liked) "Everybody Loves Raymond" might not get the specifics. But complaining about people who don't get your jokes? That is universal.
Olivia Harrison's honesty contributes mightily to Scorsese's portrait of an artist more interesting than some of us may have realized.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Stick with this fast-moving, clip-heavy survey course of Steinem's career, and you'll eventually get past the surface stuff.
For me, Mister Magoo's Christmas Carol, which marks its 50th anniversary this week with a Saturday night presentation by NBC -- which hasn't shown it in decades -- will always be my Christmas Carol.
A disturbing documentary about a side of the modeling business that's far from super.
