Anyone expecting a Sleepy Hollow-type chiller is definitely in for disappointment. But if you're in the market for an oblique examination of adulterous/ middle-class guilt delivered in a certain, unfussy style, knock yourself out.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty of larks to be had from a fast-moving fantasy that doesn't take its mythology too seriously and employs actors who don't look like teenage rabbits in headlights.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that posits Billy Ray Cyrus as a techno-genius and allows the baddies to get away with Russian accents that would put most meerkats to shame.
It looks good, jolts often, and moves at a fair lick. And it certainly puts a silver bullet into the puffed-up were-wusses of Twilight.
While a fuel cell or two short of animation's final frontier, Astro Boy capably fills the space between Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius and Wall.E.
As a slice-of-life drama free of melodrama, sentimentality and cliché, Precious is priceless.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For anyone prepared to make the necessary allowances - and there are a lot of them - it's an exhilarating ride. And at the very least, you get to see Gibson back on vengeful form. He's not too old for this s**t yet.
At the end of the day, it's okay. But when it comes to animation from Disney, 'okay' is a bit of a let-down.
With the messages about friendship, loyalty and the all-too-fleeting nature of childhood already striking the perfect emotional chord, the 3D treatment simply deepens the visual experience.

It's this unpredictability that makes A Prophet so gripping. The time also flies thanks to the brilliant editing, Audiard expertly changing gear from quiet introspection to scenes as pulsating as any Hollywood thriller.
Just because an outlaw pays his debt to society, it doesn't make him a hero.
Like. Poke. Share.
Drop dead Fred. Seriously.
There's no denying the humanity of Leigh's films, good and bad. Another Year is another fine example. But like so many of his characters, it rather overstays its welcome.

Guided by the native wit and instinct of Brazilian director Saldanha, the (3D) action soars between the rooftops and party-crowded streets to the surrounding cliffs and jungles with barely any drop in tempo.
Brand improvises his way out of duller spots, but while the man-child shtick is fine in small doses, stretched over a couple of hours, it gets rather trying.
Somehow, Lim manages to keep you pinned to the passenger seat for over two gas-guzzling hours - with no perceptible drop in testosterone levels.
Hanna's not always on target, but you shouldn't take your eyes off her.
At best, Priest is a passable time-waster. Mostly, it's like watching an extended Gorillaz video.
Much like Sean Penn's Into The Wild, it's a heartfelt quest and not without its rewards.
It's definitely not far from Cliché Central. But if you're looking for Credibility Street, you'll soon get lost.
Whether you care about her characters or not (and you won't), Tadjedin does at least keep you guessing as to who will take the moral high ground come the end.
A stir-fry of visual and verbal treats to please every palate.
It's depressing to think that anyone might actually enjoy this heartless, soulless and witlessly exploitative trash.
It's a comic-book cocktail for happy hour, a shot of quick-release gratification designed to give you a buzz from a top shelf of generic brands.

While using a comical device to explore a serious subject, Foster clearly wants to go darker and deeper, striving to draw parallels between the bonding of the kindred teens and Walter's increasingly disturbing psychotic split.
Ghosted is not out to set any benchmarks. But despite its more modest ambitions, nobody's going to shove it around.
A 91-minute warning to give this generation something to worry about.
A sharp and compelling mind-bender that goes easy on the gobbledygook.
How often do you leave the multiplex pondering the universe and your place in it? Consider it a unique workout for your popcorn-bloated brain.
This is no light-hearted spoof. It's 100% grindhouse. Which, for the most part and by definition, simply makes it trash.
In a genre where the expectation of violence is so high, rare is the film that manages to shock and startle with such regularity.
Ironic that Cars continues to be Pixar's most underpowered juggernaut - but you have to admire the body work.
Pitched somewhere between Ken Loach's Bread and Roses and the Hallmark Channel, it's solid, issue-of-the-week stuff.
If it's a choice between this and mucking-out duty, pass the shovel.
There are times during this bare-knuckle brawlathon that you really fear for the safety of documentarian Ian Palmer.
Worthy and tasteful but rarely convincing and increasingly dull, Sarah's Key should open the door on more closeted skeletons than it does.
Wyatt does a remarkable job of transferring the low-budget grip of his (literally) breakout flick The Escapist to the free-wheeling spirit of the summer blockbuster.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing yet ineffably sad, what emerges is not the story of an ape who failed to be human, but a story of human failings.
Writer and director take us on a self-indulgently drawn-out journey through the eyes of a dead fish down numerous dramatic dead ends...
Upholding franchise traditions in amusingly grisly style, the Reaper's latest round-up is definitely up to snuff.
With no sense of humour and long lulls between action, director Megaton appears primarily concerned with coming up with as many different ways as possible of getting Saldana down to her skimpies.
While showing a healthy disregard for romantic comedies, director Will Gluck's follow-up to his equally raunchy sleeper smash Easy A is essentially When Harry Met Sally for the i-generation.

Despite using a limited palette of earth tones and cold metals, there's a satisfying richness and depth to his CG world. Against unforgiving and ominous backdrops, the characters emerge with genuine soul.
Just another squelchy but unscary ritual of blood, guts and generic mumbo-jumbo.
It's a lip-smacking piece of action burlesque, pulling one surprise after another from its splendidly filled fishnets. Like any good sucker punch, you don't see it coming.
Bored? Lack of wish-fulfilment in your life? Take Limitless for quick, over-the-counter relief.
It's best approached like a buddy movie with gold standards. Because, by Jupiter, it's the rapport between Tatum and Bell that lifts The Eagle beyond any derring-do.
The gags come thick and fast. Literally.
Visually and musically: smokin'. Dramatically: no cigar.
It's a buttock-clenching ride, even though stringing out some of the early potential disasters would have made it tenser still.

As ever, Rapace steals every scene she's in, maintaining Lisbeth's moody enigma whether she's lying on her sick bed, making a memorable court entrance in full punk regalia, or taking care of family business.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The trouble with Rodriguez is that, while full of ideas, he sometimes struggles to balance quantity with quality. For all its manic action, Machete feels strained and oddly familiar.
Don't put money on it.
So thickly does Perry lay on the sanctimony and self-pity, you begin to wonder if it's all a spoof. Stick a Wayans brother in there and you could call it Tragic Movie.
Pretty stars in exotic settings with a hint of excitement and an air of mystery. Ah, Salt by Chanel.
Far-fetched yet inescapably engrossing and often seat-squeezingly tense, The Next Three Days is rip-roaring guff.
Thanks to Reeves' co-stars and a little Chekhovian inspiration at the end, the film just about gets away with it.
For those who can face love stories without studio-sanctioned happy ever afters, here's compelling proof that the tide of slush does not flow unopposed.
This is the sort of set-up that would have been perfectly nailed in a single episode of Friends.

With Portman's dance moves as convincing as her descent into derangement and Kunis also hitting a career high as her minxy opposite, here's a trip to the ballet that won't fail to sort the men from the boys.
It's a bittersweet pill. But with fluid direction from Richard J. Lewis and Giamatti in mesmerising form, Barney's medicine is remarkably easy to take.
As well as driving the story, the themes of loyalty and trust also give the script its richest vein of humour.
[A] painfully protracted mix of doomed love and mild toilet humour...
This is a story about guts: having 'em, trusting 'em, spilling 'em.
A colourful distraction for kids and a pleasant dip in the ocean for those with a few more knobbles on their shell.
Though Allen has never been exactly feelgood, his previously endearing pessimism has given way to a mean-spiritedness that here borders on misanthropy.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, this is one film for which empathy - and thus interest - will be proportional to your salary.
Battle: LA is perfect cinema for gamers.
The unconnected stories allow Evans to dwell on past and future, and dwell is what he does.
The walls are awash with mashed heads, gouting wounds, split torsos and burnt flesh. It's like being put in the stocks and pelted with raw offal.
It certainly gives the nippers their slapstick fix. Sadly, the only sense of wonder it will stir in their parents is when it will all end.
Not many animated escapades aim to please such a broad audience. Even the poo jokes are sophisticated.
None of your Lock, Stock larks or one-last-job capers here, just a compelling story of low life in the suburbs.
Its heart is definitely in the right place. But there's more to comedy than funny accents. And daubing on Eastern profundities like lumpy henna won't cover the cracks.
A remarkable testament to working class lives and the unifying power of art, Waste Land is a rare thing - a film that makes you proud to be human.
Like Hattie Mae herself, this franchise is just cliché and padding.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Ever been so starved of entertainment you've tried to see how far you can push a pencil into your ear before hitting your eardrum?
As well as adding colour to the characters, the animation nicely captures the textures of the backyard which in turn bring an engaging simplicity to some of the cuter sight gags.
Anyone looking for fresh roadkill really won't find much to slow down for. That said, there's enough screech and splatter to keep your average Friday night rubbernecker happy.
Wes Anderson has come up with the liveliest adventure set on English soil since Wallace and Gromit ran into the were-rabbit.
Even if one or two things don't add up come the final twist, you're still in for a jittery hour.
Like the cartoons of Monty Python, the results are weirdly inspired and fitfully amusing but mostly unfathomable. Such is the delirium of Doctor Gilliam.
With all the meaty goodness of Neil Marshall's Dog Soldiers, The Cottage offers solid Brit-horror nourishment.

With a fondness for reflective surfaces and long takes, Hou picks up an everyday situation, observes it from various angles, gives it a gentle shake, then puts it down again, seemingly without comment.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A morality tale with a distictly Coen-ish air, making excellent, occasionally surreal, use of a great location and lacing the comedy with bloody unpleasantness. It even has a quirky score by Coen collaborator Carter Burwell.

You can almost see the writers (Ellroy, Kurt Wimmer - creator of sci-fi mish-mash Ultraviolet - and first-timer Jamie Moss) charging at one another with false antlers in a challenge to come up with the toughest soundbite.
Save the effort by asking the neighbours if you can come round for ten minutes every night for a week. A wet week. Before pay day.
In terms of originality, this Mummy is dead on its feet. And no matter what their nationality, everyone struggles with the generally awful dialogue.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps a shade too long to hold the youngest viewers in permanent thrall, this is a family film in the truest sense - only the grouchiest bear won't find something to like.
This awesomely unambitious film has all the depth of a Pepsi ad.

Though every shot is painstakingly framed and perfectly lit, the film fails at the human level. These people remain strangers throughout. There is nothing wrong with the performances but it's difficult to create empathy without intimacy.
Unless you're fourteen and female, look away now. There's absolutely nothing for you here.
Arty-farty, cheap and dreary, Edo Bertoglio's post-mortem of New York's Seventies creative in-crowd is exactly the sort of self-absorbed guff that makes people glad to be square.
Yet while it's as novel as a second-hand ejector seat and hits the groin more often than the funnybone, Get Smart still registers enough clicks on the giggle counter to make its mission passable.
Meadows is adamant that there was no corporate influence. But even without the benefit of the doubt, it can't be denied that his extended short carries some sweet observations.
He does, however, leave the door open for a sequel. But who'd want to clone a runt?
With too much talk, not enough adventure and a laughable disregard for geography and anthropology, 10,000 BC is less Jurassic Park than Pleistocene parp.

Yet as Ferrell and Reilly babble, yell, and clobber themselves silly in the (fruitless) pursuit of laughs over 97 excruciating minutes, anyone who manages to complete this moronic marathon with them deserves a medal.
From ballrooms to bedrooms, we've seen it all before. And while familiarity doesn't necessarily breed contempt, it does have a habit of nudging the snooze button.
Dispiriting and unpleasant, a trip to Eden Lake will leave most viewers feeling the need for a hot shower and a tetanus jab.

Bleak surroundings and grim humour create a suitably sombre mood, but in the wake of juicy police procedurals like Dennis Lehane adaptations Mystic River and Gone Baby Gone, this is disappointingly straightforward stuff.
Pleasingly, there are no cosy resolutions here; it's up to the viewer to decide each character's fate. Want a happy ending? Work for it.
David Mamet sets him on the path to righteousness in a collection of contrivances masquerading as a meaningful plot.

With dialogue as convincing as power-sharing talks in Zimbabwe, characters so two-dimensional they'd be drummed out of a comic strip, and a hero who makes Jack Bauer look like a dithering idiot, Taken is hands down the unintentional comedy of the year.
Veracity and mordant humour are all well and good, but Seidl treads a very fine line between making jokes about being sick and making sick jokes.
Middling family fare, Ember too often smoulders when it needs to fire.
Beastie Boy Adam Yauch's basketball diary is of limited general appeal.
Without Anna Faris - undoubtedly the best thing in Scary Movies - this would be just another superficial wheeze about the perils of superficiality.
But while the gravity-defying creations, tonsorial trickery and intricate braidwork impress, the film is remarkably drab.
Burn After Reading is a clown-mobile; a comical death-trap constructed from lots of disposable parts.

Igor is a bit of a Franken-toon itself, stitching grown-up gags to a Disneyfied storyline (beauty is on the inside; don't step on others to get ahead; yada yada yada) while lurching wildly from one age group to the other.
Essentially covering the same playlist as Jack Black's School of Rock, The Rocker is a good-natured, live-the-dream lark in which the one-liners score hits but the slapstick continually misses.
Ludicrous? Occasionally. Ponderous? Frequently. But dangerous? Only for the careers of Cage and his stylist.
As daft as it all becomes, Vantage Point is never dull. Approach it like a double-bill of 24 and there's enough excitement to overcome the clichés, particularly during the climactic car chase.
Worthy of thine attention? Corset is.

According to the Ferrell method, the art of comedy characterisation is to put on a straight face (daft hairstyle optional), bellow the first thing that comes to mind (rude words optional), race around like a child on a sugar rush... and repeat.
While Zeta-Jones and Eckhart make an appealing couple, their chemistry never really develops due to the script's complete lack of sauce.
1408 is the best King conversion since Misery.
With smashing performances and plenty of heart, it joins Bobcat Goldthwait's recent Sleeping Dogs as a worthy addition to 2007's woof-and-ready hall of fame.
By the end, many will be outraged by the sheer irresponsibility of it all. The rest will be too busy laughing.
3:10 to Yuma builds up a full head of steam and sustains it.
Bullets through umbilical cords, shootouts during sex and gunfights in gun factories: this is one movie that does exactly what it says on the tin.
Crisply shot by cinematographer David Connell, the South Australian locations offer a nostalgic, golden glow to proceedings. Sadly, the characters inspire little sense of wonder.
Finding humanity amidst inhumanity, A Mighty Heart is sobering proof that the most frightening horror stories come from the real world. Every day.

Ladies and gentlemen, Quentin Tarantino presents Death Proof: another feature-length gimmick that chokes two screamingly good action sequences in a smog of self-indulgent, self-referential, self-satisfied flatulence.

Recycling ideas and characters from 250 years of romantic literature without adding any new ones of its own, Evening is like dining with Jane Austen and Barbara Cartland and not being allowed to get down from the table.
A meticulous killer with family issues; a cop with problems of her own; secondary murderers on the loose; a plot with unexplored depths - this could have been a decent TV series.
It goes without saying that Rendition is a matter worthy of your utmost attention.

Imagine Time Bandits confined to a boring Berkshire village and drained of colour, and you can see why this pig's ear of Susan Cooper's well-received children's story went belly-up at the US box office.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When people try to make British comedies for American audiences, bad things invariably happen.
The only amusement here comes from counting the imaginary tumbleweeds that so frequently roll across the screen.
If Hollywood is going to insist on broadcasting calls for the world to wake up and smell the coffee, it's time to stop strangling them with the Stars and Stripes.
When Sylvester Stallone's Get Carter is no longer the worst remake of a Michael Caine movie, you have to ask yourself: what's it all about?
Those expecting fresh Squid will be disappointed. With few laughs and much whining, Margot takes the fun out of dysfunctional. It's a damp squib with lots of wail.
A sombre condemnation of US foreign policy, wrapped in an absorbing whodunit.
Burton's best film since Ed Wood will come in handy for anyone in need of something for the weekend.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Naturally, nobody builds suspense like 'The Master', but the appealing team of Lockwood and Redgrave receves sterling back-up from twinkly Dame May and Cecil Parker as the spineless adulterer.
As the author of 'What's Eating Gilbert Grape?', writer-director Hedges knows how to tell a story about kith and kin without smothering it in goo.
Forster takes few liberties with Hosseini's novel: it's a straightforward, anadorned adaptation with the much of the dialogue in Persian and a capable non-starry cast.

Colourful, fizzy and destined to keep the karaoke busy for a few months, the ten musical e-numbers pop between the eyes like wads of overblown bubblegum. Would that they stick in the memory in the same way...
Issues of depth aside, this is as distracting an event movie as there's been all year. But it's the stuff of multiplex, not legend.
Coppola drags everyone on a humourless trudge through a jungle of pretension that will have most moviegoers glazing over long before an ending that really isn't worth the wait.
Schmaltzy musical cues ensure we all get the message, but the desperately dull final third is likely to drive both kids and grown-ups to nose-picking, seat-kicking distraction.
All dilutions aside, director Dahl mixes a dash of Six Feet Under with shots of Mr & Mrs Smith and Grosse Point Blank to put the kick into an enjoyably spiky little cocktail.
While The Golden Compass doesn't have time to clarify all the book's complexities it's as welcome a retreat from this old England as Hogwarts, Narnia or Middle Earth.
Goodwill be stuffed - this is about as appetising as a plateful of reheated sprouts.
A soulless, slackly directed, suspense-free exercise in misanthropy packed with unconvincing stereotypes
Innocence is entirely absent from this extremely dubious addition to the big-screen adventures of Ronald Searle's cartoon creations.
Don't bother looking for wires and safety nets because there aren't any. As the end credits show in wince-making detail, all the performers genuinely suffer for their art.
Take away the Fab Four and the monstrous Metropolitan Cathedral and this could be a post-war chronicle of any northern conurbation; an hour-plus Hovis ad with more broken windows.
Easy on both eye and ear, this jaunty little number has many virtues to commend it.
Despite being second out of the 3D traps after Bolt, their first special-specs-required outing is at least as eye-catching as Pixar's Oscar-nominated pacesetter. Occasionally, it's even better.
Stick two fingers up at the moral majority... then shove them in the High Voltage socket and get ready to have your socks blown off.
Director Waters pulls out the odd cracker, injecting Dickens' timeless story of redemption with a healthy dose of self-awareness.

Extolling the virtues of honesty, decency, friendship and family while portraying capitalism as the root of all evil, this big-screen outing for Disney's latest pop princess is a wholesome treat for her legions of young fans.

Salvation is clearly aimed at a younger audience than its predecessors. The carnage is surprisingly bloodless, there's virtually no cussing and several scenes were clearly conceived with one eye on the PlayStation.
It's always nice to see pros at work. But while there's nothing wrong with unabashed fluff, you'd expect something more substantial from two such seasoned campaigners.
Director Iliadis succeeds by building tension and putting everyone at unease rather than grinding out cheap shocks.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Looking For Eric is his most entertaining film yet, a feelgood, footy-mad gem that takes spectators through several rounds of anguish to a cheer-inducing finale of hope and glory.
With superb planning and execution from Woo, his stuntmen and the backroom boys, the action unfolds like a game of Risk played on the grandest scale.
Loathe to say it, but even after the closing stats about rape and the amount of compensation paid out by the Vatican, Beyond The Fire has little more resonance than a Madonna video.
It's clear that there isn't enough imagery to cover the narrative. This is a 50-minute radio programme stuck in 90 minutes of pixels.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With a script of pure gibberish stitching the pieces together, it's as though Ed Wood Jr, Clive Barker and Hieronymous Bosch had too much absinthe one night and decided to make a home movie.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not particularly well-rounded then, but any film that gives voice to the oppressed while raising global awareness has got to be a good thing.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Adam provides a welcome explanation of why some folk seem queerer than others.

Collet-Serra manages to sustain tension throughout, prudently deploying his jumps and jolts and pumping up the grue factor. So while it often prompts hoots of derision, they're often choked off with a vice-tight wince.

Optimistic and constantly amusing, the Yes Men are a force for the good. That, plus the knowledge that many of those free marketeering goons will have been crushed in the credit crunch, makes this a guilt-edged pleasure.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is just a giant slurp of cinematic Sunny D, quenching the thirst for instant fun with CGI sweeteners and a fast-acting concoction of other slapstick additives.
Favouring character and atmosphere over flamboyant technique, this is as focused, balanced and compelling a war drama as you're likely to see.
While Vardalos does her big fat best to keep it fresh, the duff characters and uninspired direction make Greece look as appealing as a week-old kebab.
Love's film is ultimately pointless, having nothing new to say on the issues of male bonding, acceptance and tribalism.

Small wonder this hard-to-swallow cocktail of bawdy comedy, cross-cultural romance and issue-of-the-week melodrama was left on the shelf for three years. The marketing people can't have had a clue what to do with it.
Sweet and sometimes sharp but never bitter, this is a heartwarming work of refreshing geniality.
With plotholes you could drive a snowplough through and as eventful as an Antarctic winter, Whiteout is less a whodunit than a getonwithit.
These are private people whose every careworn expression tells a story. It's during their silences that we see the real, human cost of progress.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wisely, Mottola doesn't try to reinvent the comedy wheel. He's simply taken the plot-free route of Superbad, made the like-for-like swap of Jesse Eisenberg for Michael Cera, upscaled the romance, downsized the slapstick.
Jetsam makes an interesting proposition but neither the execution or resolution exert any real grip.
You know exactly what to expect: a blood-and-guts joyride with Death In Excess. And the wonderfully in-yer-face 3D will knock your block off.
A sexed-up, dumbed-down romp that can't decide whether to please undemanding adults, sniggering adolescents or naughty children who shouldn't be watching in the first place.
Afterschool presents modern youth in a cold light. It's difficult to like but even harder to dismiss.
The dubious combination of business, buffoonery and child manipulation makes Imagine That a tough sell.
It's as crazy as a crackpipe on a kayak, but the title alone proves that this is a hell of a lot smarter than it looks.

The combination of gore and giggles can work. But where Scream was funny and knowing and peppered with genuine scares, Sorority Row seems happy merely to play dumb and make a joke of its own derivativeness.
It's worth the price of a ticket but, like most passing curiosities, the first coming of Cirque Du Freak is all sideshows and no main event.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The tears and laughter are genuine enough, but Berstein's orchestrations make her less of a fly on the wall than a fly in the ointment.
A subtly persuasive drama steeped in a strangely beautiful pallor, thanks to superb HD cinematography.
But, hackneyed, unconvincing and ultimately preposterous, Pride and Glory should be made to hand in its badge.
Like a plate of cinematic sushi, writer-director Yosuke Fujita's debut is an off-the-menu mixture of crazy comedy and bland romance that won't satisfy everyone. But it's certainly worth a try.

With high-class acts to match the hi-tech savvy of Scott and his trusty crew (cinematographer Alexander Witt, editor Pietro Scalia, composer Mark Streitenfeld), this is as taut and engrossing a couple of hours as you'll experience all year.

Choke was never going to win any prizes for subtlety, but by toning down Palahniuk's nastier absurdities in favour of obvious laughs, Gregg's adaptation is no more provocative than the average Carry On film.
As calm and thoughtful a history lesson as ever needed to be taught, Waltz With Bashir is a moving picture in every sense.
But as syrup and cynicism congeal into one painful clot, there is never any doubt that this is a major studio's crack at the Yuletide market.

Executive produced by his father and proving that talent is not hereditary, this ill-advised bit of showing off from Jonás Cuarón is exactly what you get when artistic parents indulge their offspring.

"Hang on lads, I've got a great idea..." said Michael Caine at the end of The Italian Job. Presumably he didn't mean waiting 40 years before pulling off a caper that wouldn't blow the bloody doors off a rabbit hutch.
Throw in the inscrutable performances, the peculiar switch in tone and that head-scratcher of a title, and you'd be better off using the hour to tell someone about your childhood.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Fact-based or fictional, no genre sticks to the playbook more rigidly than the sports drama. Creditable addition to the canon though it is, The Express does not buck the trend.
Auburn leaves too many dramatic holes and blows his potentially explosive 'Festen' moment by allowing a confrontation over dinner to fizzle into anti-climax.
From the producer of X-Men... comes the dullest, gooiest chick-flick of the year.
Needing only to span the emotional range from blank to sincere, Reeves is pretty well cast. Sadly, there's not enough Gort and too much of Smith's squirt.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While Neill gives a masterclass in subtle eccentricity and Northam and Brown happily play second string, the theatricals are wisely left to legendary virtuoso O'Toole.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kline and the talented Gaitan do their best to engage on a human level, but ending with various sobering stats about the global sex trade only underlines the film's woefully misplaced dramatic emphasis.

Rest assured, there's no lack of gusto here, director Dornhelm complementing the virtuosity of his performers with pleasing camerawork and subtle stylistic flourishes (colour fades, split screens, and an impressively stark finale).

Those whose national football and cricket teams are led by an Italian and a South African respectively have little room to talk, but surely Scotland has enough homegrown filmmaking talent to stick it to we sassenachs without relying on the Yanks?
In the interests of full disclosure, the 2006 version of The Pink Panther ranks amongst my three most excruciating cinema experiences of all time. This sequel is no better.
Full of cute mutts and daft ideas, you might as well call it 101 Dumb Notions.
While any remaining competitors slink away with their tails between their legs, Pixar and Disney just need to find a name for their new pedigree. Here, Pixey!
The cast looks vaguely uncomfortable too. Even shameless scenery-chewer Curry can't muster any enthusiasm for an over-earnest script that throws around pearls of non-wisdom like moondust.
Intended as a satirical commentary on Japanese society, Tokyo Sonata frustrates mainly because its sharper insights are lost in the hotchpotch of ponderous drama and head-scratching farce.
In terms of performance and production, this is an undeniably high-quality affair. Yet it's all rather superficial.

Handed a role that will amuse nobody but her bank manager, Zellweger displays an infectious lack of enthusiasm, convincing only in capturing the look of someone who wishes they would rather be anywhere else. It's easy to sympathise.
Valkyrie is no action extravaganza. Yet despite having a rich seam of moral ambiguity to mine, the characterisation is no deeper than in Singer's X-Men.
Not that anybody would expect perfection from a film called Beverly Hills Chihuahua, but the chewed bone of a story makes it all mutts ado about nothing.
At a bum-numbing two-and-a-half hours, the film does at least have one thing in common with other Christmas visitors - it long outstays its welcome.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While it'll certainly make you wince, Gordon's slapsticky execution and misguided injections of humour serve only to bleed the situation of suspense. What emerges is not so much horror as a grisly farce.
Role Models matures with age, becoming sweeter and less raucous as it goes on. Unfortunately, when it finds its heart, it loses its legs.
Shot in the wilds of Lithuania and strewn with dramatic battles of all kinds, this epic, Band of Brothers-meets-Exodus adventure is solid stuff indeed.
A jaw-clenchingly unfunny insult to both sexes and everyone's intelligence, it redefines the term 'bridal shower'.
By Odin, it's a totally unexpected hoot.
No spine, no sympathy. No sympathy, no interest. No interest, no point. You get me, bruv?
It's straining at the leash to be liked. Take it home.

If the script doesn't grab you, the eye candy probably will; Evans missing no opportunity to show off his Captain America physique and Faris likewise exposing more flesh than the meat counter at Tesco Extra.
It might have high-rolling credentials, but Wild Card is bluffing.
Riddled with implausibilities but executed with jaw-clenched earnestness and benefiting from a solid twist, this dark morality tale just about gets away with it.
While following familiar sci-fi codes, what makes The Signal unique is the way it's transmitted. Because just when you think you've found its wavelength, it switches to another.
Bringing a little dash of class to a big brash world, A Little Chaos goes a long way.
Some crime sagas only give London's underbelly a tickle. Hyena scratches 'til it bleeds.
It all comes together in a satisfyingly preposterous finale. It even dares to leave a deliberate loose end. Shame it leaves so many in the middle.
Unadulterated, unashamed, unaccompanied fun.
Robertson makes a consistently engaging lead, ably assisted by Clooney as her world-weary foil.
While not quite bad enough to be so bad it's good, Survivor provides lots of completely unintentional entertainment.
Spy generally accomplishes its mission.
Powered by Downey's charisma and state-of-the-art visuals, actor-director Favreau's vibrant franchise-starter makes RoboCop look like Dixon of Dock Green.
A spectacular feat of cinematic engineering.
Thanks to the scenery, the performances and a rich vein of unintentional silliness, The Longest Ride feels a whole lot shorter than it is.
From script to performances, it's completely implausimundo. And it's often nasty to the point of gratuitous, with a sense of humour likely only to appeal to those who take their comedy extra black.
Not unlike most teenagers, it's a bit strange but a lot deeper than it looks. And it knows how to keep a secret.
XXL? ZZZ...
Cub will keep gorehounds happy, but its cruel dismissal of youth makes it disturbing in more ways than it should be.
A slow-burning story of regret and redemption, this is film of moments; most fleeting, a few intriguing, one outstanding.
Attaboy.
For every LOL moment in Trainwreck - and there are plenty - there are three that thud harder than an old comic keeling over on stage.
Gray does an undeniably fine job of taming what amounts to a decade-long soap opera, covering a lot of narrative ground with little loss of dramatic steam.
Fast, loose and smarter than it looks, Dope has a point to make and has fun making it.
While the old folks are an unpredictable delight, it doesn't take long to tire of DeJonge's teenage know-all or Oxenbould's excruciating bursts of schoolyard rap.
If you're up for a spot of lyre rock and other hey-nonny-nonsense, this is exactly as you like it.
Chugging along like Planes, Trains And Automobiles with a drop in comic horsepower, it's an unremarkable but perfectly serviceable odd-couple caper that'll pass the time when it's a bit grim outside.
Throws up just enough intrigue and theological-ethical questions to qualify as one of the year's more guilty pleasures.
A tryingly fey biopic with all the style and substance of cigarette smoke.
Making wry observations about the generation gap without patronising anyone on either side, Meyers gently furthers the cause of the over 60s and working mothers alike ...
It's only when the giddiness passes that you realise you've witnessed not only an incredible true story but a fitting tribute to an unforgettable landmark.
Director Stephen Frears and writer John Hodge turn reporter David Walsh's exhaustive expose of Lance Armstrong into a whistlestop tour of one of sport's greatest scandals.
MacFarlane ensures that any sops to touchy-feeliness come with an arm-punching pay-off.
A saddening story of a principled man left disillusioned, discredited and disowned.
Although it's the sort of film that can't pass a mirror without pointing a finger and winking at itself, it generally earns the right to do so.
Only the Coen brothers could make a film so impressively brutal and yet so understated as this. It helps that the set-up is so fiendishly simple. Blood simple, you might say.
Some sort of lazily conceived exercise designed to distract undemanding teens and people too knackered to follow anything of substance after a hard day's work.
Textures and gestures are brilliantly rendered, the body language saying more about the characters and their relationships than any words ...

After running a few fool's errands for Hollywood with the likes of Pineapple Express, Your Highness and The Sitter, director David Gordon Green makes a serious return to indie business with a full-blown case o' the Mississippi blues.
Even middling Hitchcock is a cut above most thrillers.
movie_title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1956)

movie_review_blurb: The scriptwriters don't exactly deliver an embarrassment of riches in the joke department ... Unless you're a sucker for rodent farts, in which case they come up trumps.
The surreal quirks fly like priests in inflatable rockets in the latest melan-comic doodle from the Spotless Mind of Michel Gondry.
The lack of coherence and backstory makes it hard to gain any sort of dramatic hold, not helped by Slattery's uncertain shifts in tone.
Your date will be smiling though the sniffles. You won't need to ungrit your teeth. Everyone goes home happy.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With the element of originality gone, this trip to Sin City just ain't as gripping as the first. But you gotta admire its style.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Written in stone or bellowed in Latin, guff is still guff.
A murky tale, intriguingly told.
All blandishments aside, the underlying optimism and engaging performances make for a thoroughly agreeable dish. And it all looks yum.
An object lesson in acceptance and the perils of eating too much cheese, The Boxtrolls is crate fun.
Good show.
Between Firth's English bluster and Stone's gamine charms, the players hit just the right note of Coward-esque theatricality to complement Allen's settings and mood.
Nicely composed and played with an endearing sense of Hitchcockian humour, Grand Piano is well worth a tinkle.
Solemn, reverential and brief, Ida provides a thoughtful footnote to one of the most emotional chapters in human history.
It's high time MLK got the big-screen platform he deserves. Thanks to Selma, justice has been done.
When the randomly appearing lip balm on the main protagonist's lips becomes a source of distraction, you know you're not hooked.
Capturing the jaundiced look of the Scorsese-Coppola crime era, it oozes class and atmosphere.
Come the last beat, you'll probably be exhausted. But you'll also feel entertained, inspired and wonderfully alive. The ovation starts here.
Put it in your sights.
There you have it, kids: all you need is love. Although loads of money and a good wi-fi signal definitely help.

Despite being hampered by an overly convoluted plot and two of the feeblest Bond villains ever (greedy buffoons Koskov and Whitaker don't have a quantum of menace between them), Dalton brings much-needed grit to the role.
Ho-ho-hum.
Ticking all the boxes required of the genre, it's well up to movie sub standards.
Exhaustive biography this is not. But in focusing on Brown's rise and heyday and with Boseman faultlessly capturing his groove, you can't fail to have yourself a funky time.
Like discovering the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel was built on a graveyard, it'll take most old ladies to a much darker place than they were expecting.
A symbolic portrait of a state that puts bureaucracy before community, it's as sobering as a week-long hangover.
Shore eventually delivers the blood and thunder we've been waiting for.
A cleverly constructed story of intellectual weight and genuine intrigue.
It's hard to recall the last time Murray displayed the sort of energy and commitment he shows as the self-destructive and seemingly irredeemable Vincent. There might not even have been a last time.
One weepie that never resorts to cheap manipulation, thanks to a wry script (based on John Green's chart-topping novel) and central performances to match ...
Warm, wistful and perfectly cast, it's like hearing your gran bang on about the old days after a couple of sherries. Grand, just grand.
If they handed out awards for commitment in the face of screenwriting adversity, this laughably unconvincing wannabe tearjerker would sweep the board.
It's a preposterous tale about a preposterous business. But the fact that half this stuff really went down makes it preposterous fun.
Offering a uniquely textured style of animated excellence, it's proof once again that Laika's hands-on methods are more than a match for the machine-tooled perfections of Pixar.
While lurching from pure Hitchcock to pure poppycock, this imaginatively orchestrated schlocker is guaranteed, at some point, to make you gasp.
For the most part ... this is a superior addition to the genre that offers much food for thought.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For all its candy-covered monsters and eye-opening talents, Miss Peregrine's world is peculiarly familiar.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film too often lets intrigue drift into ennui. It often takes so long to reach its next stop it could have been The Girl on the Southern Train.
With Cruise in control and Zwick rarely taking his foot off the accelerator, this is tosh of a very high calibre.
It builds up an effective, nape-prickling head of steam ...
The emotions are as beautifully captured as the scenery, but the staging is wutheringly contrived.
Ever wondered how Love, Actually might have turned out if Richard Curtis had written it with a hangover?
Think Dead Poets Society... without the grandstanding.
The shtick becomes a little samey but there are enough pearls of idiocy and head-in-the-oven moments to keep you in the perversely festive spirit.
The film doesn't present the edge of seventeen so much as its annoyingly grating surface.
The gangsters-and-geezers genre has been going grey for some time. With its arresting mix of the stylish and the raw, Jet Trash gives it a shot in the arm.
A cheekily enjoyable swipe at the fickleness of fans, fame and the global gossip machine.
Fitting, entertaining, and true to itself, T2 does what all good sequels should: making a pleasure of other people's leisure.
Some knowledge of Bat-lore is advisable, but for lovers of sardonic asides, super-silliness and sock-pow-biff animation, this is guaranteed to lighten up the darkest of knights.
For the uninitiated, this is a splendidly clear account of a pivotal chapter in world history. For the rest, it's a timely reminder.
You'll get your money's worth.
Thanks to the formidable effects and thumping forward momentum, you'll be through your popcorn in no time.
Oh, to be confined to a Gothic prison and denied human contact until you fall in love with your hideous, foul-tempered captor... it's every girl's romantic dream.
Step away from the vehicle.
Ritchie allows precious few breaks in the action.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sandstorms, spiders, crows, rats, zombies... lots of zombies. Alas, nothing as exciting as a WWE star on his way to becoming Hollywood legend.
There's something to strike a chord with most audiences.
Whimsical and first-world problematic as the story may be, Keaton and Gleeson create a genuinely enjoyable chalk-and-cheese rapport.

Delivering a sugar rush of gadgets, giddiness and gibberish, Despicable 3 is literally all over the place. But somehow the three co-directors manage to pull the threads together to make daft sense of it all.
One thing's for sure: loving thy neighbour will be a darned sight harder after this.
Kruithof delivers a no-frills calling card with a political thriller that borrows liberally from the genre's 70s heyday.
At the end of the day it's an action movie and in that regard Atomic Blonde kicks serious ass.
Driven by two performances of exceptional nuance and restraint, this is a story that inspires us to individually live and let live and collectively do the right thing.
Thankfully, the jumps come frequently enough to raise it a Watt or two above the standard horror potboiler - phew!
While the sentimentality is as tangible as the surroundings, nothing is overcooked or forced home.
Unlikely to keep anyone out of the water ... but perfect bait for a Friday night.
Director Hytner maintains the homely feel with plenty of beige hues and a cast stacked with British talent.
Ultimately, the film manages to find the wit and humanity in any situation. As one would only hope from the writing, directing and acting superpowers involved.
Headland's romcom may have sex on the brain but it certainly gives a couple of Hollywood's lesser lights the chance to shine.
Whilst neither a masterpiece nor a misfire, it's a pleasure to see a biopic that's not afraid to break the mould.
With characters speaking almost exclusively in soundbites, anecdotes, proverbs and quotations, it's like being cornered at a convention of fortune cookie fillers.
While scoring highly on pace and atmosphere, many questions remain unanswered.
Capture The Flag has enough visual energy to get to the moon and back. Alas, the script blows harder than a solar wind.
Steeped in cigarette smoke and pinko-paranoia, Trumbo delivers a suitably noirish take on one of Hollywood's less glorious eras.
While only providing sporadic entertainment for the over-15s, it'll keep the tween set amused to the bottom of their popcorn buckets.
Bounding onto screens with a heart far bigger than its budget, this little beauty offers youngsters something light to snack on before their next Disney feast.
Unfortunately the humour is frequently more WTF than LOL.
While your enjoyment will depend on your relationship status, your complement of X chromosomes, and your affinity for Wilson's brand of brash, you'll go on much worse dates than this.
With Reeves in energy-saving mode, the troubled cop and corruption routines simmer but never come to the boil.
Najafi rarely lets the nonsense flag. Having honed his skills on guilty small-screen pleasure Banshee, he knows his way around a gunfight and a car chase.
Woefully uninspired and toxically unfunny, this film is so rotten it could necrotize your soul. Horrible, just horrible.
In terms of optical stimulation, there's something to please all of the people at least some of the time. Even when it all gets a bit Confucius.
Trachtenberg lulls viewers into a complete sense of insecurity with a neatly executed three-hander that confines itself almost entirely to a single subterranean bunker.
Something tells us you won't have to wait 20 years for your next star-spangled slice of cheesageddon.
[A] sleek-looking but mechanically dodgy vehicle...
There'll be better pantomimes around at Christmas.
There's nothing wrong with its signals but the manoeuvres still need L-plates.
Engaging performances certainly broaden its appeal, especially from the younger members of the cast. But as you might guess from the title, it's totally preaching to the converted.
Cramming lots of Lewis Carroll's beloved characters into a story of its own imagining, Disney's follow-up to 2010's Wonderland is as yummy-looking as an Easter Egg... but just as hollow.
Burnt is strictly a la carte.
Not a heartbreaking work of staggering genius, but a gently uplifting film that celebrates fresh starts and life's possibilities.
The script lands a few solid blows for women's rights and mines a rich vein of humour, tossing up nuggets of both the morbid and deadpan variety.
If a joke's worth flogging - or even if it isn't - it's flogged to death.
Uncomplicated but unremarkable, Jane won't blow anyone away.
One thing's for sure: Facebook won't like it. That alone has got to be worth a thumbs-up.
Mr Kipling would be exceedingly pleased.
You'll laugh and you'll cringe. But, like Alice's behaviour, the film is too erratic to exert any emotional grip. So cry you won't.
Put on your party shirt, grab a brew, and waste some precious time.

Not only comes with all the post-war style and Noo Joizee-ness you'd expect from the story of an Italian-American boy band striving to make it big in the 50s and 60s, it plays its musical numbers dead straight.
Crucially lacking in tension and detail, this is a frustratingly vague telling of an extraordinary tale.
Bigger, sillier... and as on the money as anything five credited screenwriters have collectively come up with in years.
Stillman is still a breath of comically refined air in a world all too eager to hear Adam Sandler's next belch.
Providing a feast of kills, confrontations and capering cubs while keeping on-screen gore to a minimum, nature lovers of all ages will get their fill.
If you're plugged into Sparks, you're in luck. Others are advised to bring a good book.
Only die-hard curmudgeons will remain unmoved.
While the youngsters to whom the stories are aimed won't take long to get the fidgets, older viewers will undoubtedly appreciate the scenery a tad longer before joining them.

Newcomer Brannigan is a real find, though his dramatic weight is splendidly countered by the scene-stealing Maitland who provides one of the film's two unforgettable, can't-believe-he-did-that moments.
A fiend-ish puzzler less likely to give you scares before bed than leave you scratching your head.
Sadly, there's no getting around the obvious lack of chemistry between Blunt and her doughily bland co-star.
While this results in some genuine moments of truth, most scenes feel forced to fit the standard rom-com template.
A natural selection, whatever era you're from.
The action too often feels shoehorned in to break up the (far from universally compelling) character arcs as Nolan and his sibling co-writer Jonathan draw everything to a cathartic close.
Voiced by MacFarlane, you could argue that Ted is just Family Guy's hooched-up pooch Brian with more fur and less class. Maybe so, but he's still a riot.
There's just not that much to recall.
Even the presence of Charles Dance as a gentleman crook with connections to Scotland Yard can't hide the fact that the film is all style and no class.
Co-directors Sam Fell and Chris Butler will please a broad crowd, striking a consistent balance between morbid slapstick and fabulously droll wit.
With nary a single sympathetic soul in sight, it's impossible to care who does what to whom or when.
Even the stiffest upper lips may start to wobble.
Practically embracing the commercialism of childhood and clearly made with one eye on the franchise, it's arguably the least hypocritical holiday flick of the modern age.
Alas, everyone involved appears to have seen it less like the next country for old men than easy money for old rope.
Just the sort of rom-com you'd expect from a director who once came to blows with George Clooney.
Not since Robin Williams rocked it from the delta to the DMZ has the war in Vietnam produced a story with as much snap and sass as this. And you can take that to the bridge.
As the title implies, Josh Schwartz's first directing job is designed purely for the short-term satisfaction of simple appetites.
Think American Pie (without the sight gags) meets Sex and the City (without the gloss) and you've got this, a girls-on-top comedy that's all spit and no polish.
A joint to be savoured.
And there's you thinking that The Shining was just a scary movie about Jack Nicholson going nuts in a big, old hotel in the middle of nowhere. Ha! Think again.
For a story of illicit lovers, wronged women and anxious protest, Ginger & Rosa lacks one rather important ingredient: passion.
Dumb, noisy and not half as cool as it thinks it is, it's like being caught in a shouting match between half-cut rednecks at a Nascar meet.
The narrative might not go far, but you'll certainly feel like you've been on the road. On and on.
Yet another underwhelming, box-ticking sequel in which the action feels as perfunctory as the plot.
The leading trio and soapily watchable tone make it worth coming out of your room for.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Guilty pleasure" is pushing it, but you might develop a certain guilty appreciation for the way this slab of breezeblock Brit-schlock goes about its ludicrously contrived business.
Ultimately, any misgivings are far from grave... and animation lovers will certainly rest in peace.
It's a no-win situation regardless of the outcome. In keeping with the cautionary tone, Vinterberg leaves the dust unsettled.
The shortfall of suspense is emphasised with every pointless car chase, head-slapping contrivance, and attempt at tongue-in-cheekiness. This movie can seriously damage your IQ.
Ambiguous and enigmatic or muddled and unsatisfying? It's your call.
While lovers of Britain's answer to Inspector Clouseau will rejoice at his return, others will find it as funny as a dozen kicks in the goolies. Which it sometimes literally is.
Only first-time visitors to Paris are in for disappointment: it simply can't live up to this.
This is an old-fashioned cockle-warmer that connects through flesh and blood, not pixels.
While wearing the politics lightly, Robinson neatly captures the transitional, expectant mood of both the time and the place.
While making no effort to explain the terminology - mathematical or baseball-ical - the script throws enough fastballs to keep even the most ignorant of us Limeys entertained.
It may be a marketing nightmare, but as examinations of mortality go, few come funnier, wiser or more astutely acted.
Just a load of planes, cranes and Himalayan snowcocks.
Schlock lovers and Friday night thrill-seekers are disgustingly well served. Best skip that tray of gooey nachos, though.

Even if the adventure wasn't brimming with humour, invention and derring-do, it's Downey's bold take on such a well-loved (and defined) literary hero that is bound to make any addition to the franchise worth a watch.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Thankfully, the cast raise it above Hallmark standard, especially Jackson with a performance that proves he doesn't have to bring down great vengeance or furious anger to grab your attention.
Really ... it's just Dodgeball with a lobotomy.
Where so many sporting champs turn out to be dramatic chumps, this is a supremely confident debut from a talent who packs charisma like punches. She'll go far.
Hill's streetwise-nerd shtick ensures that The Sitter is not without chuckles. They just don't all belong in the same film.
Carnahan brings the raw edge of his debut Narc to this snowbound, mens' own adventure.
Where some directors might have let the religious overtones induce feverish lapses into Southern Gothic, Egoyan wisely plays it as a straight procedural-cum-courtroom drama.
The set-up is ripe with intrigue. Unfortunately, focus is frequently lost in the murky atmosphere.
Mavis is not entirely irredeemable. Perfectly balancing credibility and mental instability, Theron gives her surprising depth.
Awash with jollity and drollery in equal measure, Gideon Defoe's Pirates! book series was sailor-made for Aardman Studio's brand of sophisticated, stop-motion silliness.
With philosophy in its heart and shrapnel in its head, it's like being battered with a Kevlar-backed Dictionary of Pentagon Propaganda.
While eschewing the mockney flash of his Lock, Stock mucker Guy Ritchie, Fletcher's kitchen sink is brighter than most, filled more with Shane Meadows brass than Ken Loach gloom.
It isn't the wildest safari you'll ever go on, but it has plenty of attractions to offer less cynical visitors.
While charting familiar waters, the plot moves swiftly and efficiently, building a good head of steam over the first hour before exploding during the Panamanian highway robbery.
With all due disrespect to its source, 21st century Jump Street is both dope and dopier.
Lamentable in script, performance and execution...
While it won't get you in a huge flap, The Raven will give you enough caws to stay awake upon a midnight dreary...

All credit to the world's most pale and interesting heartthrob for subverting, if not entirely upending his image as Guy de Maupassant's homme fatale Georges Duroy, a penniless ex-soldier whose only talent is in the art of seduction.
Thankfully, any bumps in the plot are steamrollered under director Espinosa's procession of breakneck chases, chaotic shoot-outs, and convincingly ugly fistfights.
In terms of spirit and atmosphere, Marigold is as natural as its more experienced performers' talents.
It's a worthy story, straightly told.
Give these guys more power and more responsibility.
Under Polanski's direction, the subtle switching of allegiances and steady erosion of airs and pretensions make their middle-class meltdown a joy to behold.
Nobody's forecasting gales of laughter, but it'll give your pipes a canny wee toot.
With few characters to warm to and enough plot to fill a dozen nights in the TV parlour, turning Dickens' doorstop into a single, consistently enjoyable piece of cinema is no mean feat.
It's like being trapped in an improv workshop run by people who share too much on Facebook.
All the wry banter and gentle soul-searching in the world can't save the audience from drifting into apathy.
Makes up for its lacks of originality with more flash than a One Direction press conference.
Much of this could be forgiven if you had even the remotest shred of sympathy for Imogene. But from beginning to end, she's the sort of character you should cross the cinema foyer to avoid.
It's a poignant and frank delight, perfectly summed up by the most awkward after-dinner speech since Festen.
This is the sort of script you imagine came with little hearts over the 'i's instead of dots. With no jokes to freshen it up, it's cheesier than a ripe camembert in an unwashed sock.
Fast and furiously good natured, it certainly puts the gas into gastropod.
What emerges is a richly shot daydream whose vagaries will please the high-brow while frustrating the common hordes. But its general sensibility undoubtedly lies somewhere in the middle.
With jokes for every level of sophistication, not all hit the mark. But with so many visual twists and deliciously surreal turns, there's something fun going on in every frame.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As you'd expect from Scott, the action is efficient, clinical and nasty. If only the same could be said of McCarthy's dialogue, which always sounds pretty but too often lapses into profound irrelevance.
Parkland is the most lucid dramatisation of the tragedy to come out of Hollywood yet.
Warm, heartening and often rather splendid, there's only one word for it. Even though the sound of it is something quite atrocious...

Little more than a series of repetitious chases that ploughs through the cliches like so many piled-up boxes, barrels, crates and Christmas trees. All that's missing is some blokes trying to cross the street with a plate glass window.
[Lee's] uncompromising attitude proves to be exactly what's needed to westernise a landmark in Asian extreme cinema - without dulling its edge.
Now here's a novelty - a movie that might make you want to give Vince Vaughn a hug rather than a slap across his smart-alecky chops.
An incredible tale of love, courage and humanity - and their opposites - the story of Eric Lomax sounds like it was dreamed up in a Hollywood melodrama workshop. But it's true.
While it plays by the occult numbers too frequently to create any real sense of dread, the filmmakers summon up enough fresh fiendishness to sustain the interest.
There's nothing you won't see coming, from the plot to the preponderance of weight gags that generally end with "but you ate it".
For all his character clichés, Letts' dialogue invariably comes with the sting of truth. You'll find something to empathise with even if you don't want to.
An in-yer-face showcase of violence, female objectification and Eastern, wu xia action made to make adolescent lads drool.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Roarsome.
Thankfully, with its hokily enjoyable mix of sword-swinging heroics and CG pandemonium, Pompeii doesn't blow it.
Stupid, irresponsible, sweary, puerile, overloaded with pop culture references, and shamefully funny: Friday night just found its perfect partner.
Farhadi loosens the valve on a drip-feed of revelations, each one changing any assumptions prompted by the last.
It's a Gonzo comedy in every sense.
If imitation is flattery, the makers of How To Train Your Dragon and the Oscar-winning Brave must never have felt flatter.
movie_title: Justin and the Knights of Valour (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A B-movie of considerable ambition and substance.
There's no shortage of bloodshed, but rare is the film that uses bullets and flashing blades to provoke sadness rather than excitement.
It's not a total descent into romantic hell, but it gives a comprehensive tour of the upper circles.

Slapstick. Wit. Invention. Random laser battles. While it's easy to get carried away by the action - as the characters frequently do - it's the joyful irreverence that makes this such a terrific ride.
The film is always keen to set up a gag but rarely makes the punchline worth it.
This unlikely ménage-a-trois has created an offbeat romance of remarkable warmth and credibility.
In pedigree and accuracy, The Invisible Woman is not in doubt. But with so many questions left unanswered, it feels like a love story unfulfilled.
Sibling screenwriters George and John Gatins (the latter an Oscar nominee for Flight) deliver nothing that Smokey and the Bandit didn't manage at half the length and with twice the charm.
Twohy gets the Pitch Black saga back where it belongs: at the B-movie end of the sci-fi universe.
A disposable thriller with no aspirations to reality or serious social commentary...
Good for a few chalk-and-cheese chuckles but no real belly laughs.
A film that is unafraid to recognise that, for some, a life spent drunk is easier (and much less boring) than fighting a disease with no permanent cure.
Child's more open-minded readers and those unfamiliar with his ex-military hero can rest assured that Cruise's Reacher is a character of considerable screen substance.

With each chapter covering no more than a few days a year, mainly around her prison visits or his rare days on release, the pair create a credibly stagnant relationship. Forced to snatch whatever intimacy they can, their frustration is palpable.
Queasiness abound but there are no real jolts; the words "foreskin", "anus" and "vulva" are unlikely to disturb anyone under the age of 97.
From the objectification of females to the condoning of crime, the mild political incorrectness of the 1960s fits uneasily with the 21st century upgrades.
Starting with the least meet-cute encounter ever, Warm Bodies injects much-needed life into a genre crushed to a sugary pulp under the juggernaut of Nicholas Sparks.
Who knew that emo could be this much fun?
Aside from the stunt team and the over-caffeinated editors, nobody appears interested in making this what it should be: a major movie event.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: By hook or by crook, Williams chivvies everyone along to the requisite throat-clearing denouement. A feelgood finale, for sure. You just might feel like you've been man-handled to get there.

The most unforgettable film of any length you will see this year.
movie_title: Le Souvenir d'un avenir (Remembrance of Things to Come) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmaker's bone-deep understanding of her subject subtly opens the picture.
Engagingly evenhanded and intelligently assembled first feature.

This terrifically smart and solid piece of filmmaking lets the former Weathermen, now in their 50's and older, speak into the camera and reveal a bit of their personal histories as well as what the peace movement meant to them.
Once the picture kicks into gear, it has the inspiring resonance of found art.
The picture has a spiky, efficient hilarity, and the director uses his actors well.
It is a bewitching and harrowing tale of the continual submersion of self to stay alive, told by a woman who survived the impostures in which she cloaked herself.
Insanely likable but suffers from anemia.
Most of the film's allure comes from the sensual, butter-voiced Thandie Newton; with her, Mr. Demme has found the 21st-century corollary to Audrey Hepburn.
The picture is desperate to be a Date Night event, but it feels more like a Last Date movie.
The film is far more successful when raising questions of spirituality and Christianity than when dealing with the subject at hand.
This picture is murder by numbers, and as easy to be bored by as your ABC's, despite a few whopping shootouts.
This isn't a movie: it's a police report and the strictly-the-facts terseness of the story makes this more than clear.
Mr. Leconte gives this meeting of opposites in Claude Klotz's script a lovely, sportive élan, instead of making it register as lumpy, obvious polemics.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The frenzied momentum churns up a lot of adrenaline and stomach acid for Irréversible. But the performances certainly don't stir up much emotion.
Just plain generic.
Like a soft drink that's been sitting open too long: it's too much syrup and not enough fizz.
The movie is a success on its own terms because the director doesn't condescend to pop music.
High-school cafeteria soup has more flavor than this bland, tepid throwback.
This salute to the literally unsung and underrecognized studio heroes of Motown is so good because it is one of those rare documentaries that combine information with smashing entertainment.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: After several scenes of this tacky nonsense, you'll be wistful for the testosterone-charged wizardry of Jerry Bruckheimer productions, especially because Half Past Dead is like The Rock on a Wal-Mart budget.
Even when the movie is over, the psychological physics of Personal Velocity will remain in your head.
Cranks up an impressive amount of energy considering that it's the third installment.
Another wholly unnecessary addition to the growing, moldering pile of, well, extreme stunt pictures.
Leaves no cliché unturned; it's Old Jack City.
A movie that could be stupider only if it were longer.
Though the film is spongy and drenched in sweetness, Bruce Beresford's direction is steady and well oiled.
The most incredible accomplishment of Towers is that at its heart it is a transition film that lasts nearly three hours and holds the viewer's attention.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Nights is festooned with yards of gross-out jokes, sniggering allusions and, astonishingly, a sentimental climax that's more repellent than any of the crude effluvia the film is drenched with.

The wonderfully lush Morvern Callar is pure punk existentialism, and Ms. Ramsay and her co-writer, Liana Dognini, have dramatized the Alan Warner novel, which itself felt like an answer to Irvine Welsh's book Trainspotting.
This film, Mr. Caetano's feature-length directorial debut, has an emotional integrity that's concise and direct.
A movie so bad that it quickly enters the pantheon of wreckage that includes Battlefield Earth and Showgirls.

The fabulous bones of this oft-told tale have been picked over so often that there's no flesh left on them. But Mr. Marshall and the screenwriter Bill Condon get a terrifically sweet concoction out of this fabled skeleton.
Mr. Wiseman's stubbornness is manifest in his work, and you will fall for the same quality in The Last Letter if you have any affection for his past work.
[School's] like a half-empty glass of Coke that's been sitting out for a couple of days; sure, it looks like cola, but one sip tells you exactly what's missing.
David Gale may be the first liberal-leaning movie that could be brought up on assault charges since its director, Alan Parker, made Midnight Express.
Lost may not be a great piece of filmmaking, but it is a great story; its directors display dramatic intelligence.
With Shanghai Knights, [Chan] has come through with one of his best.
Enchanting and diverting but not resonant.
Second-rate and ordinary.
This competently made picture seems a rehash, and not a terribly interesting one.
An entertaining, grimy view of the traps of machismo tucked inside a cop thriller.
What this concert film and documentary makes clear is that the real Miley is not just like her predominantly pre-adolescent, female fans.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The genius of Scorsese's film, which is being shown in IMAX in 93 theaters, is that it reveals the Stones' mortality while celebrating all that makes them more than mere mortals.
If This Is It doesn't miraculously restore the middle-aged Jackson to his past glory, it at least offers glimpses of his bygone greatness, and poignant suggestions of what might have been.
The threat may be as illusory as the thrills in Jonas Brothers are contrived. But that won't stop Jonas junkies from enjoying their magical mystery tour.

The best thing about this bizarre love story (follie de grandeur) between a female pool cleaner and immobile man in wheelchair is that it puts icon Robert Downey behind the camera after long absence; with some luck Patrick Dempsey should become a lead man
The narrative is weak and the ending fake, but Gina Kim's interracial romantic melodrama is well shot and acted, particularly by Vera Farmiga as a sexually repressed wife.
The narrative is flawed, but it benefits from its timely subject (impact of Iraq War on home front) and gender reversal, centering on widower whose wife had died in the war.

Steve Zahn shines in Illsley's feature debut, elevating this eccentric small-town comedy two notches above the level of writing. Using the fish out of water format, this Sundance premiere begins well but then declines rapidly.
One of Van Sant's best films, a richly dense, poetic evocation of friendhsip that retells Shakespeare's Henry IV in an original and intriguing way; River Phoenix gives his most riveting performance.

One of the best screwball comedies, a remake that improves on the source material due to Hawks brilliant idea of changing the protag's gender thus turning it into a romantic "newspaper" film; Cary Grant, Rosalind Russell, and Ralph Bellamy at their best

Best thing to be said about this fluffy crowd-pleaser is that contrary to Hollywood's dictum (beware of children and animals), the dogs, cute and reliable as they are, don't steal the show from Shannon who holds the uneven feature on her solid shoulders
Kempmeier's follow-up to Virgin is structurally messy, confused, and cliched, a lost opportunity to deal in significant ways with child abuse and rape
Billy Crystall's feature directorial debut is a misfire: As an actor, he's too likable to play the egotistical comedian who torments everyone around him for the sake of his career.

The music is glorious, but as a movie, this is a photographed play, a nostalgic evocation of small-town American that was congruent with Kennedy's New Frontier; within a year, though, Kennedy would be assassinated and the optimistic mood would vanish

Ben Stiller's feature directorial debut is a zeitgeust comedy, whose significance is more sociological than cinematic--It's "The Big Chill" for the twentysomething crowd in the Age of Clinton and AIDS.

Grounded in the rich cinematic tradition of Small-Town America, the film doesn't break much new thematic ground, but it's well-acted by the entire ensemble, which consists of both pros and young thespians.

One of the weirdest, most original entries in this year's dramatic competition--American indie set in Goe with Hindu actors--The Pool should divide film critics, but a closer look beneath the surface reveals consistent themes in Smith's growing oeuvre

Along with Lassie Come Home, this is one of MGM's classic family-animal melodramas, based on Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings' novel, beautifully acted by Gregory Peck, Jane Wyman and Claude Jarman Jr.(in his debut), with strong production values (in color).
After the artistic and commercial failure of Undertow (his only genre film), Green is back on terra firma with a grim and harsh yet lyrical dissection of three emotionally intense relationships.

Using well the paradigm of the outsider, here the impact of a new baby on a seemingly perfect family, this elegantly made, often sophisticated psychological thriller marks Ratliff's smooth transition from docu to feature filmmaking; he's a talent to watch
Jarmusch's mildly entertaining film tells three stories that take place at the same time but are told sequentially (end-to-end) rather than through intercutting, which is Hollywood's prevalent norm.
Sentimental and contrived, Benigni's well-intentioned Holocaust dramedy may only work as a children's fable. Inexplicably, it won a prize at the 1998 Cannes Festival.
movie_title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Lask naver got fomral education but he's certainly movie savvy for his complex and convoluted debut borrows heavily from the recent cycle of postmodern metaphyical meta-narrative films of Michel Gondry, Spike Jonze, Kaufman, and even Marc Forster

On the surface, Young's adaptation of Pomerantz novel feels like a variation of Postman Always Rings Twice, but setting the story in Jersey in a Latino working class milieu and adding Oedipal elements separate his film from the yarn's other versions

Production values are brilliant, and as the drug-addict-hooker Sharon Stone gives her best performance, but thematically, Scorsese rehashes grounds that he had explored deeper in previous films (GoodFellas) and his approach here is too cold and remote.

Harjo's likable Native American fable is very much in the tradition of Smoke Signals, except that the equally sentimental narrative centers on a siblings relationsip rather than father-son medlodrama.

In his impressive feature debut, Christopher Zalla blends successfully the conventions of a political thriller with those of a family melodrama, set against the context of two timely issues, illegal Mexican immigration and stolen identity.

One of the weakest films at this year's Sundance dramatic competition, Weapons is a violent crimer that rehashes familiar turf of the "youth, crime and neighborhood" movie genre, better and deeper explored in numerous indies of the past 15 years.

Sundance Jury Award Winner: Though grounded in a particular locale, Israeli kibbutz in 1974, this disturbing coming-of-age tale also serves as an allegory about the clash between "deviant" individuals and a system that emphasizes "health" and conformity

Capra advocates populism and egalitarianism, underlined by values of Christianity. For him, every person is "God's creation" in his/her own right, evert person possesses some talent and should do his/her best with that gift.

This idealized tribute to a charismatic teacher who devotes himself to music appreciation has the same old-fashioned texture and sticky sentimentality as Goodbye Mr. Chips (of 1939), but Dreyfuss gives an effective, surprisingly restrained performance

Centering on a lesser-known chapter in the reign of Queen Victoria, this richly detailed drama about her intimate relationship with her servant that scandalized the country is extremely well-acted; Judi Dench deserves an Oscar nomination

Kloves' directorial debut features three superlative performances by Jeff and Beau Bridges (as bickering siblings) and particularly Michelle Pfeiffer, who's at her sexiest with a show-stopping number atop a piano in red dress!

With its movie references and psycho-babble,, Baumbach's follow-up to the highly acclaimed Kicking and Screaming is imitative of Woody Allen and Stillman, a slender, one-premise serio-comedy that's better scripted and acted than helmed.
Actress Lahti's feature directorial debut is a disappointingly sappy melodrama about the unlikely bond between a rebebllious high-school grad (Leelee Sobieski) and a dying older man (Albert Brooks).

One of the year's best films: This tragi-comic musical is Luhrmann's most audaciously innovative feature, one that creates its own hightened world, aggressively defying historical authenticity and the established conventions of Hollywood musicals.

Based on the stage hit, Fonda's most popular war movie casts him as the action-driven first officer of the Reluctant, a cargo ship miles away from the battle zone whose route is described by him as "from tedium to apathy" and back again.

Aussie helmer Duigan seems committed to sensualist cinema: as a follow-up to Wide Sargasso Sea and Flirting, this comedy of morals and manners centers on a repressed preacher (Hugh Grant)and sexually wild spirits set against spectacular vistas.

All the elements for a fun hard-boiled crime drama are present, except for a coherent story and a measure of good taste. What enhance the film are Lalo Schifrin's music and some idiosyncratic actors like Alfred Molina and Ruben Blades.

Devotion to art by afficionados or practitioners can give life meaning but the demands can also be trying. Underneath the lustrous images of Parisian society that message comes through in Thompson's film, France's entry for the Foreign Language Oscar.
This special effects extravaganza is s good star vehicle for Jim Carrey, exhibiting his skills and his shticks; in a small part, the sexy Cameron Diaz is bound to become a leading lady.

A throwback to yeteryear's epics, Kazakhstan's official entry for the Foreign-Language Oscar is an old-fashioned actioner using real locales and extras rather than CGI effects; lack of unified vision may derive from too many directors behind the camera
