movie_title: Ich will nicht nur, daß ihr mich liebt (I Don't Just Want You to Love Me) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: The first film of the popular series, in which David Niven (not Peter Sellers) is the nominal lead, introduced Mancini's pouncing score
Richard Todd received an Oscar nomination for playing an obnoxious patient in an rmy hopsital who suffers from fatal illness
A disappointing film
Gary Ross (Big, Dave) makes an impressive directing debut with this charming, nicely executed fable, which contrasts values of the 1950s with those of the 1990s.
This historical Danish film about culture collision was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar.
This powerful family melodrama from the Netherlands won the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar
Ambitious documenatry about the endless Middle East conflicts
Well intentioned but ultimately disappointing Vietnam War romantic melodrama.
Though not one of Astaire-Rogers strongest musicals, the musical is still enjoyable despite its rather bland plot.
Too bad this confusing, incoherent satirical espionage thriller turned out to be the swan song of Sam Peckinpah,who made so many good films (The Wild Bunch).
Charming, offbeat serio comedy about the relationship between a macho and a transsexual
Though he is the producer and not the director, this supremely mounted if old-fashioned horror movie bears the unmistakable signature of Guillermo del Toro.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As directed by Burt Kennedy, this first, drab sequel to the smash hit Western Magnificent Seven, only retains Yul Brynner from the original cast.
A solid, if too conventional docu of the noted artist.
Stylist Claude Lelouche (A Man and a Woman) is still full of surprises in his choice of genres and subjects.
Well acted but overly familiar and sentimental sports tale of the underdog
This serio comedy about an eccentric Southern family is a minor work in Altman's oeuvre, but it's well acted and enjoyable.
This early star vehicle of Gary Cooper displays his good looks, boyish charm, amd strong chemistry with the two women, one played by Fay Wray.
A disappointingly sentimental and shallow film from John Hughes about the homeless
Though structurally messy and visually shapeless, The Help deserves to be seen for its novel subject and thematic concerns, and pleasure of watching good acting.
Amiable, well-acted but middlebrow femme-driven melodrama
A disappointingly detached and tame film for such a subject matter.
Aiming for a different angle, the fifth installment, which is technically proficient, slightly tweaks the formula in a way that should please the series' loyal fans but won't recruit new ones.
A modest, intimate, not particularly engaging American indie (premiering in Cannes Fest) about the adjustment problems of a woman who returns from a tour of duty overseas.
Mildly involving tale of four orphan boys in the Outback
Well acted WWII melodrama
Centering on a young immigrant Korean girl in Toronto, this Sundance indie marks the feature debut of a gifted female director.
Taylor Hackford showed his skills as a commercial director with his very first picture.
This feature debut (graduation thesis) is an uncompelling exploration of ennui among young gays in L.A.
Not much improvement over the vfirst, severely flawed version.
Sunrise may not be the greatest film ever made (as the French critics once declared), but it certainly is one of the most lyrical, stunning, and influential works in cinema history.
movie_title: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)

movie_review_blurb: A touching, haunting tale of young outcasts refugees in Poland just before WWII, though occasionally the lavish visual style is distracting and negates the seriousness of the subject.
based on interviews and historical footage, this is a fascinating chronicle of six women of different backgrounds who were deported to the notorious camp.
It may or may not start a new trend of storytelling, but it's the kind of bold, interesting, technologically-determined documentary that could not have existed even five years ago.

Two movies (and two genres) for the price of one, this ultimate popcorn movie of the summer is a mishmash by design, in which Bond meets Han Solo/Indiana Jones, though more effective as Western than sci-fi thriller.
A deceptively quiet film that celebrates ordinary life as well as the art of storytelling.
Paul Mazursky's worst film.
The comedy is some good moments, and the chemistry between Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds is strong, but it's too cute and predictable
Italian Anna Magnani received a second Oscar nomination for this marital drama by George Cukor, who was a replacement director.
Earnest, overly familiar coming-of-age tale
This color spectacle is more of a celebration of the annual drag show than a probing documentary
This charming cross-cultural tale is the promising feature debut by a young Mexcian director.
Though the acting by Hoffman and especially Barbara Harris (in Oscar nominated turn) is good, Ulu Grosbard's satire seldom finds the right tone.
movie_title: Who Is Harry Kellerman and Why Is He Saying Those Terrible Things About Me? (1971)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting portrait of a black male prostitute from the bold, gifted director Shirley Clarke
Skillfully crafted crime-noir, well directed by Robert Montogmery and well acted by the entire cast, especially Thomas Gomez in an Oscar-nominated performance.
A poignant satire dissecting American beauty pageants
This dramatization of the story upon which Jean Genet's play The Maids is based is well acted and has some powerful moments.
Touching, warmhearted and well acted ensemble piece
Compelling romantic mystery drama, well acted by Gerard Depardieu and Natalie Baye; stay away from the American remake, Sommersby
movie_title: The Return of Martin Guerre (Le Retour de Martin Guerre) (1983)

movie_review_blurb: This complex and involving Argentinean crime drama, with strong moral overtones, won the Best Foreign Language Oscar.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Controversial and provocative documentary than even PBS did not air.

One of the best-acted comedies of the summer, the movie has a lot of charm, humor and insight in its first hour, before turning into old-fashioned middlebrow fare with morals and lessons and neat ending.
A powerful portrait of mob power from the gifted and versatile director Yimou.
movie_title: Shanghai Triad (Yao a yao yao dao waipo qiao) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Susan Hayward received the first of her five Best Actress nominations for this melodrama (woman's picture) in which she plays a fallen woman.
movie_title: Smash Up: The Story of a Woman (1947)

movie_review_blurb: A disappointing second feature from Ed Burns, the director of The Brothers McMullen.
The feature directing debut of actor Vin Diesel is a derivative, hanging out tale.
A crime gangster indie film with a twist
A crow-pleaster hat took the inernational festival circuit by storm and put Aussie filmmaker Luhrmann on the map as a talent to watch.
Emotionally touching, nicely shot portrait of street kids in Seattle.
This well acted ensemble melodrama is not one of John Sayles' strongest films.
A silly, harmless star vehicle for Whoopi Goldberg--sort of nuns on the run.
Marking Billy Bob Thornton's debut as a director and solo writer, Sling Blade is a powerful southern gothic parable about good and evil.
A riveting docu about the controversial filmmaker who made some great propaganda art for Hitler
movie_title: Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A poignant inside look into the world of crossover puzzles of the NY Times.
This charming saga, winner of the top Cannes Film Fest award, tells the story of one family in Yugoslavia circa the eraly 1950s, when politics invased every aspect of life.
movie_title: Otac na Sluzbenom Putu (When Father Was Away on Business) (1985)

movie_review_blurb: There may be debates about Yordan's Oscar-winning script, but Dmytryk's direction of this compelling Western is taut and the acting, especially by Tracy and Katy Jurado (Oscar-nominated), is superb.

The conception and execution of this film is not as bold as Henry V or Hamlet (also by Olivier), but the cast, headed by Olivier as the malevolent hunchbacked monarch, Gielgud and Richardson, is superb.
Informative docu about the search for great contemporary art
A tale about women in the West is a good idea for a genre that's been male-dominated, but not in Kaplan's shallow picture that looks like a fashion spread.
Mediocre operetta starring Nelson Eddy about the Soviet revolution
Ettore Scola's charmingly original, Oscar-nominated film examine French history and culture through dance.
The music is glorious, but the biopic is pedestrian and fictionlaized to a fault, and Robert Alda as the genius George Gerhsiwn is too bland
Harmless entertainment at its most commercial and least artistic, offering some fun spotting the stars in cameos
Lavishly mounted Western by Jacques Tourneur, better known for his noir films
Back in 1968, this sci-fi, directed by Schaffner and penned by Wilson and Serling, was original, quite intelligent , and well executed, garnering a special Oscar for makeup.
Dominic Cooper, in a dual role, is amazing, but his dazzling performance is contained in a rather weak narrative that is not very deep or provocative.
Ed Harris as the fall guy is good and the visuals of this film noir are impressive nut the narrative is severely flawed.
Iceland's Oscar-nominated feature should put its director on the international map
Well acted melodrama in the kitchen sink realism style
A chick flick form Lebanon, this film has some charm
As a follow-up to Battle of Algiers, Burn! is a flawed film, but it's worth seeing for its tone of outrage and provocative ideas about colonialism, big business, and slavery.
This Universal's multi Oscar-nominated tale was very popular in the 1940s
This dark, well-acted suburban tale is follow-up to the gifted Mendleson's most promising feature debut
This romantic melodrama, her second talkie, is verbose and stiff, but Garbo gives a strong, dominant performance, which earned her another Oscar nomination.
Starring Gene Wilder, this offbeat comedy-fantasy for children has achieved a status in pop culture
movie_title: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (1971)

movie_review_blurb: Judy Holliday's Oscar-winning role is for her best (and best-known) film.
movie_title: Born Yesterday - The Films of Judy Holliday

movie_review_blurb: Interesting, well-acted feature debut by a new indie director
The plot of this Stanley Donen musical is slender, but it doesn't matter as it features some of Astaire's best dancing, including a number in which he dances on the walls and ceiling.
After several disappointing films, Allison Anders has made a nother personal film that thematically is linked with her first (and best) feature, Gas Food Lodging.
max Ophuls's merry-go-round narrative, based on Schnitzler's famous play, is exquistely directed and played by best actors of Frenhc cinema: Darriuex, Signoret, Barrault.
One of worst movies of the summer: Lame, unoriginal, and not particularly funny.
Despite limitations imposed by the Production Code (lesbianism!), this first version of Hellman's play is more powerful than the 1961 remake, also directed by William Wyler.
In her second feature, the gifted and original Miranda July very much fulfills the promise she has shown in her stunning debut, Me and You...
Timely, relevant, and touching documentary that needs to be seen.
Charles Lane's indie feature os a goo showcase for the British comedian
A soft, overly familiar coming of age tale, though in small, eccentric role Vanessa Redgrave is good.
With his bravura performance, vet actor Hal Holbrook elevates this modest indie rural drama considerably.

Expanded review: Based on riveting story, this remake of the 2007 Israeli film is a gripping if implausible thriller, offering commentary on the making of political heroes and myths; at this phase, Helen Mirren can do no wrong.
A powerful, bleak B-level biopic of the legendary gangster made just a decade after his death.
An interesting, if too reverential documentary about the life of the blues singer turn minister.
Wajda's intelligent and complex drama could be appreciated as a period piece about the french Revolution as well as a parable of modern politics in Poland and elsewhere.
George Bancroft received Best Actor Oscar nomination for this crime movie directed by von Sternberg.

The eagerly awaited American version (it's not really a remake) of the Swedish crime novel is Fincher's third masterpiece within a decade, reaffirming his status as the most brilliant director working in Hollywood today.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Lacking subtlety, War Horse is one of Spielberg's most accessible melodramas, exhibiting in its visual style classic Hollywood cinema and deliberately made for all members of the family.

Likely to divide critics, the film deserves audience support as one of few works about the impact of 9/11 on ordinary lives, boasting a strong turn by Thomas Horn as a boy forced to come to terms with personal loss and collective nightmare.

Jolie acquits herself more honorably as director than writer in her debut, a simplistic, contrived Romeo and Juliet melodrama, in which there are no secondary characters and litte attention is paid to the broader political context
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Crowe's first work in six years, following the disastrous Elizabethtown, is mildly engaging but ultimately too sweet-natured and innocuous for its own good.

One of the worst films in the career of the otherwise distinguished director Yimou, a sentimental melodrama that trivializes the tragedy of the 1937 Nanjing invasion, featuring Oscar-winner Christian Bale in a mannered, over-the-top performance.
A notch down from the 2009 blockbuster, the second installment of the franchise may be what the fans are expecting: more of the same--only bigger and louder.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Jane Camion's stunning feature debut is a bold and audacious dark comedy about sexual politics and dysfunctional family relations.
The latest work by Finnish cult director Aki Kaurismaki is is his strongst in a decade--and one of 2011 best foreign pictures.

Nominally, Ceylan's sixth film is a genre item, a police procedural, but as the tale unfolds, we realize its ambitious and ambiguous metaphysical goal in contesting the nature and constraints of human knowledge and objective truth.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Irving Rapper's screen version of Emlyn Williams semi-autobiographical play is well acted by Bette Davis as the spinster-teacher, but is too theatrical, sentimental and conventional.

This clunky musical (a formulaic combo of football feature and campus comedy) is best known today for featuring two actresses who would become major stars in the 1940s: Judy Garland (then 13) and Betty Grable.
Scripted by Joseph Stefano (better known for Hitchcock's Psycho), this mildly engaging suspense thriller became Gary Cooper's final film, released posthumously.

Garson Kanin is not Leo McCarey, who was originally assigned to direct this screwball comedy, reuniting Cary Grant and Irene Dunne (Awful Truth), but he has made a well acted, decent, and enjoyable film.

One of the most underestimated movie musicals, based on Gershwin's masterpiece, Porgy and Bess receives a lavish production from Otto Preminger in an all-black, Oscar-nominated picture, starring Sidney Poitier and Dorothy Dandridge.
Sharply uneven, this teen-angst feature begins exgremely well with some relevant social commentary; it also put on the map Christian Slater as a talent to watch.

Making a smooth transtition from animation to live-action, Bird has directed a fast-moving, largely enagaging, well acted (especially by Renner) actioner, which is the fourth and most entertaining of the franchise.

Alfredson's take on John le Carre's seminal 1974 espionage thriller is intelligent and absorbing, both thematically and visually, benefiting from the passage of time since the fall of the Berlin Wall.

Eastwood inspired by Citizen Kane? Part character study of an iconic figure, part chronicle of the FBI institution, J. Edgar is a sharply uneven, shapeless film that deserves to be seen for effort and ambition rather than execution.
This impressive debut, winner of the cinematography award at Sundance Fest, elevates the visibility of a taboo subject within black culture that has remained unexplored by independent cinema.

part history, part mythology, and largely a violent spectacle of state of the art effects, Immortals is a wannabe epic blockbuster, a visually striking but emotionally barren tale that lacks a coherent, unified conception.

This gender-bending period film is not particularly rich in ideas, but its serves as a showcase for Glenn Close, who has not had a good leading screen role in years, and Janet McTeeer in the supporting category.
A disappointing sequel that retains the impressive visuals of the 2006 Oscar-winning original, but lacks its narrative energy and charm.
Despite expectations, the gifted director Bill Condon is unable to put a peronal signature on this tale, resulting in another disappointing movie to be poorly reviewed but fully embraced by the fans.
This is repeat business for the filmmakers of Valentine's Day, except that this charmless party of a movie (and movie of a party) has larger cast and is even more schmaltzy than the first picture.
Shrewdly conceived, this franchise rebook aims to please adult viewers who remember the TV show, as well as their children, exposed for the first time to the magic of the cultural phenomenon.
Like an unexpected Christmas gift, this animated frature is an unexpected delight, revolving around a premise that often concerns children.

A frontrunner for the Best Picture (and other) Oscar, this charming valentine to the magic of silent cinema has won the hearts of moviegoers in every festival it has played, beginning with Cannes Fest in May.

Fluidly directed by Moverman and splendidly acted by Harrelson, who deserves Best Actor Oscar nomination, Rampart adds an honorable (if familiar) panel to the subgenre of the Dirty Cop, alongside Eastwood's Dirty Harry and Ferrara's Bad Lieutenant.

Mark your ballots: Dominating the entire film, Meryl Streep's towering, Oscar-caliber performance as Margaret Thatcher rises way above the limitations of the strangely nonjudgmental writing and pedestrian direction.
One of the best foreign films of the year, at once particular and universal in its concerns.

The second teaming of Diablo Cody and Reitman, a serio comic fable about the maturation of a delusional femme, is elevated considerably by Charlize Theron's full-bodied, multi-nuanced, Oscar-caliber performance.

A must-see fable for movie lovers of all ages, Hugo is full of paradoxes: a children's tale likley to be more savored by adults, a technologically-determined feature yet also personal tribute to the medium's origins and magical power.

The timely socio-economic context is just a premise for a broadly entertaining if implausibly plotted caper comedy, which lacks the glamour and stars of Soderbergh's Ocean's movies but offers Eddie Murphy one of his strongest parts in a long time.
Talented comediennes Queen Latifah and Dolly Parton (in a comeback role) are underused in this fakely energetic, increasingly silly film that ultimately boils down to catfights between them.
Semi-effective heist thriller, in which the gritty style and visual floruishes can compensate only up to a point for the formulatic tale and generic characters.
This WWII drama, centering on the suspenseful warfare between rival sumarine officers, German (Curt Jurgens) and American (Robert Mitchum, deservedly won the Special Effects Oscar.
This darkly humorous satire of an urban hospital is probably the only decent movie that Arthur Hiller had directed, benefiting from Chayefsky's Oscar winning script.
A slick, quintessential 1950s melodrama, about intrigues and leadership in the business world, well acted by an all-star cast: William Holden, Barabara Stanwyck, Fredric March, June Allyson.
Sergio Leone's Western is his undisputed masterpiece, a lush, sensuous, elegiac operatic film made on epic yet intimate scale.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Sensitive, occasionally touching romantic fable, well directed by John Cromwell and well acted by Robert Young and Dorothy McGuire.
Starring Charlton Heston and Sophia Loren at their prime, Anthony Mann's grand historical epic is still much admired by viewers and directors.
A bad but commercially popular romantic melodrama, due to Brooke Shields' celeb status at the time and the the Oscar-nominated tune by Lionel Richie.
Lavishly produced by Zanuck, this big-budget historical epic is preposterously plotted and acted, though Shamroy's color cinematography is good.

Formulaic and predictable in the way most Hollywood versions of inspirational true tales are, Big Miracle benefits from the likeable personalities of its characters and the actors who play them, Krasinksi and Barrymore.
Modest, humble, initimate and revelatory, Panahi's self-portrait concerns the socio-political conditions under which filmmakers (and all artists) work and create.
Well acted by Irene Papas, Cacoyannis' adaptation of the famous Greek tragedy was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar.

In their second appearance, Redford and Fonda have charm and show good chemistry but, they are too old for this formulatic, old-fashioned romantic comedy about a burnt-out rodeo star and TV journalist
MGM's first CinemaScope picture has not aged well (too verbose and the acting is stiff), but production values are good and Robert Taylor and Ava Gardner are handsome.
Fellini's solo directing debut, a charming fable about a newlywed couple, shows themes and characters that will reappear in his future work, not to mention the significance of wife actress Masina.
An admirable, though not completely successful, effort to resurrect the revered Hammer tradition, offering good part for Radcliffe.

Uma Thurman and Angelina Jolie move over, Gina Carano, a new riveting action star is born in Soderbergh's Haywire, a globe-trotting spy thriller, which is silly and movieish but delivers the basic goods.
A messy, poorly made thriller, in which you don't care if the hero (Sam Worthington) jumps or falls.
Disney's first live-action musical is the second, inferior version of Victor Herbert's operetta; the first, in 1934, stars Laurel and Hardy.
Announcing the arrival of a new directorial talent, Miss Bala is a powerfully haunting crime-thriller, which could be taken realistically as well as allegorically.
Set in picaresque Rome, this prepsoterously plotted romantic melodrama features heartthrob Troy Donahue (Summer Place, Parrish) at the height of his stardom with teenage viewers.
Canada's Oscar entry is a sensitively acted, precisely directed drama about children forced to deal with issues of loss and death.
Led by director-star Ralph Fiennes, all the actors deliver their lines with such passion and commitment that they make this modernist adaptation all the more effective and relevant to our times.
Though well acted, especially by Ingrid Bergman, as the woman in love with the suave Yves Montand and the boyish Anthony Perkins, the melodrama has not aged well.
Scorsese's remake (also hommage in some ways) is inferior to the original 1962 version, though the acting is good, and both Robert De Niro and Juliette Lewis garnered Oscar nominations.
Benefiting from a great cast (Van Heflin, Aldo Ray, James Whitemore), Raoul Walsh's WWII actioner is one of the most commercially popular war movies ever made.
This mediocre musical, starring Deanna Durbin in her only color film, was nominated for two Oscars.
With his physical stature and moral gravitas, the gifted Liam Neeson elevates Carnahan's survival thriller way above its familiar elements of man vs. nasty nature and cruel wolves.
Hal Roach's historical swasbuckling adventure, which features a strong woman as its hero, was nominated for the Best Sound Oscar.
Lavish, overlong, and dull, Henry King's historical adventure stars Tyrone Power in what amounted to one of Fox's biggest-budget productions.
Frenzy marked 3 kinds of return for Hitchcock: return to England after 20 years, return to form after some flops, and return to the kind of commercial film he's most clearly associated with.
This modest post-Vietnam War small-town melodrama represents the feature directing debut of actor David Carradine.
The third version of Fannie Hurst's novel, filmed in 1932 and 1941, is the weakest: Susan Hayward may be too old and too tough for the part.
Starring Alan Ladd, Mitchell Leisen's moderately engaging political melodrama, is best known for using Nat King Cole's tune, "Mona Lisa," which won the Best Song oscar.
Don't expect any factual expose about the formative years of U2; this is more of a rock farce in which the band is sort of a plot device.
A highlight of 2011 Sundance Film Fest, in its style, this intimate relationship portrait recalls some of the eraly works of the French New Wave, with a touch of Cassavetes.
Like the excellent recent documentary My Perestroika, this film is suffused with an uneasy nostalgia for the Communist heyday: simpler, more innocent, yet somehow wilder, with more at stake.
An intriguing essay about the seductivenss of evil and its price.
movie_title: Jud Suss Film Ohne Gewissen (Jew Suss: Rise and Fall) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This clever, biting high-school satire is arguably Alexander Payne's most original and accomplished film (and so far he has made only good pictures).
Bizarre, shocking and surreal, Last Circus is a significant film set against tumultuous political contexts; I wish they kept the orginal Spanish title, Sad Ballad.
There's really no reason to see this dreadful picture; better to rent the 1984 feature.
A freewheeling offshoot of the good indie Smoke
An early, interesting indie about the Cajuns that came out of Sundance Film Fest.
Though simpler than Arrowhead, John Ford's previous medical film, this tale of doctor Bull is still emotionally effective
This primitive, mythic epic catapulted Schwarzenegger to movie stardom after being a famous body-builder.
Walter Salles' humanistic approach is evident in this film, which offers a poignant look of how Brazil has changed over the past decade.
There is humor but it's too sane and too safe to qualify the film for an eccentric midnight movie
movie_title: ...And God Spoke (The Making of '...And God Spoke') (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Decades later, this avant-garde, experimental film holds up extremely well
A French crime-gangster film of epic proportions
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A messy, incoherent political thriller

Highlight of Israeli cinema and winner of major award at Cannes Fest, Footonote is an intelligent and complex film that's effective as a ferocious father-son Freudian drama and poignant staire of scholarship and recognition.
One of the most significant docums about women, culture, and society ever made.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Rosie the Riveter (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Barry Levinson deviates considerably from the wry, ironic tone of Malamud's novel, and if the film is mildly enjoyable it's due to the acting of the supporting cast and polished production values.
Preposterously plotted, highly sentimental supernatural thrillers
This Taiwanese feature was a huge hit in its country, but its appeal might not translate well in other societies.
This film teams two of Brazilian cinema's greatest actresses, the sexy Sonja Braga and the brilliant Marillia Pera (Pixote).
Disappointing film, directed by a good actor, Peter Berg, who thinks his tale is clever and witty
Susan Hayward received the first of her five Oscar nominations fo this well-acted medlodrama (woman's picture), loosely based on J.D. Salinger's story.
This suspenseful spy melodrama marks the impressive screen debut of director Jules Dassin, who was later blacklisted
This sequel to the smash-hit Father of the Bride is inferior in every respect, but it was made quickly, cheaply and generated profit for MGM.
Robert Downey Jr. gives a strong, Oscar-nominated performance, but Attenborough's disappointingly formulaic biopic doesn't capture Chaplin's genius as artist or his complex life
Another interesting film from Joe Berlinger
Peter O'Toole received an Oscar nomination for playing an eccentric womanizer and boozy star (modeled on Errol Flynn) in this charming comedy set in the 1950s.
A searing, informative documentary about the 1992 civil unrest in Los Angeles
Jesse Peretz's feature directing debut is a dull portrait of an idyllic first love between two misfits.
A funny slapstick comedy, starring Billy Murray in top form

The first big-budget, star-driven film from the very gifted Danish director Scherfig (An Education) is a disappointing romantic melodrama that mistakes kitsch for art and confuses schmaltz with emotionalism.
Essential viewing for fans of Monty Python and British comedy, this film consists of some wonderful sketches, even though Terry Gilliam doesn't appear in them.
movie_title: Monty Python's And Now for Something Completely Different (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Ditected by Michael Curtiz (Casablanca), this musical marks the feature debut of Doris Day, and its best part are the songs, including the Oscar-nominated tune, It's Magic.
Loosely based on Tolstoy's short story, it works best as a silent horror film with some poetic qualities.
movie_title: Daddy, Father Frost Is Dead (Papa, umer ded moroz)(Father, Santa Klaus Has Died) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly a labor of love, Fernando Trueba's docu is a great chronicle of Latiz jazz, its history, performers, and enduring appeal.
This modest film by the young Brian De Palma, starring the young Robert De Niro, is one of the first features that dealt with Vietnam.
Warrior is emotionally intense and decently acted, but it's too familiar as family melodrama and too manipulative as populist and inspirational sports picture.
Lynn Ramsay's third film is visually weak but themtically strong, a horror tale contesting cultural taboos about motherhood, dysfunctional families, and troubled sons.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Lebanese filmmaker Labaki's sophomore effort is politically resonant but not very deep, and it's too broad, which may explain why it won the Audience Award at the Toronto Fest.
The most upbeat cancer comedy ever made, 50/50 is effective as brom, romcom, and more.
Sigh with relief: at least this terrible exploitation feature, wasting the talents of De Niro and company, is not a remake of Sam Peckinpah's last film of the same title
This impressive directing debut is a well acted, caustically funny Irish thriller, a classic fish out of water comedy
A minor, utterly familiar and predictable father-daughter road picture melodrama, though Abigial Breslin is good
The fascinating factual story and Gerard Butler's compelling pefromance compensate up to a point for the uneven screenplay, middlebrow sensibility, and Fortser's pedestrian direction.
Hugh Jackman is the only reason to see this picture, which is essentially a retro, old-fashioned father-son melodrama.

This slight, cliche-ridden tale of the tumultuous relationship between Marilyn and Olivier is redeemed by the wonderful Michelle Willliams, who captures vividly the multi-faceted persona of the sex icon and insecure actress.

After his sophomore jinx, Brewer is back on firm ground with this retro (but not cool), old-fashioned musical remake, which you can see with your parents and grandparents due to its unabashedly corny and harmless nature.

This prequel to Carpenter film deserves some credit for trying to update the 1982 classic with new ideas, but ultimately it's disappointing due to the disproportion between the underwhelming narrative and the overwhelming effects.
The film has some charm, but the potential comic explosiveness of bringing together such major talents as Steve Martin, Jack Black, and Owen Wilson remains unfulfilled.

Wonderful collaboration: Jackson brings his dazzling technical skills and Spielberg his elegant and fluent narrative mode, resulting in a charming, meticulously made animation that takes full advantage of 3D and state of the art F/X.
The film has many flaws--overlong, episodic, earnest--and yet if does offer vivid insights into the identity formation of the cult writer as a young man and of the broader context of Puerto Rico.
Anderson and Metzler have assembled a formidable lineup of highly articulate talking heads to make the case for Fishbone's significance.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wim Wenders' tribute to (and for) the legendary choreographer Pina Bausch (who I have met several times) captures vividly the artist and her work, while putting to great use the 3D technology.
Despite few moments of cornball and some gratuitous 3D, Dolphin Tale is irresistibly cute and undeniably touching--an enjoyable film for all members of the family.
How She Does, a retro (but not in a cool way)film that's alread labeled as She Doesn't, is at least two or three decades behind the zeitgeist in subject, characterization, humor or message.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Absorbing if too earnest chronicle of youth rebellion against the rigid and repressive social order of contemporary Iran.
Unsatisfying sci-fi thriller, though it's not Charlton Heston's fault

Though not one of Almodovar's strongest works, his noir medical thriller is creepy, bizarre, and stunningly elegant to merit our attention, not to mention that Antonio Banderas is assigned his best role in decades.
Robert Duvall, Melissa Leo and the rest of the talented cast are totally wasted in this bogus spiritual golf movie, which is not even good enough as a telepic.
This 1970s-like political thriller and morality tale, which shows Clooney in top form as director, co-writer and actor, is a frontrunner in this year's Oscars; Ryan Gosling is brilliant.

This psycho-sexual melodrama is a mixed bag, well acted (Oscar-caliber turns by Fassbender and Mortensen) and elegantly shot, but too theatrical and not provocative or unsettling by Cronenberg's standards.

Artistically, this farce is a minor film from Polanski whose ineffective effort to open up the play sacrifices its wit, tension, and tempo. Jodie Foster and John C. Reilly are miscast, but Winslet and Waltz are good.
Though timely and realistic, Contagion is a mediocre thriller-disaster film, largely due to the gap between the sophisticated filmmaking and the routine (borderline banal)storytelling.

Mark your Oscar ballots: Beautifully written, splendidly acted, Alexander Payne's new serio comedy about love, forgiveness and redemption, adds another glorious panel to an already distinguished (if still brief) career.

It's unfortunate Von Trier has such bad reputaion (kicked out of Cannes due to anti-Semitic remarks), for Melancholia, a restrained, meditative film about the end of the world, boasting a terrific turn by Kirsten Dunst, is a striking work.

Best scenes in this fresh, fact-inspired, charming feature are between Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill, who (with justice) should get his first Oscar nomination. No need to know baseball to enjoy this entertaining but not great (it lacks cohesiveness) film.
Several gifted actors, Ricci, Dorff, and others, are totally wasted in this silly, unfunny comedy revolving around a single idea: a wannabe porn star who's not equipped.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: McQueen's follow-up to his stunning 2008 debut, Hunger, reteams him with the brilliant Michael Fassbender (busiest actor right now) in a dramatically intense and challenging exploration of sexual addiction and social alienation.
Intriguing, personal war docu, about small-town soldiers stuck between boyhood and manhood; a good companion piece to the fictionalized The Deer Hubter, to which this work makes reference.

A disappointingly exploitational and unnecessary remake of Peckinpah's masterpiece, a generic thriller that further suffers from the miscasting of Marsden in the role brilliantly played by Dustin Hoffman in 1971.
A kidnapping story told in simple but effective way.
Hungarian auteur Bela Tarr's final work, an historical tale that's both particular and universal, bears his unmistakable aesthetic signature.
This installment is deemed by some fans to be the best of the first Star Wars trilogy in technical accomplishment and narrative involvment, but other critics disagree.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: A Brazilian soap opera about frenzied romance with political issues in the background.
This portrait of black juveniles is technically vibrant, but it lacks a discernible POV to make it dramatically engaging.
A vastly entertaining, but cliche ridden and fictionalized biopic of the legendary performer
In this interesting, feminist indie from Nina Menkes, we get a complex portrait of a woman who may be both a victim and onlooker.
technically, the b/w film is impressive, but the tale is shallow and diffuse and has little to say about our media- saturated life and obsession with fame.

Watching this overproduced movie, which is devoid of real plot or characters, is like spending a day in amusement park, taking rides that vary in excitement, at the end of which you feel saturated and exhausted.
Austria's nominee for the Best Foreign Language Oscar is a precise and effective psychological thriler
Denys Arcand made this original movie, in which life imitates art, at the peak of his career, right after Decline of the American Empire.
Matthew Harrison's low-budget indie is a stunning debut and guerrila filmmaking at its best.
This minimalist yet revisionist indie feature (Reichardt's debut) is a highlight of the 1994 Sundance Film Fest.
One of Visconti's and Italian cinema's masterpieces
movie_title: Rocco and His Brothers (Rocco e i suoi fratelli) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Boasting top-notch cast, John Ford's very last, underestimated film celebrates the strength of women in dire conditions.
Ingmar Bergman's provocative existential drama was the first to garner him great international attention.
In this experimental film, Cassavetes' approach and a cast of unknowns brought a new sense of realism to the American cinema.

Made at the height of popularity of Astaire and Rogers, this elegant musical boasts glorious score from the Gershwins, including the songThey Can't Take That away From Me, which was nominated for an Oscar.
The French picture aims to titillate and shock with its graphic sex and violence, but ultimately it's monotonous and pretentious.
By today's standards, this small-town melodrama about hypocrisy, based on John Steinbeck's writing, is sentimental, but it made an impression when originally made.
A disappointing comedy, out of synch with the zeitgeist
Well acted by Celeste Holme and Lorette Young as French nuns in the U.S., this sentimental religious melodrama was very popular in 1949, garnering 7 Oscar nominations.
Richard Lester's inventive, humorous mockumentary of the Beatles had a huge impact, forever changing the definition and limits of the musical movie genre.
This darkly humorous ,romantic comedy between an introvert adolescent and and old spunky woman, is playing it too safe to be considered truly anti-establishment, but it became a cult picture.
Raoul Walsh's well directed crime noir marks a turning point in the career of Bogart, who became a movie star in 1941, same year in which Maltese Falcon was also released.
At 81, Christopher Plummer gives an Oscar-caliber performance (and one of his very best) as a late gay bloomer in this touching romantic comedy.
Diana Scarwid received a Supporting Actress Oscar nomination for this sensitive but uneven melodrama about an embittered disabled man, well played by John Savage.
The film examines such relevant issues as violence in school, voyeurism, and abuse.
Historically significant, Litvak's sensationalistic political melodrama is considered to be the first Hollywood anti-Nazi film made by a major studio
Another terrific, ultra-realistic family drama fom the talented Dardenne brothers, winner of Cannes Film Fest top prize.
King Vidor made a visually striking, influential feature about ordinary people and their anonymous, impersonal lives in the Big City
As a biopic, anti-Apartheid chronicle, the film is mediocre, but the young Denzel Washington is excellent, rendering an Oscar-nominated performance.

Brandauer renders a strong performance in this biopic of the Jewish and gay military officer, though the film is not as powerful or richly detailed as his portrait in Mephisto, also directed by Szabo.
Joan Fontaine received her third and last Oscar nomination for this romantic melodrama, well played by Charles Boyer.
Shifting the locale of Jim Thompson's novel to Colonial Africa, Tavernier has made a compelling, well acted film.
Though prepsoterously plotted, this vivid and colorful Western allows Clark Gable to show his macho charm and Lana Turner her sex appeal.
Jessica Lange received a well deserved Oscar nomination for this compelling chronicle of farming in the Reagan era.
Cool, stylish, vastly entertaining Hong Kong actioner from John Woo, in top form.
Anders' subject, Latinas gangs, is significant, but the treatment and execution are flawed.
The meanings of John Huston's disurbing deconstrcution of the the myth of the Old West have changed over the years due to the offscreen lives (and deaths) of the three stars: Gable, Monroe, Clift.
Mildly engaging melodrama that's more sharply written than directed.
Finland's Oscar entry is a mildly engaged melodrama about unexpected role reversal.
movie_title: Letters to Father Jacob (Postia pappi Jaakobille) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Visually striking, thematically poignant, and morally weighty, the first film of Lord of the Rings is superb.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: An AIDS drama with a twist, this is one of the best gay-themed films of the year.
movie_title: A Year Without Love (Un Ano sin amor) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The second chapter of Peter Jackson's seminal epic disffers from the first in narrative and tone, there are more battle scenes and the mood is darker.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Cars 2 is not a bad sequel, just a disappointing one (though Cars was not great either), a structurally messy animation that goes overboard as compensation for the flawed narrative.
Though the plotting is preposterous, this is John Woo's most successful American movie, demonstrating his unique signature as auetur applied to a a blockbuster.
Full of twists and turns like a thriller, James Marsh's compelling docu deals with provocative and timely issues, such as biological versus cultural determinism.
Amateurish and crude, William Castle's film is better known for its aggressive publicity campaign.
Gorris' polemic feminist film is schematic but it raises some interesting questions.
movie_title: De Stilte Rond Christine M. (A Question of Silence) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Well acted French melodrama
The tragic saga of the rise and fall of famous Argentinean magician is interesting, even if the style is too dizzying.
movie_title: El Acto en cuestión (The Act in Question) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Selznick's version of Mark Twain's famous novel is the first (and best).
Gregory LaCava was more adept at directing melodramas and screwball comedies than historical epics, such as this one.

By today's standards the film is naive and amateurish, but in 1943, it was one of the most scandalous features Hollywood has made due to Howard Hughes brilliant campaign to exploit Jane Russell's buxum.
Poor, unsuccessful cloning of Hitchcock's Vertigo
Starring Loretta Young, this Best Picture Oscar nominee belongs to a cycle of Hollywood films about doctors and nurses.
Meg Ryan gives a solid peformance in this flawed melodrama about alcoholics
movie_title: When a Man Loves a Woman (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Chaplin's hilarious comedy still is one of the most poignant critiques of modernization and mechanization of mass production.
The acting of Bob Hoskins in Jordan's disturbing Odd Couple tale is superb.
Predictable but still charming German romantic comedy, centering on the erotic appeal of food
Original and touching, this personal docu deals with the long-lasting effects of nannies on the children they take care of.
A creepy, riveting psychological thriller about desire, eroticism, and voeurism, beautifully acted by Michel Blanc and Sandrine Bonnaire.
Gabriel Figueroa's cinematography is the best element of this Mexican folk tale, which was the country's first nominee for Foreign Language Oscar.
Paul Newman's charismatic performance elevates this hodgepodge of a picture, but it is not enough.
An intriguing tale about race, sexuality, and politics in the New London, splendidly played by Daniel day Lewis as the gay punk.
Dramatically intense and relentlessly grim Israeli drama about the complex relationship between an aging prostitute and her teenage daughter.
Robin Williams gets a chance to stretch as an actor in this semi-effective thriller.
It's probably a coincidence that two of our most beautiful and sexiest stars (Julia Roberts is the other, in Larry Crowne) play foul-mouthed, heavy drinking teachers in high- concept comedies.
Taylor's charming comedy owes its existence to Fellini's I Vitelloni and Barry Levinson's Diner.
A routine thriller, curiosuly disappointing from Alan Pakula that even stars like Denzel Washington and Julia Roberts can't rescue
This bad-taste comedy put John Waters on the map as the propeht of low budget, trashy but signficant indie films
As the aging actress, Vivien Leigh is good but Warren Beatty is miscast as the gigolo in this weak screen adaptation of Tennessee William's novella.
movie_title: The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Whitney Ransick's promising feature debut, influenced by Hal Hartley and Tarantino, is well acted by treat Williams and the rest of the ensemble.
Victor Nunez's interesting first feature, which he wrote and directed, helped define regional independent cinema.
Norma Aleandro received an Oscar nomination for this sentimental family drama
An impressive feature debut about the nature of love and loss, as felt by a group of characters, some of which gay.
Though less complex and softer than former efforts, Dardennes' new film is an emotionally compelling, ultra-realistic coming-of-age morality tale, well acted by Thomas Doret and Cecile de France.
A signifcant feminist indie about sexual difference, desire, and gaze.
Metaphysical in narrative, ambitious in goal, surreal in style, suerbly acted by Brad Pitt (who should get Oscar nomination), this is Malick's career-summation film, his masterpiece.
Kurosawa's masterully executed acion film influenced many young directors, including Segio Leone.
This feature debute, which gives good name to American indie cinema, is worth revisiting on DVD for the performances of Mark Ruffalo and Laura Linney.
Cacoyannis emerged out of semi-retirement with this amusing farce about the wild and crazy inhabitants of modern-day Athens.
movie_title: Pano, kato kai plagios, (Up, Down and Sideways) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: William Castle tries but fails with this one.
The impersonations of Sean Connery, Michael Caine an dothers are hilarious and there some witty one-liners, but the mockumentary overextends its welcome by at least 20 minutes.
Relevant and informative, Page One is a must-see documentary about the creation, operation, and consumption of news at a time of transformation and revolutionary change.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The sequel has some mildly amusing moments, but it has a slapdash quality to it, and at 102 minutes, it feels padded.

Taking the story back to its roots, Vaughn has made some shrewd decisions, reflected in the superb cast (McAvoy and Fassbender stand out) and the use of Cold War context, which evokes the early, much admired James Bond pictures.
It's too bad that the execution of this Paul Newman starring film is so poor for it raises some interesting social and political issues
This Canadian Western suffers from an overfamiliar concept; it's yet another version of the Cain and Abel mythology.
movie_title: Dos Hermanos, una Chica y un Arma (1993)

movie_review_blurb: One of 2011 best American films: Showing another facet of his considerable talent, Ryan Gosling is compelling as an action star in this noir thriller, which combines elements B-level Hollywood flicks and stylish European art films.
Slick, sexy, and charming, this romantic comedy should catapult the gifted Reese Witherspoon to major movie stardom
As a director and actress, the Gallic Maiwenn is a talent to watch.
movie_title: Le Bal des actrices (All About Actresses)(The Actress' Ball) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though stereotypical, this interracial romantic melodrama was one of William Holden's most popular films
Warmhearted, original, but not entirely successful tribute to classic Hollywood movies of the 1930s, specifically Capra's You Can't Take It With You.
Reuniting with Andrew Gregory, Louis Malle, in what became his swan song, has made a modern, captivation version of the Chekhov play.
A timely political drama, well acted by Nick Nolte and Gene Hackman.
Sidney Lumet's all-black musical, starring Diana Ross, is a failed effort to transfer the setting of the Judy Graland musical to contempo Manhattan.
Intriguing but ultimately flawed Western that shows Brando talent as an actor and director.
This good natured, episodic spoof of gangster movies was Woody Allen's first film as a director.
An original, personal, emotionally touching documentary, which represents a new type of indie, based on innovating filmmaking.
One of the most significant feminist works made, Jeanne Dileman is a masterwork in thematic, aesthetic, and formal-theoretical ways.
movie_title: Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Light and gimmicky, self-reflexive and shallow, Allen's time-travel romantic comedy is an amusing, occasionally witty love letter to Paris the city and the myth.
In many ways, John Badham's intriguing tale was prophetic.
Gary Cooper gives a commanding performance in William Wyler's popular 1940 Western, which features Walter Brennan in an Oscar-winning turn
A highlight of the Sundance and Cannes Film Fest, this is a powerful, eerie film, grounded by a great performance from Michael Shannon
Though decently shot and acted, Van Sant's romantic melodrama might be one of his simplest and most conventional films, lacking his personal signature.
The narrative leaves much to be desired, but compared to the previous 2 chapters, at least it offers some thrills, sporadic humor and fun, not to mention Spanish spitfire Penelope Cruz.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A sentimental, mildly enjoyable musical starring Bing Crosby
Physical, visceral, intimate, and even sensual, Lebnaon, a highlight of Israeli cinema of the past decade, is a combat film like no other war film you have seen before
The gifted actress Forte plays a Cuban-American woman fighting to have a viable career amidst many problems.
Cukor's movie is less successful as a musical than as a star vehicle (one of her very last) for Marilyn Monroe, who is at her sexiest.
A relevant, well documented docu about a shameful chapter of history
This screen version of Tennessee Williams's noted play is poorly directed (it' still theater), but it's well acted by Geraldine Page
This charming French film about the friendhsip between a German soldier and a French girl was nominated for the 1962 Foreign Language Oscar.
movie_title: Sundays and Cybele (Les Dimanches de Ville d'Avray) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: No doubt, the film is cruel and manipulative, but it's also the scariest thriller I've ever seen.
Victor Nunez's second film is a superb charcater-driven ecological thriller, toplined by Ed Harris
This sequel to the 1990 picture contains some funny scenes and witty one-liners.
A significant docu about the horror of imprisonment of Polish Jews during WWII
Mildly engaging, Dark Habits, Almodovar's third features about nuns on the run, is not as satirical or entertaining as his previous or later films.
Mickey Rooney received a well-deserved Oscar nomination for this war drama about American soldiers in Italy
A handsome, intriguing chronicle of the internationally famous ballet company
Laurence Olivier gives one of his most riveting, Oscar-nominated performances in this bleak drama about a selfish, aging, pathological vaudevillian.
Hartley's three-part anthology, a semi-academic treatise about the limits of narrativity, offers some minor rewards.
Arteta's third feature is good step in the right direction, for him as a disrector and for Jennifer Anniston as an actress
The lead, Ileana Douglas, is good, but the musical film suffers from repetitive structure and lack of sufficiently interesting ideas.
A quintessential film noir of the 1980s, much underestimated at the time of release.
The message of this stirring feature is relevant, going beyond its particular political context
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The third version of the classic is better than the second (in 1948) and almost as touching as Cukor's first rendition in 1933, toplining Kathatrine Hepburn.
One of Murnau's classic silent films features a great performance from Emil Jannings, who three years later became the first Best Actor Oscar winner.
One of the best foreign language films of the year
Though not one of Sayles' best efforts, this indie about a lesbian coming out is well acted.
This father-son melodrama is well acted, but it's too solemn and too concerned with being inspirational
One of the freshest indies of the 1990s, Laws of Gravity offers an ultra-realistic depiction of terrifying nihilism
This early, socially-conscious film by Joseph Losey, before he was blacklisted, deals with racial discrimination in a powerful way.
This small-town family melodrama, a quintessential 1950s film in its themes and tensions, is well acted by Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward, Lee Remick.
Lighter than the usual Ken Loach feature, Looking for Eric marks a departure of sorts for the solemn director, but ultimately, it's a minor work.
Though it's the weakest of the three panels that form Kaurismaki's trilogy, which began with Drifting Clouds in 1996, it's still worth seeing.
A derivative, senseless movie that owes its entire existence to Tarantino.
movie_title: The Last Days of Frankie the Fly (1997)

movie_review_blurb: A dull, borderline inept action-prison drama, in which lead star Robert Redford is totally wasted.
Decently avted by Hoffman and Thompson, this is a middlebrow, TV-like melodrama that goes out of its way to show the possibility of new romances and new beginnings at any age.
This environmental documentary is more impressive in goal and intent than in dramatic or technical execution.
Almodovar's second film is, among other things, a satirical critique of mainstream culture definition of love

Abrams channels conventions and cliches of 1950s genre movies by way of paying tribute to Spielberg's classics, resulting in a nostalgic, sharply uneven tale that lacks the master's coherent and elegant style.
Paul Newman gives a strong performance as an army captain charged with collaboration during the Korea War.
Timely and intriguing docu was the winner of the Directing and Audience Awards at the Sundance Film Fest.
Interesting, provocative film about one of the most polarizing issues in our culture.
A visionary work, Aguirre is one of Herzog's greatest achievements.
movie_title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (Aguirre, der Zorn Gottes) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: A sensitive meditation about the inner journey of a young woman
The only reason to this ultra-modest, underwhelming indie is Laura Linney's performance as a mature woman falling for a man half her age.
A riveting documentary that unfolds as a political thriller.
Misconceived and curiously uninvolving political melodrama, despite the urgent subject.

Sporadically engaging, Milos Forman's chronicle of American society and culture in the beginning of the twentieth century is too sprawling and dramatically diffuse, though some of the acting is excellent.

Adding a panel to the growing literature of Jewish folklore, this vivid, absorbing portrait illuminates the life and work of one of the most beloved Jewish figures, known until now as the writer of Tevye the Milkman (Fiddler on the Roof).
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: British actor Ronlad Colman gives a suave, compelling performance in a dual role
Jacques Tourneuer's most accomplished film and a great sampler of film noir, sort of a textbook both visually and thematically.
This trashy melodrama, based on John O'Hara novel, who also provided the story for Butterfield 8, is poorly executed and mostly known for its Oscar nomination.
Tyrone Power is miscast, but by standards of the time, this was a prestige, lavish production, winning an Oscar for Special Effects (spectacular flood).
A disappointingly schamltzy romantic melodrama that will not do much to promote Robert (Twilight) Pattinson's career as legit actor.
Stylistically bold, impressive feature debut about creative youth
Visually impressive sci-fi noir
Enjoyable if not one of the great Astaire-Rogers musicals, Roberta received nomination for the Best Song Oscar (Lovely to Look At).
The film's prisoners of war are so familiar and stereotypical as characters that this Vietnam movie feels like a genre item.
In this disappointing collaboration between Craig and Norman (Longtime Companion), Mia Farrow plays yet another mousy and abused housewife.
We have seen it before: The movie throws together two individuals (Shirley Maclaine and Nicolas Cage) who could not have been more different and then shows us how they learn to respect each other.
Time has made Kimberly Peirce's dramatic debut about sexual misfit, stunningly played by Hilary Swank, even more relevant and powerful.
For Durbin fans: This silly serio comedy was shot by the famous French director Jean Renoir but Universal interfered and imposed songs and retakes.
Classic of German Expressionism
Shainebrg's film lacks genuine suspense, erotic charge, or intriguing characters.
A sporadically entertaining but utterly conventional chronicle of Hollywood's musical genre.
movie_title: Hollywood Singing and Dancing: A Musical History - The 1980s, 1990s & 2000s (1980)

movie_review_blurb: David Mamet's modern, intriguing morality play is well acted by Joe Mantegna.
Milos Forman's screen version of the landmark musical production is uneven, though there's no doubt it would have been better received had been made earlier, during the Vietnam War.
The inventive director King Vidor reeceived a well-deserved Oscar nomination for making MGM's first all-black feature, shot on locations and later dubbed for sound.
Paul Muni gives a dramatically intense, Oscar-nominated performance as a coal miner fighting union corruption.
Philip Kaufman's erotic chronicle of Henry Miller in Paris, the first movie to get NC-17, is disappointingly long and uneventful, though nice to look at.
This wannabe thriller about the new techno industry is a misfire.
This indie is original in intent but disappointing in execution
Defined by darker mood and greater gravity than previous chapters, this film concludes the series on a high note that should please viewers and get serious attention as Oscar contender.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Off-the-wall and incoherent but colorful and eccentric, this satire, benefiting from a great cast, became a cult item.
A gay romantic comedy that's amateurish in both the negative and positive senses of the term.
Disney's doubleheader is intermittently witty adaptation of classic literature, narrated by Bing Crosby (who also sings) and Basil Rathbone.
movie_title: The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad (1949)

movie_review_blurb: Bo Widneberg, better known as the director of Elvira Madigan, made this Oscar nominated Swedish film about a strike.
The movie sounds like a high-concept commercial comedy, but it's quite funny and the whip-smart script contributes to the level of enjoyment of the cast.
The romantic subplot of this WWII melodrama, Tyrone Power's last film before going to war, is weak, but the action sequences (in color) are good.
Timely political documentary that resolves one set of issues while rsiaing others.
This musical western spoof was bold in its stylized art direction (nominated for Oscar), but proved to be critical and commercial failure due to lackluster cast and mediocre songs.
Effective adaptation of Charles Dickens novel, well acted by Reginald Owen and the rest of the cast.
A well acted adaptation of William Faulkner's last novel, offering good roles for Steve McQueen and Rupert Cross, only the second black to receive an oscar nomination by 1969.
Quiet, subtle and tocuhing, this drama of a widower is extremely well acted by Hinds and Aidan Quinn
Aronofsky's second feature is an emotionally intense, relentlessly grim tale of forms of addiction that may rely too much on montage to achieve real dramatic impact.
A throwback to the psycho-sexual thrillers of the 1980s, Fear is sort of a male version of Fatal Attraction
One of the masterpieces of Japanese and world cinema.
Overly concerned with making a film about the fans for the fans, but they forgot to ask, is it any good?
This remake, starring Lana Turner, of the 1939 The Rains Came is not as compelling, but the special effects (nominated for Oscar) are good
Despite the presence of two great actresses, High Heels is a disappointing film, as a murder mystery and mother-daughter melodrama.

Not as good as the first Iron Man, not as bad as Green Lantern, it's almost a necessary, even obligatory panel toward next year's Avengers, but as a stand-alone adventure, it leaves much to be desired.
A disappointing film, Remo Williams was meant as a star vehicle for Fred ward and as the first chapter of a franchise, but, alas, neither thing happened.
Very much in the British tradition of literary quality, this intimate, intelligent film is extremely well acted by Tom Conti in an Oscar-nominated performance.

Sharply uneven, this smart, timely rom-com benefits from the strong chemistry, in and out of bed, between Kunis and Timberlake before it succumbs to the level of formulatic and predictable TV sit com.
A riveting chronicle of the 1933 disaster that Stalin and the Communist Party had never acknowledged
Droll, quirky documentary
Though this controversial film about romantic, sado-masochistic love in the hetero world is weak and ultimately disappointing, it's still worth seeing for understanding Almodovar's evolution.
movie_title: Átame! (Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!) (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Vet French actor Michel Bouquet renders an astonishing performance in this intriguing family drama.
The drama becomes more intriguing as the story moves along

It's hard to think of another filmmaker who has done so much for the representation of Chinese and Chinese-American on screen, and yet his latest melodrama, a multi-generational chronicle of female friendship, is disappointing.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The acting of Liz Taylor and Monty Clift is not bad, but MGM's effort to recreate another successful Civil war melodrama in the mold of Gone With the Wind is disppointing for many different reaons.
This aunting film noir, easily John Frankenheimer's best film, is satisfying on any level, narrative, visual, ideological, and acting.
A modest period drama about the complex relationship between a repressed instructor and his young pupil.

Inspired by Bergman's Smiles of a Summer Night, andwith a touch of Renoir's Rules of the Game, this period comedy is a minor work, a trifle in Allen's career, worth seeing for some of the supporting acting.
Lamorisse's lyrical tale, largeky told through imagery, holds up extremely well, and it's still the only short feature to ever win a major Oscar (original screenplay).
Earnest, uplifting baseball melodrama
This touching, well acted Swedish family drama was nominated for the Best Foriegn Language Oscar.
An interesting documentary, though not as deep or as absorbing as Shohah.
This Russian epic about Ivan the Terrible offers a new angle and has other merits, but inevitable comparisons will be made with maestro Eisenstein classic version.
Susan Hayward plays one of her typical tough, ambitious women in this romantic adventure, a chronicle of the emergence of Tulsa as the land of oil.
This loose remake of Joseph H. Lewi classic assumes the shape of an exploitation B-picture, but it has some merits, including Drew Barrymore's performance.
A flawed adaptation of Swift's novel, though the acting of Jeremy Irons and others is good.
Boleslawksi's lavish production of this historical melodrama is best known today as the only film that all three Barrymores (John, Ethel and Lionel) made together.
In this noir sports melodrama, which is his final screen role, Bogart gives a powerful performance.
Visually inventive version of Gray's monologue, though the material is not as interesting as that of Swimming to Cambodia.
Made in 1984, this seminal documentary chronicles powerfully the participation of American soldiers in the Spanish Civil War.
Huey Long continues to fascinate filmmakers, both of docus and features
movie_title: Kingfish: A Story of Huey P. Long (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Very esrly and strange sci-fi, and a musical at that, by director David Butler
A mildly amusing comedy that blends straight and gay characters together
A heartfelt coming of age tale of an Hungarian-American adolescent, well acted by Scarlett Johansson
In this fun musical, Betty Hutton gives perhaps an overenergetic peformance in a part that was intended for Judy Garland before she was fired.
Sillier, less entertaining than the first picture
Salween's screwball comedy is a disappointing follow-up to his promising debut, Denise Calls Up.
Stylish and intriguing mystery tale made on a low budget

It's too bad exec-producer Spielberg doesn't exercise tighter control over Bay's machine-like picture, which takes James Cameron's motto (size matters) to its silliest and illogical conclusion, resulting in a noisy, soulless metallic product.
This engaging melodrama about the effects of Nazism on a young boy was the Netherland's nominee for the Foreign Langauge Oscar.
Derivative and awkward horror tale
A low-budget, well-executed, quintessentially sci-fi of the 1950s
One of Louis Malle's most personal and significant films.
A powerful documentary about the daily struggles of families raising children with autism.
An innovative, highly influential New York indie, made by Moris Engel in ultra-realistic style
A banal and sappy romantic melodrama
Sensitive handling of touchy issues and good acting elevate this Canadian melodrama above the routine and sentimental.
Paul Newman is good as the gangster, but Ann Blyth is miscast in this rise and fall biopic of the famous singer.
Eddie Cantor travels back in time in this amusing musical adventure
Contemporary life in Brazil as seen through the eyes of one working class family.
Frank Tuttle's entertaining musical revolves around the ideas of similar looks, mistaken identities
This well acted indie comedy belongs to a cycle of 1980s films about yuppies, several of which star Griffin Dunne.
Morgan Freeman reprises his role from Kiss the Girls in this inferior psychological thriller
Claire Trevor won a Supporting Oscar for playing the alcoholic mistress of Edward G. Robinson's gangster in John Huston's taut crimer starring Bogart.
Based on Hemingway's short stories, Martin Ritt's chronicle is long, rambling, disappointing film in which Richard Beymer is miscast as the young novelist.
movie_title: Heningway's Adventures of a Young Man (1962)

movie_review_blurb: Elaine May's feature not only stars John Cassavetes, but also feels like a tribute to his work (particularly Husbands).
This Nicaraguan melodrama, starring Dean Stockwell as an American pilot, was nominated for the Foreign Language Oscar.
movie_title: Alsino y el Cóndor (Alsino and the Condor) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Told in song and dance, this Spanish tragic love story was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar.
Old-fashioned, sprawling saga of a Mexican American community
movie_title: And the Earth Did Not Swallow Him (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Rene Clair's character-driven, well acted drama was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar.
One of Buster Keaton's most hilarious and most popular comedies
A funny comedy, done is slapstick style, about a single but origianl idea of how a bottle of Coke changes the entire lifestle of a tribe.
A gripping action thriller that's also extremely well acted by Jon Voight and Eric Roberts in Oscar-nominated performances.
A pleasant but routine star vehicle for Bing Crosby, with an Oscar winning song that created a scandal at the time.
With this well executed drama, a follow-up to her La Cienega, Lucrecia Martel emerges as a major Argentinean filmmaker.
Uninspired follow-up to the original comedy
One of Spielberg's two or three masterpieces, an extremely satisfying sci-fi fable.
Though too verbose and static, it's the first film to deal explicitly with gay life in China, and as such adds a panel to the growing body of movies about sexual politics in rigid societies.
movie_title: East Palace West Palace (Dong gong xi gong) (Behind the Forbidden City) (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Two great actors, Michel Serrault and Natalie Baye, elevate considerably this French family drama.
The great stage actress Elisabeth Bergner received an Oscar nomination for this melodrama, in which she plays an unwed mother.
A minor comedy in Allen's work, though Mia Sorvino, who won an Oscar, shines as the prostitute, despite the director's condescending
The third segment in Carlos Saura's musical trilogy that also includes Flamenco and Tango.
Savoca's second film also deals with sexual politics, centering on a type of woman seldom seen in American movies
Lumet's tense political drama is riveting, but unfortunately it was released the same year as Kubrick's similarly-themed Dr. Strangelove, which was a satire and more thus more popular
This Oscar-nominated film recreates in a realistic, powerful way the Neapolitan resistance to the Nazis in 1943.
movie_title: Le Quattro Giornate di Napoli (The Four Days of Naples) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: While the subject of this Israeli feature is riveting and the intention honorable, the narrative strategy and technical execution leave much to be desired.
A playful, colorful spectacle from the late era of Renoir.
The movie benefits from an interesting subject and good acting, I just wish it were more focused and deep.
Breillat's enchanting desconstrcution of the classic fable suggests how rich the source material is and why it has continued to provoke generations of filmmakers.

The screen version is still a play, but it's aturning point in the movie career of Humphrey Bogart, who had played the gangster's role on stage and then in a TV version with his wife (in Bette davis role)
Tim Burton's tribute to the B sci-fi-alien genre of the 1950s is sharply uneven, but the top-notch cast, dark humor, and production values offer some pleasure.
Shot in stylized black-and-white, this docu about the homeless was the winner of multiple awards at the Sundance Film Fest.
Blegium's Oscar nominee is a worthy historical drama about the involvement of priests in the labor movement.
Though not one of Wyler's best films (it's still a play), the drama is well acted by Kirk Douglas as the tormented and obsessive cop and Lee Grant as a juvenile delinquent.
The weakest film in the House Party series
Tom Hanks' second feature as director is an embarrassinly naive romantic comedy, which propagates a simplistically upbeat view of American society as one big happy melting pot.
Laurent Cantet makes a brilliant feature debut in this timely and compelling French drama, in which a young man learns to take personal responsibility in both work and familt matters.
The premise is clever but the film is not bold enough
Leslie Caron received a second Oscar nomination for this British film, in which she plays a French feeme in London, who decides to keep her out of the wedlock baby.
Claudette Colbert gives a charming performance as a reporter who falls for Ray Milland's soldier of fortune
Stylish but emotionally hollow, Paul Schrader's morality tale of a callboy (played by Richard Gere), offers some visual pleasures, including Armani's slick wardrobe.
Almodovar's most accomplished and most commercially successful comedy to date.
movie_title: Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown (Mujeres al Borde de un Ataque de Nervios) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: In this quintessential Danny Kaye vehicle, which won the special effects Oscar, the star plays the first of his several screen twins, a shy intellectual and a club entertainer.
Though she doesn't look or sing as Billie Holiday, Diana Rosss gives a commendable performance in this fictionalized biopic, for which she received an Oscar noimination.
This coolly detached WWII chronicle, which is critical of the French Resistance, is one of Louis Malles' strongest and most personal films.
A disturbing, well-acted, French-style amour fou
This indie film pays tribute to a misunderstood hero of the Latino community.
The structure of this Vietnam War docu is not particularly interesting, but the contents are.
movie_title: Dear America: Letters Home from Vietnam (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Stylishly seductive and well-acted by Al Pacino and Keanu Reeves, but thematically flawed, Taylor Hackford's film is yet another version of the Faustian morality tale.
This trashy adventure-melodrama is the second in the film series that began in 1970.
Denzel Washington is a reliable actor, giving a commanding performance, but it's hard to see why this actioner was a hot property on a list of unproduced spec scripts.
A trio of appealing actors, especially Witherspoon, are wasted in this unsuccessful hybrid of action comedy
The Pop of Trash's follow-up to Pink Flamingos is a more hilarious, shocking and poignant feature, with Divine in top form.
Well acted but sentimental small-town melodrama about a teacher who has devoted all of her life to work.
Starring Dick Van Dyke, this pleasant family fable with music was nominated for the Best Song Oscar
A routine Boris Karloff horror flick from Universal, nominated for the Interior Decoration Oscar.
Mikhalkov's beautifully shot tale of the impact of modernization on rural Mongolia was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar.
Slow, deliberate and too literal, this Sundance indie is mostly notable for offering the gifted Paul Dano a good part.

The film is not as dramatically compelling or cohesive as the 2007 Blood, but it's provocative in ideas and supremely acted by Phoenix and Hoffman (Oscar caliber turns), reaffirming Anderson's status as one of the boldest directors today.
Stylishly directed by Robert Siodmak, this film noir is uncharacteristic fare for both Deanna Durbin and Gene Kelly.
There's considerable gap between the film's ambition, which is to be a high-minded literary feature a la Atonement or The Hours, and its actual level of execution.

There are not many revelations in this docu of Polanski, but it's refreshing that it restores the balance between the director's background and incredibly creative career and the 1977 sex scandal that's dominated the media for decades.
Ayer's new film is not as riveting as Training Day, but it's well acted and dynamically directed, adding another honorable panel to the genre of the gritty, visceral urban policier.

Riveting, scary, and significant, Film Unfinished contrasts invaluable footage of agit-prop Nazi feature with the reaction of Warsaw Gehtto survivors to that footage and testimonies of the real life thee.
Richard Gere, always reliable but underestimated actor, gives one of his strongest, most dominant performances in Jarecki's taut thriller, one that should finally garner him Oscar nomination.
Gary Cooper is credibly cast, but this revenge Western is too verbose, lacking much drama.
Whimsical and occasionally witty, this inside-Hollywood comedy benefits from its all star Paramount cast.
Sharply observed and laced with poignant humor, Ben Affleck's gripping political thriller is his most fully realized film to date, and his first chance to get the attention of Oscar voters.
Starring Gary Cooper and Lili Plamer, Fritz Lang's WWII melodrama is one of the first Hollywood pictures to deal with the global threats of the atomic bomb.
The directors, best known for the the seminal 1933 King Kong, received for their jungle docudrama an Oscar nomination for Unique and Artistic Picture.
movie_title: Chang: A Drama of the Wilderness (1927)

movie_review_blurb: One of Disney's most admired feature animations, Cinderella was nominated for several Oscars.
Charles Laughton renders a grandly theatrical performance as the infamous pirate, a role he would spoof in a 1952 comedy.
Part fantasy, part mystery, part women's melodrama, part musical, but not satisfying on any of these levels.
The only good thing in this campy Joan Crawford mental hospital flick is the Oscar-nominated cinematography by Lucien Ballard.
This Oscar-nominated, lavishly produced musical catapulted Gene Kelly and Rita Hayworth to major stardom.
The shortest flick this summer is also one of the worst, a ghastly ghost story that fails to deliver its generic goods on any level.
Decades later, Bunuel's first feature still is the seminal surrealist film, a powerful assemblage of shocking images aimed to provoke and irritate.
More titillating than provocative, and lacking wit to make this tale of inventing the vibrator more significant and entertaining as serio-comedy.
Spanning a short period of time, this tense and intense Norweigian drama about a drug addict is extremely well directed and acted.
The only Western Jack Lemmon, better known for embodying on screen urban angst, has made, Cowboy is well acted by him and Glenn Ford.
Though not one of Preminger's stronger films, it's still worth seeing this fact-based courtroom drama starring Gary Cooper.
Sharply uneven, Coppola's period musical about he famous Harlem club is lavishly produced but shallow.
James Cagney's first color film, an aviation tale, was Oscar nominated for Cinematography and Interior Decoration
